The majority of hours labelled on my review went into Frackin Universe. Do not buy this game to play it without modifications (which are available on the Workshop).

The base game (while not exactly bare bones) has a lot of wasted potential. I am a sucker for open world games and space exploration. If this game had more diverse options for gathering resources on different planets, as well as a wider variety of means to customize the ship, it would probably be my favorite game of all time.
Starfield is it was good

I dunno. It's good if you like decorating I guess.

There's no real sense of progression. Sure you'll upgrade your armour and weapons and move to a higher tier of environment, but all the enemies, all the tactics and frankly all the environments remain the same from start to finish. At hour 1 you're wandering the surface of a planet, using a spear to stab guys with guns. At hour 2 you're wandering the surface of a "higher tier" planet and the guys with guns take more spear stabs, then at hour 3 you have a better spear and the guys with guns take the same number of stabs as they did at hour 1. It's progression of a sort but leaves a lot to be desired.

Everything is easy. But that doesn't make it quick. The whole game feels like one fetch quest after another. Maybe you like the idea of being a bounty hunter at first, but then you realise that the loop is just "fly to planet > find guy with gun > kill guy with gun (easy) > fly back" repeated again and again. It doesn't change. There are no hard fights.

Too much of the game feels like errands and busywork. You're ready for the next "leader" bounty mission... but it doesn't unlock until you spend an hour flying from planet to planet killing low level minions that pose no challenge. You're ready for the next story boss... but you can't face them until you've explored the surface of a bunch of harmless planets first.

And then you kill a story boss and... nothing changes. I haven't faced the T4 boss yet, but even so, I know what will happen after.
I'll get a mission to explore some T5 planets.
I'll go to one and automatically die due to it being too hot/cold/slimy.
I'll craft a heat/cold/slime repellent backpack.
I'll go to the T5 planet again. Now it doesn't kill me.
I'll fight one or two familiar enemies I've fought before but with higher stats.
I'll dig into the center of the planet and mine out the T5 resource. This will not be hard. The environment will be the same.
I'll make the T5 armour. I'll use whatever T5 weapon I found in a chest on the surface of some harmless planet, or maybe just the T5 weapons that dropped from the T4 boss.
I'll fight the guys again. Now they feel exactly like the T4 enemies from an hour ago.
I'll spend and hour exploring harmless planets looking for monkey/bird/lizard culture to scan. Mostly I'll run through familiar villages spam clicking the things and people until I'm told I can fight the T5 boss.
I'll unlock and fight the T5 boss. It will be easy.
I'll start again from line 1. Increment tier, change colour to "mauve" and it's sea-people now.

I can't help but entertain a certain cynicism...

TL:DR - Main game is AWESOME - cool mechanics, cool gameplay with lots of variability for such a genre. 
Mechs (not a part of main game) are GRINDY and boring, and throw the balance of main game out of the window sometimes.

[b] What i enjoyed a LOT: [/b] 
- Artstyle (cute)
- Game's lore and whole metauniverse is well-developed and opens up gradually
- Good main quest line progression
- Playstyle variability (Mining, Shooting-Looting, Farming, Villaging, or Subquests)
- Rich plarformer mechanics (Jump/Jet/Blink/Dash/Sprint/Grappling Hook/Sticky Ball)
- Rich fighting system (one-handed weapons and items can be combined, two-handed weapons have SPECIAL MOVES which are really cool)
- Side-content scattered around the world, is rather detailed
- Collectables - usually i'd dislike them, but in this game they feel actually interesting to seek out (cooking, pokemon-like catching, unique items), and aren't forced.
- Cool easter eggs and references!

[b] What i was okay about: [/b]
- It's about space but there's not a lot of "space" stuff happening. Your ship is just a cool personalizeable hub that's linked to player, with overworld map built in.

[b] What i didn't like (but that's okay)[/b]
- The whole universe is evenly populated and easily predictable. this makes game's world feel oversaturated and fake (at least on second or third playthrough). Planets either are completely barren (literal sandboxes), or are guaranteed to contain a few outposts and a few dungeons. [spoiler]There are no "city" planets like we see in the intro.[/spoiler] Some places that should at least feel special and unique, are rather common after some further exploration. However, i get why it's made that way - purely for fun factor. It's a sandboxy platformy crafty game after all.
- While overall soundtrack is very good and really fits the game, it gets repetitive after a while due to game's pacing. And barren planets music gets boring after a first loop or so.

[b] What i didn't like[/b]
- The mech progression is painfully slow and grindy, unlike the whole other game.
- Mechs feel too OP for the main game, like they should show up way after where they are.
- The whole game progression is artificially slowed down by the need to craft or loot, but it is still relatively easy to overlevel your character and fly past certain areas and skip some content. Although on the other hand, it may be good for replayability.
- There are some mechanics that make it really easy to abuse the game with no skill required. Spoiler: 
[spoiler](2 daggers = infinite stun, rerolling villagers (aspecially traders) should've been limited)[/spoiler]

Starbound is pretty good. Despite abandonment by the developers a few years back, it still remains a nice, compact game. Starbound can be compared to similar games, such as Terraria, but is usually rendered as below such. In my opinion, from experience, I would say that Starbound has way more potential than Terraria. A marvelous idea, but with a slightly lesser-quality execution than expected. The one thing I enjoy the most about Starbound is its modding community, which is the only thing keeping the game alive as of right now. Some of the more major mods fit the theme of the game more than the game itself, and sometimes feel like more time and effort was put into them, especially in terms of sound and visual design. In conclusion, I would give Starbound a solid 8/10.

To this day I struggle to decide if Starbound is a disappointing shitfest or just slightly entertaining in an underwhelming sort of way. In order to understand why this is, I must tell you my tale. 

CHAPTER 1: The Happy Times
My tale begins at the beta stages of this seemingly promising game, when the ugly design choices and painful gameplay pacing was balanced with an interesting and challenging gameplay structure that offered what felt like endless possibilities. Little by little, there was more content, fun mods, and a very solid multiplayer system. All in all, Starbound was on the up and up. It had survival mechanics, biomes, deep character development and a slowly growing backstory. I had a lot of fun playing it with friends and enjoying the satisfying gameplay loop of visiting other planets, finding cool stuff, and then bringing it back to our ever growing base full of memories and personal touches that added to a cool player made narrative. 

And I can pinpoint the exact moment when everything went to shit. 

Chapter II: The Exact Moment When Everything Went To Shit
At some point, there was a patch. This patch proceeded to break everyone's mods, as is the telltale sign of crappy game developers (seriously, it's actually quite easy to preserve people's mods through various workarounds as far as modern computing goes). 

See, up until this point, Starbound had a great gameplay mechanic that made the world feel more grounded. Namely, temperature. A realtime temperature system that required you to manage heat as an environmental resource. This resulted in gameplay that rewarded a slower crawl, and made you value your upgrades and spatial management. It was a fantastic feature because of how it really stimulated your creative problem solving skills. But then, a dark shadow loomed over the horizon... namely, focus groups. 

First, they came for the temperature system, but I said nothing, since I wasn't registered on the Starbound forum. Then they began to nerf the ship building, the biomes and little by little, the game was slowly being refurbished into a linear experience full of contrivances and shoehorned plot elements. Now you had to meet boolean requirements to do stuff, and the creativity was dead. All in an effort to appease idiots who like casual games on their horrible phones and tablets. 

Chapter III: Conclusion
Obviously the warning signs were always there. The artstyle clearly speaks to a sort of primordial force of stupidity in its patronising efforts to constantly look cutesy in an upbeat corporate dystopia sort of way. Like it was made by a marketing team rather than real humans, and how it was driven by mass appeal rather than anything one could respect as dignified creative impulses. 

And if you don't think this game was designed for idiots, then keep in mind that the combat features both health bars AND floating damage numbers. Even people who write "L" and "R" at the bottom of their shoes would find that patronising.

This game had promise, and it was a lot of fun. But in the end, it became yet another piece of mass produced garbage intended to placate the emotional needs of people who, in a just world, ought to spend a few years in a re-education camp brushing up on things like critical thinking and self-awareness before being allowed anywhere near a human civilisation. 

All in all I think this game speaks to the darker impulses of the human condition, and I believe future historians will find its timeline as a useful reference point in figuring out where the NATO countries' equivalent of the Caligula years began to crop up.

Starbound isn't just a game; it's an odyssey through the cosmos, a journey that encapsulates the spirit of exploration and discovery. Developed by Chucklefish, this sandbox action-adventure game invites players to traverse the boundless expanse of space, uncovering mysteries, forging alliances, and shaping worlds to their whims. With its captivating blend of procedurally generated planets, rich lore, and endless possibilities, Starbound stands as a testament to the boundless creativity of indie game development.

Gameplay:
At the heart of Starbound lies its expansive gameplay, offering a seamless fusion of exploration, crafting, and survival elements. Players begin their adventure stranded on a random planet, armed with nothing but a trusty Matter Manipulator and a ship in need of repair. From there, the universe becomes their playground. Each procedurally generated planet teems with unique biomes, flora, fauna, and secrets waiting to be unearthed.

The crafting system in Starbound is nothing short of remarkable. From humble wooden shelters to sprawling starbases, players have the tools to build virtually anything their imagination desires. The depth of customization is staggering, allowing for the creation of intricate structures, vehicles, and weaponry. Whether constructing a cozy cottage or a towering fortress, the only limit is one's creativity.

Combat in Starbound is fluid and engaging, with a diverse array of weapons and enemies to encounter. From laser rifles to broadswords, each weapon type offers a distinct playstyle, ensuring that combat remains fresh and exciting throughout the adventure. Boss battles punctuate the experience, challenging players to utilize their skills and strategic thinking to overcome formidable foes.

Story and Lore:
Beneath the surface of Starbound's vast universe lies a rich tapestry of lore and narrative depth. The game's main questline guides players through a captivating story of ancient civilizations, interstellar conflict, and cosmic mysteries. Alongside the main plot, countless side quests and lore fragments offer tantalizing glimpses into the game's lore, encouraging exploration and discovery.

Art and Sound:
Visually, Starbound is a feast for the eyes, boasting charming pixel art that captures the whimsical nature of its universe. Each biome is beautifully realized, with vibrant colors and intricate details that breathe life into the world. Accompanying the visuals is an enchanting soundtrack that perfectly complements the sense of wonder and adventure. From tranquil ambient melodies to pulse-pounding battle themes, the music of Starbound enhances the immersive experience.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Starbound is a masterclass in sandbox gaming, offering a boundless universe ripe for exploration and creativity. With its captivating gameplay, rich lore, and charming aesthetic, it stands as a shining example of indie game development done right. Whether embarking on epic quests, building sprawling colonies, or simply wandering the stars, Starbound invites players to lose themselves in a universe limited only by their imagination. Embark on your own interstellar odyssey today and discover the wonders that await in the cosmos of Starbound.

Starbound's story is like if Space-Jesus decided to become a historian and went around the galaxy holding the scan button on random plants. It's not fun but is very much forced on you. At least uniquely generated planets are really cool at first, until you realize they have very little actual diversity. Planets each only have a single biome and the two monsters you might find on one of them are just mix-matched versions of the same enemies you've encountered a hundred times already. They may as well just be biomes of a single infinite world, there is no practical difference.

Starbound is a game that doesn't know what it wants to be. It wants to put a heavy focus on having crazy boss fights like Terraria. At the same time, it wants to focus on being an open-world sandbox with infinite exploration and creativity like Minecraft. Meanwhile, it really wants to focus on having an engaging space story with unexpected twists. So how does manage all of this? It shoves a boring and repetitive story line down your throat where you're basically the center of the universe. All of the boss fights are an absolute joke, and 90% of the game's content is locked behind the story.

127 hours.
I found out today that when transferring PC's I had accidentally deleted my main character file in this game. 
Which is a weird way to start a review, but maybe, it's a chance to reflect on that character, a Novakid named Captain Orio, and I'll let that speak for itself...
Significant spoilers ahead:

In my time as Captain Orio, I have...
 - Made my living as a small farmer
 - Crafted an awesome cowboy hat, which I would wear through the rest of the game
 - Explored the most inhospitable planets the galaxy had to offer, just to say I did it
 - Put together a motley crew, of every species imaginable
 - Become the galaxy's Chosen One, finding and reuniting the heavily guarded artifacts of every species
 - Beat up a mean tentacle planet
 - Created a history museum filled with artifacts from my journeys
 - Become a Space Policeman and rid the galaxy of all manner of criminals

This game taught me to beat bosses harder than I ever thought I could. I have seen landscapes and skies more beautiful than I could have imagined from a pixel-art game. My 127 hours as Captain Orio have been filled the joy of discovery, and the satisfaction of perseverance. "I applaud your tenacious moxie in the pursuite of complex goals" - I have this quote from the shipboard AI written above my real-life desk, because it's just stuck with me...
There is no feeling quite like the first time you find yourself gunning through a radioactive alien landscape with Curtis Schweitzer's "Inviolate" setting the pace... Or the first time you watch the aurora borealis break through the clouds in the unfamiliar sky over a remote frozen world...
"I've seen things you people wouldn't believe... Attack ships on fire off the shoulder of Orion... I watched C-beams glitter in the dark near the TannhÃ¤user Gate..."

So long, Captain Orio, and thanks for all the memories. 
Time to put another 127 hours into a new captain.

I've spent over 150 hours on Starbound, and I think it's time to share my thoughts on this true masterpiece. What makes it even more special is that it marks my first-ever online game purchase. I was a little kid finally able to use a credit card for online purchases, and Starbound was the perfect choice.

This game won me over with its captivating story, enjoyable gameplay, and the wonderful music by Curtis Schweitzer. It kept me coming back for more, and I've completed the main story over 5 times. The exploration of these worlds, each with its unique charm, provided a captivating experience.

Curtis Schweitzer's music deserves special mention; it's not just a soundtrack but the perfect background that enhances the excitement and fun in every moment of the game.

Diving into Starbound always brings about a sense of comfort and relaxation. There's something about the game that just makes me feel good, and part of it is undoubtedly the nostalgic vibe it carries. It's like a delightful trip back in time, and who wouldn't want to relive some of those cherished moments?

In its own unique way, Starbound taps into that sentiment, delivering a gaming experience that goes beyond mere entertainment â€“ it has always been a comforting escape for me. It's a rare gem that manages to capture the essence of why I play games in the first place.

A massive thank you is in order, not only to Curtis Schweitzer for the phenomenal music but also to the entire Chucklefish team for creating this immersive universe. Starbound, you're more than just a game; you're my personal time machine, consistently providing that warm and feel-good escape. Thanks, love you all.

The good:
- You can fly a spaceship to different planets, build stuff on them, harvest resources, and discover neat stuff.
- Lots of cool ideas that are implemented reasonably well (minus all the cut beta content)
- It's like Terraria, but with more sci-fi stuff. If that's your bag, it's a decent solo experience.

The bad:
- Dated design that was "abandoned" (finished development) nearly a decade ago. Multiplayer is not stable enough for me.
- Runs on one CPU core for both clients and dedicated servers, meaning performance can be a mixed bag. Doesn't engage the GPU for calculations, and won't ever.
- Better content diversity and progression with mods, but struggles to maintain sync in certain areas when running the most popular mod (Frackin' Universe) on a dedicated server with resources to spareâ€”again, engine limitations are the culprit.

The ugly:
- Will likely never see an engine update to bring it up to speed with modern or continously updated titles
- Troubleshooting bugs is a nightmare with mods because many vanilla bugs still remain, and telling them apart can be tedious or a dead end
- Really no reason to play it over Terraria apart from the space aesthetic since the maps it generates for planets aren't special in any way, just the same jumble of random dungeons and blocks vomited onto the appropriate biomes. In Terraria, you can walk left or right to do the same thing that Starbound requires you to fly a spaceship for.

In short, Starbound was a very ambitious idea that partially delivered on its promise. Unfortunately, after nearly a decade since its "full release," it's far behind the times. Titles like Minecraft and Terraria continue to refine and innovate on everything from performance to content, but Starbound was declared "finished" and left to collect dust.

The game is better with mods, no doubt. Frackin' Universe, among others, add a layer of much-needed depth and incremental progression. But running these mods on a game engine that can only command a single CPU coreâ€”and it only runs on the CPU, using the GPU for nothing but displaying pixelsâ€”is a recipe for frustration.

Starbound is a beloved game to many. Simply rifling through the many Discord servers dedicated to its most popular mods will tell you the lengths people are willing to go to breathe some new life into it. Yet, it's also a deeply and fundamentally flawed game... and it's doomed to stay that way.

Starbound. "Starbound". When I say it out loud I remember my days starting out from a great catastrophe. Falling to a planet, felling my first tree. Furnishing a hole in the ground that I hastily dug to escape the slimes. 
As the days past in game, the hours stretched IRL... Alongside my adventurer friend, we explored the stars, the cute, vibrant universe full of beauty. The characters we met were all nuts, maneater plants, smart axolotl, robots stuck in ages past, energy lifeform cowboys, buccaneer penguins... Every sprite, pixel physics decision allowed us to build a simple and perfect bubble in which to live and explore and discover and love. 
And when we had seen everything there was to see, we downloaded Frackin Universe. And we added 100 mods. And the possibilities became endless. Sadly, as we explored further the matrix space, the game became frayed around the edges. Our perfect bubble was to full, ready to burst from the creations we filled it with. Our base, our castle in the sky, our rabbit hole from Alice's Wonderland... It became too much for the reality of the code. The more we wanted from this game, the less it could take it. The sun rose and set, the winds of change blew over our lives... The dream could not last. It was too much, too beautiful, too heavy. 


Came a moment where we had to accept that this game had taken us as far as it could. And now our great creation, our imagination, our friendship and adventures are forever frozen in time - in a perfect bubble of happiness. 

I am thankful to have known this game above so many others. This game has a soul. This game could be so much more. My wish upon a star: let this game revive, let it be born again, let the community create more mods, let the adventure continue. 

Let us meet again

Good 2D platformer game where you survive and explore space. The ground can be mined and you can build your own settlement and charge people rent to live in it. The alien planets have a lot of character and different threats and resources. You'll need to craft protective gear or pilot a mech that can drill through the ground. Drive your spaceship all over the universe and see what's out there. Build up your character abilities to get familiar metroidvania powerups like folding yourself into a little ball, running fast, dashing, wall jumping and more. Get new mechs and swap out the modules on them to make an explorer mech, miner or fighter. Fly around in space to board a space pirate and fight your way through their ship. Find and explore whole cities of apes, bird people, medieval-minded robots and more.

The game was kind of a mess when it first came out but the developers really got it together and made an amazing game. It's similar to Terraria but better in a lot of ways. The mod support is amazing and you will find endless enjoyment with some of the huge mods like Frackin Universe. The cutesy art style doesn't appeal to me as much but the gameplay more than makes up for it.

Highly recommended!

After almost 500 hours, I'll go ahead and leave my 2 cents here, several years too late.

To me, Starbound is Terraria, but with better combat, better aesthetics, more to explore, and a story to follow.
At least, that's how I'd describe it if I were wanting to paint it in the best possible light.

Truth is, there's merit to all of those statements, but there's also too much holding it back from actually being loved in the same way Terraria is.

I don't really want to leave a (bigger) wall of text getting into the intricacies of what I mean by that, so instead I'll just highlight my biggest 2 issues with the game.

1: Boss Encounters.
As with Terraria, Starbound progression involves pushing through various boss fights. It's more story-locked than progression-locked, but it amounts to the same concept, more or less. Unfortunately, every single one is incredibly underwhelming. There are no actual Difficulty options in Starbound, just settings that change how much Death matters and if Survival Mechanics exist. So what you get is what you're stuck with. Basically, it comes down to the fact that the fights largely don't offer a "dance" to learn. You're not trying and trying again to get the mechanics down to handle the boss appropriately. You just hit it, and if you eat a laser to the face or whatever, you mash a Bandage, repeat until victory. It's all very straightforward and undertuned, which makes the combat I enjoy a lot more than Terraria's mostly irrelevant, because you never have to properly use it to win. You can flail around and be totally fine. Starbound, even with its boss encounters, is notably easier than even Classic Mode in Terraria.

2. Story.
The Story is something added fairly late in Starbound's development. Pretty much the last thing added before launching as 1.0, IIRC. It doesn't NEED to exist, but because it does, I have opinions on it. Namely, it feels like an afterthought, and because of that, I wonder why they bothered at all. It leaves me with nothing but negative opinions, whereas if there were no Story, it'd just be about the exploration and power/boss progression, which would have been fine. The TL;DR is this: BBEG shows up, we talk to Exposition Girl, who has us go and SCAN different objects and then run a related Boss Dungeon... 4 times in a row. Then we collect some MacGuffins to go kill the BBEG - The End. It's as basic as basic can be, and the associated gameplay is roughly 40% "find this randomly generated structure that could be anywhere and just scan everything in it", which is INCREDIBLY un-fun to me. That, and as already mentioned, the bosses are not engaging, and therefore don't add much to the dungeons they reside in.

At the end of the day, I still recommend Starbound. It's a decent game. I honestly do enjoy the moment-to-moment gameplay & combat more than I do in Terraria. I honestly do think it looks significantly better. As a result of that, I also have a lot more interest in building things in Starbound. I'm still more likely to boot up Starbound than I am Terraria. So of course I'm going to recommend it.

But the moments that SHOULD be capstones all fall flat, and a game like this needs to have those moments work, otherwise it makes the whole thing feel a lot more mundane, and that's basically what's happened with Starbound.

Thankfully, there IS a decent modding scene here, and for the most part it's all accessible via the Steam Workshop. There's a few pretty large "expansion" style Addons available, tons of Race addons, tons of weapon addons, some mechanical overhauls, Music, QoL, and comprehensive compilations like Frackin Universe. There's enough good stuff in there to help build around the solid core that Starbound has that it's definitely worth looking into if the Vanilla experience feels "close" but not quite there to you.

The game is incomplete.  I'm playing here with 200+ mods, and it still feels incomplete.  There's interaction missing, vehicles glitch, and combat is radically unbalanced.  And that's WITH 200+ mods.  

If the developers ever come back and finish this game, it'll be amazing, but right now it's not worth your time, and it's almost not worth my sunk cost fallacy.  A shame.  It could have been amazing.


I'd like to give a shout out to the modders though.  There's fixes and additions for everything and it really does expand the experience.  I REALLY can't stress how uncomfortable I am that I paid for this game.  But the the modding community and their output here is nothing short of amazing.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right handâ€”the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bedâ€”the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Awesome game. Cracked it open thinking it'd be a total ripoff of Terraria but boy was I wrong. Sure, the art style is the same but there's a lot more depth to this game. There's a story, you can acquire sidequests. It's a ton of fun.

Honestly, after all the years I've spent playing this game-- sometimes alone, sometimes with friends, It's been worthwhile, though honestly It just doesn't feel interesting anymore. I'd still recommend the game and I highly recommend messing with mods, but it's one of those where you can only do so much before the messy development history comes to mind or the people you've played the game with come and go (as Starbound is a game that is better with friends). 

This is a game that has changed my life far more times, for better and worse, than I could ever count.

Was it worth it? I think so.

Would I relive these experiences again that were all tied around this game? I'm not sure... but sometimes I wonder what could have been of this game. Perhaps in some world this game never had those issues in development that forever tainted how I felt about Starbound. Even then, it was still fun while that enjoyment was strong within me, and I know well that the highs in this game still inspire me to this day...

tl;dr good sale buy, worth it with friends

The base game is extremely whelming (not tried modded at this time) and it wasn't the best or the worst i've ever tried. "better with friends" although sometimes it can be a laggy mess with all the effects going off at once. One thing i did notice is that your character difficulty is persistent in multiplayer, which means if you picked casual and everyone else picked survival, you wont need to eat while all your friends have to carry a kitchen/campfire/microwave to make food to survive which is pretty entertaining if you're on the casual side and an impressive immersive experience i haven't seen in any other game where you're usually pretty much railroaded into the difficulty of however the server settings were made.

i had a decent time but its extremely bland after a while and nothing really differentiates the exploration of a planet other than what type of defensive backpack you have on and maybe some environmental dangers on the surface and maybe some mixing of mini biomes underground; and the hazard of nearly dying if you forget you're on a dangerous planet and accidentally remove your backpack to use the bright one because you forgot you were on a dangerous planet. Since they seem so similar to other safer planets (no UI icon or otherwise constant info that "its dangerous to take your backpack off") until you remove it and get penalized

the combat is mildly interesting with the energy usage for guns/staffs/launchers but shoehorns you into having a switch weapon for melee or using throwables like javelins or bombs since most guns without the higher tier energy bonuses or an energy boosting food will drain you pretty quickly. Staves are a good solution to this since they use metered amounts and you can regen the lost energy quickly but aren't useful in tight spaces where the top of the staff/wand is blocked as it wont trigger the attack and you waste 2 seconds charging for it to fail the cast. The delay before using weapons is also strange, since melee should be able to start swinging instantly but the cooldown of the weapons triggers when you swap to it, so you're standing there awkwardly for a second before you're able to start fighting/defending after a switch, and the delay for swapping to javelins is especially noticeable 

You progress thru tiers pretty quickly so by the time you have a set of lower tier gear you can easily replace it for the next gear tier or even skip a tier and keep linearly progressing until you reach the end, which comes way too quickly imo. Its similar to terraria or minecraft where you COULD get a set of silver armor, or you could just go get plat and go from there but the small amount of choice for higher tier armors is very limited and there's no real side-grade options. The difficulty of the planet factors how much damage you take and do to mobs, so unless you're good at dodging stuff and build fighting anything that can't phase thru walls its easier to  just stick with following the upgrade path so you dont get turned into an oil spot instantly

Its possible to go your entire playthru without ever using a space station as its pretty annoying to set up and by the time you get materials to make one you like, it may be irrelevant and not much use other than a hub to grow stuff at if you're not on casual difficulty unless you did a lot of early game titanium grinding and went to asteroids to mine copper/gold which a first-timer may not know about without combing the wiki for these specifics

I also don't know why the game is so afraid of letting you earn money since you get 1/5 the price of everything you sell and it doesn't get any better than that aside from using the terramart container to sell food, which only increases the value of each part of the dish by a few pixels and isn't worth the time to make the more complicated stuff to sell

it was 100% worth the $7 i gave it since i did get a few hours of entertainment out of it, but that's about it for this until i give the mod a try sometime in the future

This game could be so, so good. So much potential. They could make this a classic, just like Terraria and the others. But it did not happen. I just hope someone will make something similar to this in the future, but not go the same route as these devs did.

TL/DR for anyone who doesn't want to read:

The game is great with mods, but the vanilla game is sorely lacking since it tries to add too much and most of that is half finished. Also unpaid child labor is a thing.

[h1]Main Review[/h1]

To start off, I have about 300 hours invested into this game and enjoyed it a lot. But about 250 of them are from mods like Frackin' Universe which is basically a [b]"Minecraft Tekkit" or "Terarria: Calamity mod"[/b] type expansion mod which adds an astronomical amount of content to the game and expands (and finishes) a lot of the half finished content that is a part of the vanilla game. [b]This review will be mostly for the vanilla game.[/b]

Its pretty enjoyable for the first beginning hours of the game, but it quickly becomes a repetitive "scan the world" fest.

[b]A lot of the content in the vanilla game feels half finished:[/b]

[*]The colony building feels more like a small side thing that gives you a small amount of extra pixels(this games currency) and doesn't really benefit you very much

[*]The radiant quests (randomly generated quests) feel sooo lackluster, and its the only way to recruit more crew members

[*]Space stations seem pretty useless and are extremely expensive to build

[*]The whole story is kinda meh, especially when you have to scan random household objects to progress the bar. This felt very lazy imo and got dull really quick which is why I've only completed the story [b]once[/b] out of the 300 hours I've played this.

I personally wouldn't recommend the vanilla version of this game, it's a game that's packed with a lot of content; the caveat  being that a lot of the "content" that its packed with feels unfinished. If you do decide to get it however, I would highly suggest downloading Frackin' Universe before you even play this game on the steam workshop.

Ah, Starbound... Think of it as you being compared to your brilliant cousin, that is Terraria, but you told your parents that you wanted to be an astrophysicist, not a best-seller fantasy novel writer. The difference being, Terraria fulfilled, or even surpassed, its parents expectations. While you, Starbound, are potentially stunted because you had to do odd jobs here and there, and kind of missed all the things that's required for you to be an aspiring astrophysicist.

Positive things:
â€¢ Starbound's art direction is visually pleasing. Thematically on point, and I have no qualms on the visual department. I like the pixel art, I like the ambiances, I like how they portray space and its inhabitants.
â€¢ Simple narrative to follow, nothing too convoluted. It's much easier to digest or follow compared to its cousin. You're a Protectorate graduate, who just happened to have a sh*t luck. You begin your adventure with basically nothing but your matter manipulator. And you're kind of free to do whatever you want from the get go.
â€¢ The music! Oh my God, the music! Curtis Schweitzer has absolutely made Starbound even grander that it should have been. Without his music, exploring barren planets would be boring as hell. The sound department is also on point!
â€¢ The space is vast, random, and there are like more than thousands of planets to explore, with unique items, inhabitants, dungeons, and quests. This is where, I think, Starbound has the upper hand. The variety satisfies my thirst of exploring. And if you're considering mods, Frackin' Universe is one of the best to enhance your experience.
â€¢ It's a sandbox game, you do whatever you want. You want to be a space-faring adventurer? Fine. You want to settle down on a red planet with cute critters? Fine. You want to be a landlord and collecting payments from NPCs who stay at your accommodations? Suit yourself. You want to explore Glitch Castle to relinquish the crown? Cool. Or you want to go to a speakeasy that's filled with sadistic penguins as regular patrons? Go for it. Or you just want to destroy a planet because you don't like the colour of the dirt? Do it.
â€¢ So many decorative items to [strike]steal[/strike] collect! Use your matter manipulator to mine or copy them. You can also 3D print most of the furniture that you have encountered.
â€¢ You can recruit NPCs as your crew member once you beat and spare them, or complete quests from them. They could help you in battle, as additional firepower or someone who could buff or heal you.
â€¢ The ship customisation! My dream of having my own space ship and designate a room for my crew members to hangout with pinball machine, soda machine, car beds. I could even lease some of my rooms in my space ship to NPCs.
â€¢ The puzzles in dungeons are quite fun, the boss battles are simplistic but also fun too.
â€¢ Similar to Terraria, your friend could drop in and drop out very easy in this game when playing multiplayer.

Negative things:
â€¢ I don't know where to start, but a wasted potential is one of the glaring issues that I found in Starbound. This game could have been Chucklefish's own flagship Terraria-like. The basic stuffs are there, the lore are there, the mechanics are there. The game sorely needs support like how Re-Logic supported Terraria.
â€¢ Some of the side quests feel fetchy, and that is the nature of randomly-generated quests.
â€¢ This game sorely needs more variety.
â€¢ If you have explored the game for more than 40-50 hours, you will feel that you have seen everything the game has to offer.
â€¢ If you're coming from Terraria, this game would feel like a downgrade, not a side-grade.

I have to highlight I loved the game in itself, not being compared to Terraria, but the similarities are there to be compared, and that's natural. I don't really like Terraria that much, I loved the progression, but always wishing Starbound had more care like Terraria is. I hope Chucklefish would revisit this game or make a sequel to it while addressing the issues that made Starbound feel inferior to its competitors.

Do I recommend this game? It depends. Yes, if you haven't played Terraria and looking for a sandbox metroidvania exploration game. No, if you have played Terraria. Also, don't forget to check out Frackin' Universe as soon as you beat the story, as this mod enhances the gameplay and the variety.

Has the most gorgeous pixel art I've ever seen and has so many creative ideas, so it's super sad that the gameplay is so uninteresting and there's not much to do. Imo it should have been more open ended and ditched the boring story quests.

I just realized this game is the OG Starfield.

Clunky and unwieldy combat.
Controlling the character feels bad.
Absolute garbage UI.
Bad performance considering what the game is and how it looks.
Game constantly feels like it's on the brink of falling apart.
Built and hyped on the legacy of a much better game.
Has an unfinished, forever early-access feel to it.
Overpromised and underdelivered.
Wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle.
Obnoxious inventory management.
Filled to the brim with trash items.
Illusion of depth by throwing quantity at the player rather than quality and drip-feeding even the most basic game progression.
Terrible writing.
God-awful quest design.
Endless fetch quests.
Main quests suck, but you NEED to do them to unlock a lot of basic things in the game.
Constant thought of "oh man, I hope this gets better later on...".
Meaningless exploration.
Most planets are extremely flat, empty, ugly, boring, repetitive and completely devoid of interesting landmarks. Not to mention single biomes for the entire planet.
Land on a planet, then walk forward mindlessly for 3 minutes to find the POI (which will most likely be a recycled outpost you've already seen a dozen times before).
Wasted potential.
"That's it?!" moment when you finally complete every single hand-crafted and progress-blocking quests and side quests.
Fundamentally broken.
Extremely defensive fans that mostly refuse to acknowledge the game's shortcomings.
"But mods can fix it!". 
"You just gotta make your own fun out of it!".
"But the ship customization is good!".
"It gets good after X hours! Trust me!".
"Why did you even play it for X hours if you didn't enjoy it?!".
"If you didn't enjoy it, then it's not meant for you!".

To give credit where it is due, it's still more impressive than Starfield by virtue of being both an indie game and a much older title.

And if you do like the game, good for you! Keep enjoying it! For me it is and will always be one of the biggest disappointments I've ever had in gaming.

I should explain my relationship with this game. As a younger kid to early teen (I was nine when this game came out), I wanted it... So I looked and looked, when I hit ten I discovered a supposed "download" for the game. I had no idea Steam existed and so: I downloaded it.

Yeah, my journey with Starbound started by pirating it so. Not the best start. When I grew a little more and discovered Steam, it was probably one of the first few things to go in my cart. I was ecstatic to play it again, and lord did I play it.

The gameplay loop of Starbound is very easy to follow:
[list]
[*] Land your ship on a new planet (after you go through the tutorial quest and the first "main story" dungeon to get your ship running).
[*] Walk all the way to the left or the right in a search for settlements/dungeons OR immediately dig down if you used your ship to check what ores/gems are here for your progression.
[*] Explore and collect resources, no doubt for the next tier of item so that you can boost your stats higher.
[*] Prepare to search for "clues" as to the next civilization; search for clues; complete the next story dungeon.
[*] Move up to the next danger tier of planets.
[/list]

Now, this is well and good. But there's a few flaws with Starbound that really take that same gameplay loop and make it largely unsatisfying. And you may ask, what do I mean?

Well. Every bit of story progression is locked behind you completing some amount of action. You can't progress your armor and workstations without going out to a [generally] more dangerous planet in order to collect new resources. Now, imagine, for just a second, that every step of the story is locked behind around thirty minutes to two hours of just searching planets and doing nothing else of substance: that's where my problem lies.

The story is very slow progressing. You go between huge bursts of the plot via dungeons and then immediately get blocked from more because you haven't scanned the 10th item you need and have to go back to another planet.

Me describing which one was the most annoying below, marked as a spoiler:
[spoiler] The Hylotl one was probably the most annoying. Hylotl rarely occupy the surfaces of planets, meaning you need to go out of your way to an oceanic planet and spend however long scouring the darkness until you happen upon one of their colonies. And a genuine tip I have for you is to put a teleporter flag inside one of those structures in case you want to come back in case you want to double check and make sure you didn't miss anything later. [/spoiler]

I should give my [most likely non] controversial opinion on this game:
The game is fun for a little while, but opening that workshop page is probably the largest dopamine hit my brain can receive. I would start the game vanilla, that is my full recommendation. But good lord, add some cosmetics I implore you.

I normally don't play the game anymore without RPG Growth, Frackin' Universe, and Frackin' Races. They add so much nuance and make your character choice actually matter. It lets you develop a playstyle and most of the classes dictate how you approach combat: from a distance or jumping towards your foe and screaming.

Just, tldr:
Game is good, progression is slow and tedious. Would 100% recommend lightly or heavily modding the game.
Like Terraria, except it's in space and more focused on building than combat. The only major criticism I have of this game is the low replay value without mods.

Just to preface this - this game is only receiving a 'recommended' from me due to the solid foundation it provides to a healthy modding scene. If you're not planning to use Workshop for this game, then treat this as a 'Not Recommended', sadly.

I want to love this game, I really do. But sadly, missed opportunity and poor design choices hinders this game from truly succeeding. Having such a rigid story in a space exploration game simply gets in the way of exploring. There is nothing to promote exploring, except for the possibility of a few unique weapons (emphasis on few). Once you own those, there is really no reason to explore most planets, as they are pretty much the same experiences with slight asset swaps.

On the other hand, there's not really much reason to stay on a planet either. You have the NPC housing system, which is a good foundation, but once again very barebones, and arguably out of place in a game focused around planet hopping. Building is good, wiring is decent and the paint system is cool.

Despite all this, however, there is heart in the game. Heart which is exposed and multiplied by the modding scene. Playing a modded session of Starbound in a group is a surprisingly fun experience.

6/10

The game is good in singleplayer, but multiplayer netcode is essentially unplayable due to lag and desync issues.

The Linux port also disables your monitor if you are playing in X11 (Luckily this is "fixed" by using wayland).

Terraria is simply a better game.

This is my favorite casual game. I play on Casual mode, and just enjoy collecting armor sets, upgrading my ship and going mining. A few of the systems are not my favorite, like the clues system and fossils, but I really enjoy how incredibly customizeable the entire experience is. Your ship, your character, your crew, your armor and your colony can all be customized to your tastes. The campaign is simple, fairly easy with  the right equipment, and doesn't take to much pains to complete. It can get boring if you play it too much too quickly, though.

I'm very conflicted on this game. It's fun to build, the planets and generated structures are fun to explore the first time you encounter them I guess, but this game has a variety of major problems.

Planets are all one biome, why? I understand this is probably to facilitate some kind of "progression" (which this game also sucks at) but it just makes for boring exploration after a while. The occasional interesting microbiome does not make up for this. Several planet types are also worthless, either being impossible to explore or very similar to other types.

The game relies too heavily on procedural generation in order to simulate the feeling of a vast universe. Most enemies you will encounter are incoherent and unmemorable, procedural weapons have boring effects.

I could keep going but it's futile as despite all of the game's problems, I do enjoy playing it [i]with mods[/i]. This game was built from the ground up to be modded and that's easily its biggest strength. Much like Minecraft, you can shape this game into something far more enjoyable for you.

I would advise you ignore anyone who compares this game to Terraria however. They are very different games, and you are probably not likely to enjoy this game if you're a big fan of Terraria.

So far, after the hell-hole of a development this game went through I would say that it is now worth it. Especially if you can get it on sale! The sheer amount of things you can do in Starbound is pretty cool, but that leaves it very surface level. 

I noticed a lot of the time that people compare it to Terraria and though the games feel similar, Starbound is just as quirky and fun (in my opinion) in its own unique way. While Terraria has a really fun combat mechanic and its features are more fleshed out, Starbound offers that generic "Jack of all Trades" vibe. 
So far I have had so much fun playing both games but single player and multiplayer. Starbound, given its narrative is a bit more linear and offers a lot of direct story telling that gives you a chance to explore the vast galaxy and accomplish many things such as building a colony, decorating your spaceship, and saving the galaxy. 

The main downside that is faced when playing is that it attempts to be that Jack of All Trades which leads to it coming off as a shallow system. Nothing is too in depth, Nothing is too bare-bones. There is genuine love crafted into this game and with the Modding Community being pretty good, there is a lot of playability if you are looking for a sandbox styled game with relative freedom to build almost anything you want. 

Overall, I have enjoyed this game for a while now and surprisingly given my mobile lifestyle, really appreciate that this game is playable on a macbook. For something that can be played in a slower paced setting it is quite fun as long as you don't get overwhelmed with the onslaught of choices that a player is given shortly after the 1-2 hour long tutorial with all the various features given.

But the people who made this game didn't understand WHY Terraria was good and didn't have any ideas or a plan going forward to make this game good. They just made something "like" Terraria without enough sense to understand the thing they were trying to copy. So this game ends up being a strange abortion of the concept.

I've also seen barely any worthwhile mods for this game, which tells you something when even modders can't make the game enjoyable. Most of the mods I've seen are simply races/species and of course sex mods. Nothing legitimately game changing or significant.

Starbound isn't just a game; it's a universe I've willingly lost myself in for over 500 hours, and I can't help but wax poetic about this interstellar gem. If you're looking for a sandbox adventure that seamlessly blends exploration, creativity, and an endless supply of quirky charm, then look no further than Starbound.

From the moment you beam down onto your first procedurally generated planet, the sense of possibility in Starbound is intoxicating. The universe is your oyster and I can attest that the depth of exploration is unparalleled. Each planet is a canvas waiting to be painted with your footprints, and the diversity of biomes and creatures keeps every discovery feeling fresh, even after hundreds of hours.

One of Starbound's standout features is its crafting system. It's a virtual playground where your imagination is the limit. I've spent countless hours designing elaborate structures, creating intricate furniture, and fashioning my own armada of starships. The game encourages creativity in a way that feels both liberating and rewarding, and my 500+ hours are a testament to the endless possibilities it offers.

The game's narrative is woven into the fabric of exploration. As I've traversed the cosmos, I've encountered mysterious ancient races, delved into forgotten dungeons, and unearthed the secrets of the universe. The overarching storyline adds a layer of depth to the seemingly boundless freedom, creating a perfect balance between guided adventure and player-driven exploration.

Starbound's pixel art style has an undeniable charm, and the soundtrack is a cosmic symphony that accompanies every jump to a new star system. The soothing melodies and upbeat tunes have become the soundtrack to my space faring escapades, enhancing the immersive experience.

Multiplayer is where Starbound truly shines. Whether embarking on daring missions together, constructing massive collaborative bases, or engaging in friendly (or not-so-friendly) PvP, the camaraderie of shared exploration elevates the game to new heights. My time with Starbound includes countless memories of laughter, triumphs, and the occasional spaceship race across the galaxy with friends.

In conclusion, Starbound is a masterpiece that has captivated my heart and imagination. It's a testament to the game's enduring appeal that each session feels like a new chapter in my cosmic saga. Whether you're a solo explorer or seeking a universe to share with friends, Starbound beckons you to dive into a vast and enchanting galaxy. Suit up, fellow travellers, and prepare for a journey that transcends gamingâ€”it's a celestial odyssey that keeps calling me back for more.

[b]Introduction:[/b] Oh my, am I excited and sad about this review. Hello once again to the people who have been reading my reviews ever since 2020 (which is when I started doing reviews so many reviews)! I'm so utterly sorry to announce that this will be the final game review, I will ever make. it has been a long journey up until this point but I have been holding this game for a long time now, it is finally time to talk about a game that I hold so much love towards, way back in 2016 when I first played it...Starbound! Starbound is an open world sandbox game that was developed and published by Chucklefish in July 22, 2016. The reception was really positive with over 80,000+ reviews, which is ridiculous. Well, this is it, ladies and gentlemen, I present you, Starbound!

[b]Story:[/b] It has a lot of depth in it, you got a lot of lore in this game that it's literally too much to go over but I'll cut it short. So, the story goes like this, upon waking up, you walk to the right to find someone holding a speech, holding the main tool you use, the Matter Manipulator, when everything seems normal at first, a tentacle creature, attacks the entire place and everybody else, so you make a run for it, all the way until you reach the spaceship, as soon as you escape, you find yourself in space, alone. Upon finding a teleporter later on, in a planet that you are near. You arrive at the outpost, a place full of people, creatures, and penguins. You then find Ester Bright, who is the most important npc in the game, as you will get lore and missions to do, one must fight a bunch of bosses to prove their worthy of obtaining all of the six artifacts, as each one represents Avian, Glitch, Human, Floran, Apex, and Hylotl. After gathering all of the artifacts, we finally reach the final area of the game, where you face the creature who as been causing havoc, The Ruin. Once defeated, the universe is finally safe from harm. Holy crap, that is a lot of lore and like I said, there's more to this game, but I don't want to take up all of this review with some lore. Overall, a pretty solid story, it's not mind-blowing or some of the best stories you can find in any game but what's here, is good enough.

[b]Graphics:[/b] Ok, ok, ok, wow, this game looks downright stunning. From the title screen to the environments, It is such a pleasure to adore every single environment and detail present here, I'm blown away for how the visuals look in Starbound, this is a 2016 game, how does this game look better than any below average game I reviewed? Starbound still to this day, looks beautiful. Granted the themes are generic and nothing special but they some how make them feel unique from each other, for one, the looks give the world a different feel to it and the weather and effects it has on your character makes the themes feel not as uninspired as any generic games, you know the ones (New Super Mario Bros. Wii).

[b]Music:[/b] I have no words, this is a beautiful soundtrack. It's very calm, soothing, and pleasant on the ears. I love the soundtrack, it is my favorite.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] The gameplay of Starbound is very similar to Terraria, I know Terraria wasn't my kinda of game to play anymore but does that imply to Starbound? Not at all! Even though it's still grindy and time consuming, I find the music to help me keep on going and it doesn't feel that bad, i'd say, it's even more fun to explore in Starbound. Anyways, besides being similar to Terraria, Starbound's gameplay is really good, you explore in different worlds, fighting enemies, getting loot, and finding upgrades to your tools or ship. Your main goal is to complete a bunch of missions from npcs and fight bosses until you get the final artifact, which will lead into the final boss of the game, The Ruin. It's an interesting way of progress, you can even fight optional bosses that also net you more stuff! You have literally everything here, building, fighting, missions, the list goes on and on. I enjoy the game personally, and the fact that the workshop support can make the game a completely different experience is still fun and better since you can improve minor aspects like the crafting which normally takes a little bit of time, now, you can craft an item instantly. There is a lot of fun to be had here with both the main game and workshop support.

[b]Price:[/b] Go ahead, buy it on the retail price or on a sale if you are lucky!

[b]Verdict:[/b] Overall, Starbound has been quite a pleasant time for me! The Story is incredibly deep and solid! The graphics are amazing and still look solid to this day, despite the animation. The music is very beautiful and soul touching. The gameplay while it is repetitive is fairly fun, even with friends and the workshop support makes it all the better!

[b]Rating:[/b] 8/10

[b]The end:[/b] Hello...I never write this section in any review, but this one review is very special to me. I want to thank you and the others who have been reading my reviews, from the past to this review. It really means a lot to me, all of the time and effort really went into the ones that I put the most work into. My favorite year of doing steam reviews was 2022 along with 2023, I had the most fun making all of these reviews. I wish you and everybody else very well in life! As I have said in my introduction section, this is the final review I'll ever do. I really enjoyed my time with my reviews, granted some of them had no effort put into them but here's what I've been doing in 2023, I went back and fixed every. Signal, Review I did, so it's all updated with formatting and more detail in them. Well...this is goodbye then, I hope you enjoyed the long journey from the start, all the way to the end of my reviews, thank you for reading this review and if you have read any or all my reviews (I'd be surprised if you did), I deeply thank you in my heart, for your time. Goodbye, it was fun while it lasted...the end.

I am a 45 -year -old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father raising my son, who is now 14 years old. My son won this game from his uncle, so we installed him on his computer and he started playing. Until the end of the week he had 24 hours in this game. This was horrible for me, because it was hard to find ways to spend time with my son, because he is always with friends or just watching Youtube. So I decided to do a Steam account and get this game to see if I could play beside him. I bought the game, chose my skin and world and started playing, but I was stuck in what you should do. I asked my son for help and he organized a game for me to participate. I loved it, because it was the best time I spent with my son since my wife died. Since then, this game has approached me and my son again and now we spend time together away from home as well. This game reminded me that there is fun in everything, and I brought many happy memories to me and my son.
The only thing keeping it alive is mods, but even with mods it still feels boring.

[h1] Starbound: A Galaxy of Cuteness [/h1]

Starbound is like a boundless candy shop for the eyes and the imagination. With each planet, it's like opening a new wrapper, revealing a surprise of vibrant colors, quirky creatures, and hidden secrets. I've spent hours exploring, building, and crafting, and I can't wait to see what more treats this cosmic candy store has in store for me.

Hot Take: Starbound is so cute, it might just make you squeal with delight!

Incredibly good game. I have never played the official release but this game with Frackin Universe and some other mods is amazing. Long complicated tech trees and choices, exploration, rewards creativity and ingenuity, upgrades that constantly feel impactful, unique enemies, tight controls. Being procedurally generated you expect to see the same assets reused over and over again but you explore alien planets and it feels alien from new environmental effects to blocks to mobs with unique attacks. It's just incredible how well they've balanced this with the amount of content that's here. One of the better games I've played in years, highly recommend finding a mod list that includes Frackin Universe and jumping in.

This is a recommendation if you're into mods. The vanilla experience is not *bad*, but not nearly as fun. Think of this game as kind of a "blank slate" upon which you can add all the crazy stuff you want, like Minecraft before it.

I find it really cool how this game allows you to explore a bunch of different star systems, each with their own planets, with several different planet types, random events to encounter, settlements and ruins in some planets, friendly and not-so-friendly wildlife, and busy undergroud sections full of stuff. The planets here are among the best procedurally generated worlds out there. I also like how there's some actual lore, but it's ever so slightly tongue-in-cheek in some aspects, giving the game's story sort of a Hitchhiker's Guide vibe.

I also appreciate the non-random dungeons which usually contain interesting little puzzles and platforming sections, as well as unique boss fights. Not all boss fights are great, but there are some standouts here and there. Overall, visiting dungeons in between mining and crafting is a fun pastime.

The combat is also pretty fun, combining action RPG elements with 2D twin-stick action-platforming quite well. You can't succeed on skill alone, but unless you're extremely overpowered, you also can't succeed on stats alone, so you will have to use both. I particularly enjoy just jumping arcs over enemies when they try to shoot me with guns, making them miss most shots, and then dishing out some attacks of my own in the brief period before they take out their melee weapon.

The crafting side of things is one aspect in which I think the need for mods is evident. Crafting in the base game is rather simplistic, not providing you with many possibilities in the way of automation and contraption building.

I've done basically my entire playthrough so far with the FU expansion, which I hear adds a bunch of stuff to the game, and I think it's a good choice. Be warned, though, that the whole research mechanic can be a bit annoying at times.

Great artstyle, interesting mechanics, enjoyable exploration, but the story quests can feel slow and boring at times. Pretty enjoyable throughout the first playthrough or two if you're patient and take your time. There isn't too much to do after the main game except for building and exploring. However, there's a reason I have so many hours on this game, and it's surprisingly not because I like watching paint dry. People who say this game is boring most likely haven't modded it. This is where the game goes from "it's okay, but it feels like it's missing something" to "driving the AE86 from Initial D through the defenses of an arctic military facility to rescue hostages while eurobeat is blasting through the speakers". [b]If you're like me and love Starbound's artstyle, controls, and exploration but dislike the tediously long and repetitive story quests and find the gameplay loop boring, 100% mod it.[/b] Starbound has a ton of easy-to-manage mods on the Steam workshop (just subscribe/unsubscribe to the mods you want), many of which make the gameplay much more enjoyable and give you much more to do. Mods like Frackin Universe also add much more to do later in the game after the main story is complete, though it's important to note that Frackin in particular drastically changes the game and makes some things more tedious, but adds MUCH more content to the game (planets, dungeons, weapons/armor, quests, races/settlements, and some great soundtrack to name a few things). Basically, mods not only add more content and customization to the game, but also serve as the missing pieces to the puzzle that is Starbound feeling like a complete game, and to me that's more than enough to make this game a blast, especially with friends (note that locating people who actually still play this game is like finding Waldo in New York City).

TL;DR: Beautiful artstyle and fun exploration, but somewhat repetitive gameplay loop. Okay game overall on its own; great game with mods, not difficult to mod at all. Modding fixes most of the problems that make certain parts of the game feel boring and incomplete, and makes it MUCH more enjoyable. The modded Starbound experience is worth it.

I wanted to try a crafting / exploration game, as I'm fairly new to the genre, and damn this one has one of the worst onboarding and UI I've ever seen. 
Crafting : So many clicks for so many simple actions ! You need to equip each type of wood / brick before building, instead of using the tool. Why not have two modes on the tool ? And why can't I pin a recipe ?
Exploration : even this is not great : basic indications on what and where, and little you have is buried under bad UI. You need to dig all the time to carve out a path, or be able to climb. You get on a planet supposedly safe and early level ? every animal is agressive and does 3 times your damage, even after crafting a few swords. You die ? there's no other checkpoint than where you spawn from your ship. You go the other way ? you get one shot by ninja snipers out of nowhere. And good luck remembering on which planet you received this random fetch quest.
I've added mods, I've read the wiki, I was prepared to work, but this is just so clunky all around, this is not fun for me.

I got this game ages ago, and I still come back to it regularly. I love decorating my ship. I love finding a village on a planet and running around doing quests in hopes of recruiting someone to my crew (the florans are my favorite). Every time I start a new character I remember why I enjoy this game so much.

The core gameplay loop is simple: explore your planet, mine, upgrade your gear, move to a more dangerous star, repeat. Despite it's simplicity, it never feels pointless. There's always something to work towards, whether that be making armor or upgrading your EPP, or the late game tasks, like enhancing your mech or building a space station (although that's definitely [i]late[/i] game with how expensive it is).

The NPC interactions are also simple, relegated to one line of dialogue per person. They can give quests, which reward you with items, and the potential for a new recruit. Quests have decent variety, ranging from passing notes to other villagers to baking bread. The only time I dislike the NPC interactions is when I have to run back and forth halfway across the planet to do a trade or something.

If the vanilla game gets old, the modding scene is well established. Install a few of the larger mods, and you might as well have a whole new game! I highly recommend thoroughly exploring the workshop, and/or looking online for mod lists.

TL:DR The base game is a lot of fun, and if you want more spice the mods for Starbound are incredible.

I see a lot of people say "starbound is space terraria" and I will stop you there. While yes, they share qualities (like being 2d, having pixel graphics, etc), they both put stress on different things. starbound is more catered to adventuring, because there's an infinite star system at your fingertips. meanwhile, terraria's world is finite. I'm not trying to diss either, I love these games to death, but they're fundamentally different.

I would more recommend starbound to a minecraft fan then to a terraria fan. all three share aspects, but minecraft and starbound both focus on exploring the infinite world around you, while terraria is more focused on being the most powerful you can and slaying all the bosses.

It's a survival building game, but the twist is it's wrapped around a grandiose space opera plot. The best thing about telling a story in a game like this is you have a clear sense of direction, so you never feel lost or without purpose. But you also have freedom to do whatever you want whenever you want, and once the story ends you can continue to just play the sandbox universe. So really, it's the best of both worlds.

The lore of the game is really fun and creative, as you go you learn about the various races and cultures of outer space. You also have hub areas to go to and action heavy missions that feel like normal video game levels. This is like playing modded Minecraft with all of the best dungeon mods at once, or spore galactic adventures. You have a ship to customize and can colonize any of the infinitely generating worlds. And on top of that, there are tons of mods to spice up later runs. This is just an objectively good game and I'd recommend this to just about anyone, really.

Where would I start with this one...

Finished the story as a co-op with a friend and had fun with it BUT since then, I couldn't really get into it. I really wanna genuinely like it but this game is making it very difficult.

I enjoy the different aproach and a twist it has compared to Terraria and it's one of the things that's making this game great but at the same time, it feels like devs either didn't really care enough or they were forced to ship the game much earlier because while the huge potential there, it's just not it...

The story is kinda silly and the gameplay loop tied to the story becomes quickly boring (especially if you play solo), the pace is super slow and exploring, while fun, can become more of a chore than something you look forward to. The enemies and bosses feel clunky at times and the pace of fighting is also a little bit off.

I'd recommend this game mainly because it CAN be fun experience for the right people. But for most of the players, especially those coming from Terraria, be prepared to be frustrated and bored regularly.

It also doesn't help that devs pretty much abandoned the game so no content updates, no bug fixes, no QoL or performance improvement, nothing... now the game is surviving only in the hands of modders and that's just not enough in my opinion. It's a shame and it's sad because with proper care, this could easily be the "legendary status game" sitting hand-to-hand with Terraria.

Recruit Crew mates, or Penguins! The choice is yours to start life on a new planet, Or to track down the Unknown Organism that destroyed your home and uphold The Protectorate Code to Provide settlement, guidance, education, and Safety Across the universe.

Heh, I own this game twice and I still think both copies are pretty bad (the other account has a couple hundred hours).
This game stinks, bad, and it's twice as painful if you were involved in watching it develop, watching in horror as Chucklefish slowly abandoned the game, released a few pitiful updates and a content update that nobody cared about, then abandoned it completely to go be a full-time publisher for some unknown reason.

The game's glitchy, unbalanced, and most of it is a slog, especially the pitiful (gutted) story.
Even the infamous issues are still unfixed due to the devs outright abandoning it, like the final boss gate dropping even the gamer-est of gamer PCs to 5 FPS when mousing over it because the highlight effect the game does applies to the gate and all its particles like some cronenberg nightmare of coding.
I hate that they gutted the plot out, I hate that the game unceremoniously destroys Earth (plus 99.999% of humanity, who were all sitting on Earth without spaceships because ???) for basically no reason other than "uh-oh, Earth gone" for all of like 3 minutes of the game, I hate that the entire story involves a tedious slog scanning hundreds of random knickknacks across the galaxy in the hopes RNGesus blesses you with the right kind of lantern that'll somehow unlock the knowledge of where a tribe of carnivorous plants are hunting a giant bug monster.
Weapon variety sucks for the first half of the game.
Mechs are barely implemented.
Novakids are slapped in at the last second so Chucklefish doesn't get sued by the KS backers who paid for their inclusion.
There's an entire civilization mechanic where you can run a whole town full of people with different careers and such, but it's just to earn some pocket change.
There's an entire Terraria-tier building mechanic so you can build out a huge base, but... well, your ship holds all you need, so there's no reason to build ON a planet unless you need tons of plants because ??? IDK.
Literally the only thing in the game with any effort put into it is the first few story dungeons. The last two story dungeons are, no joke, "go left and fight a ton of cookiecutter enemies for a few minutes, then fight a boss" and "dig down for a few minutes and fight the final boss."

The game would be a great baseline for a remake or a reboot, add in another race, fix the plot, blow up Space-U.N. instead of Earth for the 269034742309087th time, finish all the story dungeons, write the engine not to have all this lag, I don't know.

Anyway, yes, the game has a huge modding community, and yes, you can "fix" the game and most of its issues, or just replace everything to make it a whole new game, but it's kind of that whole "Skyrim" thing where the base game isn't worth your money so I suggest waiting for a deep sale and buying it just to mod it, since the devs should NOT be rewarded for being lazy and relying on modders to fix their issues. There should've been at least one final bugfix to tie everything off nicely, but it never came.

At over 200 hours, I've gotten so much fun out of this over the years.

It's great fun. Generally understood as similar to Terraria, but different with its own space flavour. It always gets compared to Terraria which is probably unfortunate because it really is its own game.

Recent updates have made combat, missions, and weapons way more fun. Guns, staves/magic, thrown items, bombs .... it's all here. It's amazing. I absolutely love building comfortable abodes, grand floating palaces, and emergency bunkers. Make your room full of emergency storage options, and dig a secret hole down to your command lair where all your computer systems are stored. It lets you be creative.

However, over the years it became more strict in how you play the game and added story missions you have to do. It became less of a sandbox game (like Terraria) and more of a story driven game. I don't like the change and it gatekeeps some gear and items behind story. I wanted a sandbox game but they took it away.
I like Starbound :)
