Ok let me preface this by saying ALL my hours on this game were after the 1.0 update. I only learned of this game history after I was 300h in.

If you are interested in learning it, I'd recommend watching the video by a youtuber called "The Good Trash", but if you want a quick recap, here it is:
The game was radically diferent before release. It was far more sandbox-driven, the story didn't really have a grasp on gameplay, and there was a TON more content. We're talking several cut bosses, biomes and entire features like the randomly generated monsters were a lot more developped. Unfortunately, the game had no developpement throughline. If a dev thought of a feature, it was gonna be added regardless of how well it would fits. 
Speaking of the devs, they were abused. Most basically came out of university and were hired as intern. This meant that they were paid little to none for their effort. Any that said anything were berated by the higher-ups, or straight up quit. This meant that most of the game's code was a buggy, unoptimized mess of spaghetti coding.
The 1.0 update tried to remedy this by essentially butchering the game into what it is now, which angered the community even more than it was already by the way the devs were treated.

Now, for my actual review.
The game's arstyle is gorgeous, the music (even if it gets repetive quickly) is top notch. 
Gameplay wise,  mining and general exploration feels great. 
Building is perhaps the best, there's so many diferent furnitures, blocks and decorations you can choose from for your base.
Fighting however... hoo boy. It is HORRIBLE. You can choose between ranged, melee and (later on) magic weaponry. You can craft some in each class, but if you want a worthwile weapon, you'll have to use one that is RANDOMLY GENERATED. Sure, there's unique weapons that alwasys have fixed stat (based on the planet you're on), but they are very rare and most aren't even worth it.
You're honestly better off using nothing but fast firing guns with some knockback, like a shotgun or something. Most dangerous enemies you'll be fighting are either flying, fast-moving, or just ranged guy that constantly run away.
Boss fights aren't much better either. The game WILL force you to fight these guys if you want to progress the story, and aside from like, the bird one, most devolve into a mess, be it by constantly spawning minions, having bad hitboxes (the 2nd to last final boss specifically), or because they have attacks that they do off-screen even if fully zoomed out.

Now, progression and story wise. This game's progression works in tiers. Every planet has a tier, going from 1 to 8. Higher tiered planets appear around specific stars, meaning you'll have use your spaceship to get over there. However, the big bad of the game broke your ship (and destroyed Earth but that's irelevant), so you'll have to at least take part in the story until the first boss to get the chance to progress.
After that? The story basically doesn't matter. Seriously you can just play the game without caring for it. Which is honestly a blessing in disguise, since it always the same formula of "Please go scan specific objects from these guys" to "Go defeat these guys' boss please". Repeat for every race except the umans and the Space cowboys.
It is so disappointing. Each race has a trope-infused but well crafted lore to it, so having all their quest being just fetch quest feels lazy.

And finally, we're gonna talk about performance. It is inconsistent at best, and its the game's messy code fault. Seriously this game is not optimized well. It can crash itself at complete random. Its rare but still. There's also a general problem with characters going to fast. If you fall from a great height, there's a chance the game will have trouble loading the terrain arround you. There's also time were the game just won't load a chunk at all. Or others were it lags as if you were having latency issues. In a single player game. Offline.
Oh and one final thing. The lower your FPS are, THE WORSE THOSE ISUES GET. No joke, if you limit your FPS to be under 60, these issues will pop up a ton more. It's not tied to your computer's performance, its the game itself tying a lot of the code to how high your FPS are.

I just can't recommend this game. I love this game but it is the definition of "wasted potential". If you're still interested in buying it, I can only recommend you mod it to hell and back
You'll see a lot of people using a mod called Frackin' universe. It's essetnially its own game, and is about as omnipresent as the Calamity mod is in the Terraria community. 
I personally don't recommend it, since it changes so much about the game that there's mods to mod a mod. Personnal recommendations are the Shellguard expansion, the Starforge, Anom's Outpost overhaul and Project Redemption.

The no-mans sky of terraria pre-deshittfication, that with even worse performance, even on the highest end computers because from what I've heard the game is limited to running on 1 core despite having its lighting engine running separate or some shit (I'm not good with computers, just relaying some stuff I've heard about this games performance). Used to like this game and have high hopes, but well alot of the beta of this game was thrown out and the remaining bones are what this game is built off of.

Game company tried to bumrush people, tryna pull the unpaid intern shit so, generally scummy behaviour

Also fair warning, this game apparently has a memory leak on your ship, essentially the longer you stay on your ship, the laggier it gets and at a certain point theres some safety feature where it just resets your entire ship to fucken nothing. So RIP custom ship mods

Anyways, into the actual game itself well first off, the only good thing about this game is building, so if you're into that, you can get this
Thats about all the praise it gets

- One of the main selling points is random generation for "infinite" playtime. Well thats half right, its infinite slop, where theres generic random monster parts thrown together abomination that does nothing but jump and bump into you 1 through 10000. The randomly generated loot varies from the worst shit you can possibly find, to the most broken ass garbage you can possibly find. There is no connection to anything, anywhere you're basically a ghost floating through shallow soup, nothing matters, nothing happens. They also removed alot of the interesting dungeons the beta has, from underground bases, to sky towers and that weird crystal low gravity dungeon. They also removed crystal planets entirely along with tentacle dirt planets

- Another selling point is the "different races", well they're COSMETIC, they follow the EXACT SAME PROGRESSION PATH, EXACT SAME WEAPONS AND GEAR, NO DIFFERENCE EXCEPT ARMOR SKINS. They REMOVED the racial weapons and gear, so instead of maybe glitch/avian type weapons with unique attributes and appearance, you craft generic steel sword, generic titanium gun, etc.

- Story wise, its shallow kids stuff thats very boring. The story doesn't progress until you do the shitty scan missions, there are no stakes, this giant ass tentacle planet goes nowhere and has no 0 presence in the universe. You're forced into being the good guy and defeat said giant ass tentacle planet thing. Theres also the bounty hunting stuff which forces you to do the most tedious ass missions, with you essentially falling for fake glasses and nose trick (thats legitimately part of the bounty missions) and then they force you to continue running around like a headless chicken. The background lore on the species is paper thin, its the betas story but stripped down for toddlers to understand. Npcs have 1 box of dialogue and thats it, the quests are some goofy goober fetch quests that don't really reward or do anything. Crew members are stupid as hell and just as shallow. There are "lore" books, but they don't contribute jack shit

- The progression is terrible and horrendously boring. Go to planet, mine a few minerals and then farm some fucken planets for the cloth and then make the gear and backpack or "Environmental Protection Pack". You basically need these to go to the next higher tier of planet, which means no use in unique back items. The EPPs are basically progression gate locks, nothing more, they add nothing except a requirement to go to the next tier of planet, because if you land on them without the high enough tier EPP, you just get this environmental condition that saps percentage health or does some other buttfucking damage to you. So the "variety" of planets is really just a biome progression lock, like a downgrade from exploration in Terraria. Speaking of biomes, there are "mini biomes" that don't give anything. They straight up don't give anything except cosmetics at best, they do nothing, they have nothing, they just look nice.

- The difficulty of this game is hilariously bad, theres only two ways to really die
A. You fall to your death from some random cliff or rock breakage on a planet with high gravity because you were falling asleep to all classical, wimp ass music
B. You fall into lava because the music was putting you to sleep
Thats it lol, you can either mass bandage and instantly heal your hp in any other scenario, like as if terraria removed health potion cooldowns

Or, theres this funny thing about shields where they can stun npcs by slightly bumping into them. Do it just right and you can do it to monsters to, where you bump them which stuns them briefly and then you can keep walking into them until you shove em up against a all and they all die from being stunlocked by bad game design.

- If it wasn't clear from me earlier, the music in this game is ill fitting to put it lightly. Its the most mushy peas classical music that puts you to sleep. Genuinely, I was snoozing a couple hours in of nonstop hope and love type sounding music. They REMOVED COMBAT MUSIC from the beta, aka instead of music changing to combat music, it just remains sappy ass classical music. You could be burning a village down and it would still play that awfully fitting music. I thought this was A SPACE EXPLORATION GAME, whats with this sleep inducing music

- While everyone says modding can "fix" things, its less of patching up the gaping holes, more of attaching arms and other limbs onto said holes. Frackin universe, the big fix, does add alot more to do on each planet type, more monsters and so on, but introduces its own huge glop of issues. Well the EPPs I mentioned earlier are less generalized, the final tier is the "cold protection one" except it has all the previous ones installed. Frack universe removes the other previous environmental immunities so instead of just equipping one, you have to switch between 15 of them. Frackin universe also has alot of artificial progression gates, because the mod creator was upset about some people mcspeedrunning through the game and complaining about lack of content. Theres now this "research tree", which is essentially a progression lock that incentives you to do insufferable amounts of wandering through the empty randomly generated planets and digging dirt.

Frackin universe also adds infinite amounts of inventory and space clutter, dungeons that are mostly bland to okay, with maybe 2 good missions with actual custom bosses. The planets range from some good ones, like the cybsphere to okay, to kind of annoying, and pretty much a checklist if you have enough of the environmental resistance to its atmosphere.

I'll probably add more of the problems this game and its mods have to this review at another time, I've only covered a good chunk of them, but the point is This game is only good for its building, get terraria or any other game instead if you're looking for progression, a challenge, anything really

This game and Terraria defined my childhood. Both of them will hold a special place in my heart but this game will always be the flower that never fully bloomed. The game's definitely worth 15 dollars vanilla but mods are it's saving grace. The modded experience is just unmatched and I'd go as far to say modded Starbound could be better than modded Terraria. If this game had more committed devs who didn't drop it after 'full release' and tried a little bit less hard to compete with Terraria it definitely could have been at that level. Alas, it'll always be the "what if" of this genre. but for me personally, 10/10.

Let's see.

Graphics - It's a 2D pixel game, so it's not gonna need a 4090 to run.
Sound - Got a pretty good soundtrack, good to listen in game or if you buy the soundtrack for a dollar (only DLC of the game btw) you've got some bops to listen too.
Story - Only real bad part. For a sandbox game trying to be a space Terraria, the story drags on. It's a good way to get the basic survival things down, but the forced story will drive you bonkers.
Modding Ability - Stellar. The game is clearly a sandbox when it comes to mods. From QOL mods that don't change much, to whole content and overhaul mods like Frackin Universe, you'll find something cool here.
Multiplayer - Meh. There's no server browser, and featured servers are not a thing in SB. However, the community is great at making some great servers, both vanilla and modded.

Overall, it's a great game if you like sandbox experiences. and for 15 dollars, it could be worse.

Starfield:
- no aliens (starborn are just humans with superpowers)
- like 1700 worlds
- 99% barren rocks and moons, roughly 15-30% of them are inaccessible due to being gas giants or stars.  The remaining planets are all story-specific locations or generic forests with one or two earth-like ones that are also content-barren and not worth exploring 
- boring main story
- space travel is literally a bunch of loading screens taped together 
- building sucks
- procedurally generated quests
- the same 4-5 dungeons over and over
- scanning shit for no reason 
- like 15 guns
- single piece armor system with a second layer you literally never even see
- built with paid labor of like 300 people over 8 years from one of the most respected industry giants in gaming, and multiple hundreds of millions of dollars from multiple studios and corporations including fucking Microsoft 
- No building in your ship, only superficial changes to the exterior that make it harder or easier to get to your cockpit, which is the only part of your ships interior that actually matters.
- nothing to spend your money on
- boring, ugly, generic NPCs with 3 impersonal lines of dialogue each
- like 3 major cites and 10-ish handcrafted locations that anyone will ever see
- quests that suck and don't matter and lie to you by giving you the illusion of choice
- 4 major factions that are all the same both morally and incredibly similar content-wise, each of which are forced upon you and breathe down your neck any time you're around other humans, including a pirate faction that hates you if you kill and steal from literally anyone other than specifically designated targets for procedurally generated missions
- progression is gated by the perks system so 90% of players will never see the entirety of the base building system or the gun crafting system or get a class C ship etc etc.
- literally zero interesting systems outside of the main shooting and looting borderlands type gameplay with components that all constantly fight each other and don't work together at all (carry weight too low, stealth is useless, Skyrim shout powers are all stupid and outclassed by everything else because they don't scale with level, enemy AI is braindead, economy is completely unbalanced and makes no sense despite the push for "realism" everywhere else in the game, etc.)
- runs like shit; players told to "upgrade their computers"
- crashes to desktop and save-ruining glitches not uncommon 
- cringe pseudo-ironic smug reddit-tier soypilled manchild Rick and Morty dialogue that makes me want to turn the game off and not play as the character I am presented, because none of the dialogue options would ever be said by a sane human being with more than 4 brain cells.  more than happy to blow smoke up your ass with pointless, bloviating dialogue that doesn't even give you information about the characters or world and just exists to waste your time and the writer's time and the implementation team's time and the voice actors' time
- Skyrim shouts but in space
- 70 dollars

Starbound:
- cool aliens (and furries)
- literally infinite worlds
- all of them are interesting 
- generic main story but you aren't really pushed to do it so it doesn't matter
- interesting space travel system that actually matters and is build into the game's progression
- building is interesting, granular, and detailed, and is a great outlet for player creativity 
- procedurally generated quests
- at least 120 dungeons and cool mini landmarks, with more using mods
- scanning shit so you can remake it in your 3d printer to build or decorate with
- infinite procedurally generated guns that are actually different from each other
- 4-piece armor system with additional dedicated layers for appearance so you don't have to always look like you're minmaxing (even if you are)
- built with the slave labor of 15-17 year old girls over like 3 years with Kickstarter money by a dude who did some texture work in Terraria 
- you can build literally your entire ship inside and out however you like, with zero restriction other than the world size limit
- immense catalogues of stuff to spend money on and an economy balanced around reasonable drop rates for money 
- cute and cool generic NPCs that add to the world's atmosphere and lore
- 1 central hub for story content, more with mods, and 10-20 unique and handcrafted story dungeons that are all easily re-visitable through a menu
- quests that do not bother with player choice because they know you're going to do it for the loot anyway
- like 8 different factions that all hate each other and have interesting motives for doing so that actually seem somewhat believable and aren't all exclusively morally good universe savers who want to make sure everyone is happy at all times
- progression is only gated by your ability to go to new planets with fuel, collect resources, and use those resources to go to new planets to get better resources, which rewards exploration and encourages players to interact with the core gameplay loop and wealth of content
- landlord and tenant system that loops into the core sandbox gameplay of building and taking over planets that doesn't badger you constantly so you can take it at your own pace and collect rewards as you please, fossil system, bug catching and trophies that give you cool display items for your houses and a collection to work towards, pet capture system that gives you companions that can help you in combat and are actually scaled and make sense, mech system that helps you in collecting resources from asteroids and in deep space, crew system that gives you a reason to build your ship out further than just looks or storage, etc etc .
- runs on a toaster
- simply does not crash or break unless you mod it and the mod fucks something up
- simple dialogue with no explicit player voice so you don't have to subscribe to a specific character to play the game.  Also does not act like it is important to the events of the game when it literally makes no difference
- you can capture a snake and a lizard and put them in your ship as pets :)
- 14.99

Itâ€™s hard to choose whether or not to recommend this game. Putting aside the employee treatment and taking the game at face value, itâ€™s a fairly good space exploration game. Iâ€™d go so far as to say that itâ€™s better than Starfield is at present and better than No Manâ€™s Sky was at launch. That being said, the game still feelsâ€¦ hollow. I canâ€™t quite describe why, but something about the construction of the worlds, the samey quests in the story mode, and the gutting of the universe lore compared to earlier builds of the game creates an experience with just enough sense of purpose to keep you playing, but not enough sense of purpose to motivate you beyond that.

You wander around with vague notions of what youâ€™re supposed to do, passing from world to world as they all start to blend together. If there were better world-building, or a more compelling story, or even just a more complex planet-generating system, then this game would be far more enjoyable.

That being said, gameplay mods, especially Frackinâ€™ Universe, can greatly improve the experience if youâ€™re willing to give them the opportunity. But, in a similar fashion as Bethesda games, itâ€™s up to you for whether you want to buy a middling game thatâ€™s saved by mods, or if you want to simply walk away and find a game thatâ€™s better at face value.

Iâ€™ll admit that Iâ€™ve gotten far more than $15 worth of enjoyment out of this game, but I also gave it much more slack than it might have deserved.

So tl;dr: this game is decent without mods, and quite spectacular with mods, but itâ€™s up to you to see if thatâ€™s worth the trouble.

This game is strange. Speaking of flaws it has the most boring main quest i've ever seen in my life, life long grind and the same lifeless planets. But on the bright side this game is visually beautiful, has almost unlimited potential of building and engineering. Also you can end it in many ways. You can build your own city, gather your crew and kill the final boss with the power of friendship. If you're more of a solo player, but you don't like mining all the components of your equipment - you can buy yourself a weapon and some armor in the same city. The only downside is that you have no need to match your equip with the main quest. Starting with the first artifact, you can have full endgame gear against flowers with a leather armor xd. But all the flaws of this game can be fixed: you have a Workshop. With some QOL mods and some content mods, this game is the most fun one can have in the universe. Spent like 3 dollars on this game and it was great. Definitely recommend.

I really enjoyed this game, however it is in no way perfect. I can only agree with others pointing out that it feels incomplete. In the beginning, the game feels amazing, endless, and it's honestly super fun. The more you progress however, the more things start feeling exactly the same. I stopped playing when I was just flying from planet to planet trying to find one particular item, only to find the same NPC city over and over again. I got really bored at some point, even though I hadn't officially beat it yet. The game feels like an anticlimax. It starts off so strong, but in the end it just dims down and it left me wondering what the hell I was still doing.

I however still recommend this game, because even though this is a downside, for the price you pay you get lots of hours worth of fun and great content. I might pick it up again some day to play with mods, like a lot of people suggest. It is so cool to build your own spaceship and fly from planet to planet... If this were a DLC for Terraria, that would be a dream come true.

Buy it on sale, though.

2023 update:
this company sucks ass, treats their community horribly, lies about development.

the game is just as awful as when I originally wrote my review, nothing to do, boring single biome planets, basically no actual gameplay.

the game is only good if you get a bunch of mods, and the major mod that a lot of people use (fraken universe) is made by a guy who steals other people's mods, integrates them into his, and then marks theirs and other mods he simply doesn't like as incompatible, explicitly implementing code to block those mods from functioning.

the game is pretty much only good as a nsfw game with the community nsfw mod, let's be honest. as an actual game, it's literally nothing.

the company also tries to integrate said mods into the game without compensating the mod devs, going as far as to ask for modders to simply hand over their ips for free. while integrating mods into games is fine, I don't respect any company who is willing to offer such minimal compensation when integrating a mod into a commercial product. if starbound were free, I wouldn't be as upset about it.

I started over 10 characters and deleted them again and again just trying to give this game a fair chance. It felt like something may have been here. After all it is in space where there are near limitless possibilities......just not in this universe. This game is like a 2-D version of the original No Mans Sky. I need to say this game feels like it was a bunch of ideas that started together but only a handful might have actually been finished. This game really sucks. The same procedurally generated creatures and crap over and over with lets be honest very little real variation in other than a few swapped body parts and you will have seen all of them after about 8-12 planets. Most of the loot you find is almost always useless wherever you go weather it be some chest near a planets core or one you find just lying on the ground. It is all random besides boss weapons wich drop from there specific boss. No benefits to picking a race other than some dialogue so don't think too hard when making your character and don't get to too picky with clothing as you will be covering them in armor anyway. Having to go find scannable objects all over the game without direction is beyond the normal level of boring when the game is the same from start to finish with 0 variation at all besides finding a sea of cosmetics all over the place in random junk and most look like crap. You get a mech at some point with a drill and a gun. I know what your thinking: I can fight baddies and drill through dirt fast right? Well your half right. You will kill all things fast at the expense of being slow and once you upgrade your matter manipulator twice the drill becomes obsolete and you realize that the drill only digs dirt really well. Everything else it take 2 or more times as long for some odd reason. The mech is mostly used for sending into space to kill ships and board enemy vessels for more mediocre loot. Why the hell do I have a mech in space for combat and exploration and not a ship? It doesn't make any sense at all. Most bosses are a cakewalk but are a slog to get to because you can't simply go fight them instead you have more and more scanning to do. There is even a planet that is nothing but a sea of lava and the game does not tell you that there is no real way of exploring it without just dying yet there things to be found at the bottom. So much of this games instruction is untold so you end up finding out a bunch of things you should have been told to begin with about 40 hours in. The game has "lore" but most of it is so uninteresting I stopped reading them. There are a few good things here and there but to be perfectly honest there is simply so much nonsense in the game it doesn't deserved to be mentioned. What an absolute drag to play with 0 return. No fun.

Most compare this to Terraria, similar artwork, but the major difference is.

Terraria is a fps focused game with survival aspects added in.
Starbound is a survival story focused game with fps added in.

The difference is major if you understand the premise. 
I can highly recommend this game, I will happily sink several hundreds of hours into it, loving the story so far and the modding community has taken this game and run with it, the devs may have abandoned it, but make no mistake those talented modders have picked up the slack and made an unlimited amount of extras, QoL, dlcs, etc etc, all while sticking with the games original format. Well worth your time, believe me.

However it seems like the devs have abandoned this game even though it could have so much more. 8.7/10

Overall, I would give this game a 5.5/10. It looks and sounds nice, but the gameplay loop is very tedious because of some bad design choices. The inventory and material system has the strange combination of somehow feeling overly convoluted, while also too limiting. The combat is very shallow, it's similar to Terraria's, but with weird restrictions, lower diversity, and awful movement. It basically just It feels like they tried to take the game in too many directions and ended up with a bunch of concepts that don't work too well together. That being said, the game is enjoyable, it just feels like a missed opportunity.

The recent video about how Starbound lost reminded me of this again. Starbound is very special to me seeing as it was the first ever game that made me stop pirating it and actually buy it (with my first ever paycheck!) to keep up with updates. I'm not one for sci-fi but I loved Starbound. I played Terraria before but Starbound captured my interest and time more. It was shaping up to be a favourite and I was extremely hyped.

But then the updates stopped coming or were super lacklustre. Then the whole drama with the unpaid minors. Then the modding community slowly dying. I tried picking this game up again and again, but it's boring after you've finished the game once.

It's just sad to look back at this game. It's still a solid story-based game, but it's abandonware after that. You still hold a special place in my heart, Starbound. If only your developer was less manipulative and creepy.

Also, Novakid is the best race. You can't change my mind.

It's been years. Please, see how many hour I have shoved into this game. It is still my most played game on almost 10 years I've been on steam. 
And yet, I'm pretty sure that, considering the current state of the game, it should NOT be recommended considering several things:

It used to be a great game. Until 1.0, when Chucklefish decided to kill its creation. 
Then, abandonment came. It has not received any significant updates in YEARS. 
Its quality, surprisingly, has worsened over the years. And their creators are worsening, too.

You know what kept me playing for thousands of hours here? The modding community. That's the good one. It makes the game a lovely, wonderful, incredible place to be. 
And yet, with all the mods... It is getting worse month after month. Patches are needed, a lot of improvements that SHOULD NOT be granted to be made by the modding community.
I really want this game to improve, to be the star it used to be for my friends and I.

If anyone could get this OUT of the hands of Chucklefish I'd willingly help it to happen just to give this marvel its deserved glory. 

Until then, don't give a cent to them. If you've already made your mind or if you've already bought this game... go to the workshop page. It's the best decision you can make from this point.

Disclaimer
So upfront the base game has some issues some things feel just like they could be a little bit better that I will mention in the review and there are some bugs, but, big but, this game has a pretty active modding community. I recommend even if you want a vanilla experience go on the steam workshop get whatever the currently updated performance optimizing mod there is, any up to date bug fixes there are and if it's still up to date when you read this, and Alpha Combat (it re-balances the weapons a bit so there are more "good" options for weapons). Just be careful with the Date on the mods I know older ones cause issues with the bounty hunter update. I have comments on in this one so if anyone has any specific mods along this vanilla+ theme feel free to point them out there. No, I see you typing Frackin Universe; you know as well as I do that that is no where near vanilla+.

Normal Review Part
You are going to hear the nickname "Space Terraria" when people talk about this game, and while it does have it's similarities, it is it's own game. For one late game is a lot less crazy the mobility doesn't get up to that level but has a more grounded feeling. I don't want to spoil too much but even later bosses don't have you flying around like crazy and have a more "Dark Soulsy" approach with enemies usually having only occasional telegraphed attacks (aside from the cyber bullet hell. You will know him when you meet him). Now I mentioned Dark Souls but this is by no means anywhere in the same vibe or difficulty. Combat is very forgiving as long as you are appropriately geared and there is a much more lighthearted sci-fy adventure energy to it. Plenty of little jokes here and there. The story isn't any literary/cinematic masterpiece but it's simple and fun and there is plenty of lore books that help with a bit of the world building. Also if you are a colectaholic this game has many collectibles between the bugs, monsters (there are basically pokeballs), food, fish, trophies, and aforementioned lore books.

Overall I'd give the vanilla game 6.5/10
Modded however makes this game a 9/10 for me though with mods it can be all over the place and up to personal preference and what mods you have. There is a reason as of writing this is the game I have the most hours in.

[h1]Top 10 reasons to play Starbound in 2023[/h1]
[h2]Reason #1: Itâ€™s like Terraria, but IN SPACE![/h2]
It is generally accepted that Terraria is a great game. Starbound is similar to Terraria, but has less focus on combat and more focus on exploration. And of course, itâ€™s in space! And as we know, everything is betterâ€¦ IN SPAAAAAAAAAAACE! So if you like Terraria, or even Minecraft, you should definitely give Starbound a try!
[h2]Reason #2: No microtransactions[/h2]
Lootboxes, in-game stores or even a neverending stream of minor DLCsâ€¦ you can find at least one of these in most games nowadays, even in some single player titles. Starbound has none of these. The only paid DLC for the game is its soundtrack, which is not even in-game content.
[h2]Reason #3: Itâ€™s affordable[/h2]
In addition to not having microtransactions of any sort, this game is cheap. Its original price is around 14 EUR and the soundtrack which includes dozens of tracks costs 80 cents. Both of these regularly go on sale, cutting the price in half!
[h2]Reason #4: The soundtrack is epic[/h2]
The gameâ€™s soundtrack was created by Curtis Schweitzer, who also contributed music to Halo Infinite. It fits the game perfectly and has a chill, nostalgic yet epic vibe. Great stuff!
[h2]Reason #5: Endless amounts of content[/h2]
Starbound was designed from the ground up to be moddable. New biomes, new species, new clothes, new questsâ€¦. Instead of buying these as DLCs or something, players can create and share all of these and more. If something is not in the game, you can most likely add it to the game. There are new mods published on the Steam Workshop to this very day, so running out of content is almost impossible. And whatâ€™s best is the Steam version makes mods very simple to install. Entire mod packs can be installed with a single click and the Steam Workshop does the rest for you. Incredible!
[h2]Reason #6: Avali[/h2]
Thanks to [url=https://steamcommunity.com/workshop/filedetails/?id=729558042]one of the gameâ€™s most popular mods[/url] you can play as the Avali! Enough said! :D
[h2]Reason #7: Ultimate player freedom[/h2]
If you tought Starbound stopped at the usual type of mods, you thought wrong. Starbound utilizes so called client-side mods, which let you further customize your experience in multiplayer without affecting the experience of others. You want some of the characters to look different just on your screen? Or maybe you want to fly around and have infinite blocks as if you were playing creative mode in Minecraft. What about an infinite inventory? Maybe some tuning of the difficulty settings? You can do all of these with client-side mods without the people you play with also having to use these very same things. Revolutionary!
[h2]Reason #8: The blinking meme[/h2]
You might have seen or even used [url=https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/blinking-white-guy]this meme[/url] before! Did you know that its origins lie in Starbound? Now you do!
[h2]Reason #9: Instruments and bands[/h2]
A unique feature of Starbound is that it lets you play music in-game on a number of instruments. There are a few default songs and also many song packs you can download. Or you can create your own.  You can even play some specially created songs as a multiplayer band.
[h2]Reason #10: The whole gang can play[/h2]
The game features multiplayer without putting any limitation on player count. The only real limit is how much the hardware can handle. This means that with enough players and good server hardware the game can essentially become a mini-MMO.
[h2]Bonus Reason: Multiverstar[/h2]
Multiverstar, my chill, non-toxic, professionally run Starbound community just relaunched this year and itâ€™s better than ever! Itâ€™s a cool place for Starbound newbies and veterans alike where you can share your creations and play with others on a modded server with loads of content. More info at [url=https://multiverstar.pentag.info]https://multiverstar.pentag.info[/url].

READ THE FULL REVIEW (Steam has a word limit) HERE: https://gemsimov.com/game-reviews/f/starbound---a-review
--
Simple review details - I rank games on an out of 10 basis, granting up to 3 points in 3 categories, as well as a last, single point from my own self, depending on my experience with it.

GAMEPLAY

Starbound is a 2D game about a goon (of the Playerâ€™s choice) running around, destroying the environments of countless planets, killing the inhabitants of said planets, collecting stuff and (maybe) building stuff.

It features incredibly lackluster RPG elements, limited to the equipment the Player Character (PC) wears (which also determines how strong the PC is) and the race of the PC. The race of the PC affects the layout of the Playerâ€™s ship, which means that it is a stylistic choice only.

In theory, this sounds good â€“ in practice, it winds up not being very good.

Running around is affected negatively by the fact that this game, even while being played by a single person, features latency and lag caused by bad connection â€“ meaning that the PC will sometimes be moved back to a previous position, objects that were interacted with will revert to a state of not being interacted with and enemies who get hit will not take damage, as though they were not hit.

As a consequence, combat (which is incredibly simple, relying on an energy meter [stamina bar] for most actions and boiling down to occasionally being able to jump or dash away from an enemyâ€™s attack) is also affected negatively. Not only that, but the Playerâ€™s progression and the difficutly curve move in such a manner that the Player is always very close to getting killed by most encounters and never does said Player feel strong (due to limiting design).

Fortunately, the good part of Starbound are the environments (which are not THAT negaitvely affected by the constant latency issues), the things that can be found by the Player in said environments and the abiltiy to destroy everything in favor of building things. Since Starbound is built of blocks, the way building and destorying things happens is that a batch of blocks gets destroyed (or placed) at once, which makes the process a lot more manageable and even enjoyable.

However, that does not make amends for the rest of this gameâ€™s unfortunate performance. There are some interesting bosses that show up every now and then, but there are chance based drops from them â€“ CHANCE BASED DROPS in the single-player game. Itâ€™s just a jumble of horrible design choices.
1/3

PRESENTATION

Starbound is beautiful. Pixel-art that allows for wonderful sights to unveil themselves before the Player, both as backgrounds and foregrounds, incredibly soothing music and satisfying sound effects that provide great feedback. Itâ€™s fantastic.
3/3

STORY

Starbound tells a tale of galactical annihilation and eldritch monstrosities, a cult dedicated to said monstrosities and a group of fellows tasked with protecting the Galaxy from harm. The PC is one such Protector, and goes on a trip to collect a number of macguffins, with which a door is to be open, which door leads to the elditch monster, which gets killed and everything is wonderful again.

The game features a plethora of interesting things â€“ related to the many races that are present â€“ and has a LOT of lore connected to them, but at the same time it constantly falls into plotholes it has created. Robots, who are culturally and technoloically programmed to be stuck in medieval times, somehow design and manifacture spacefaring vessels. Plant people with the intelligence of 6-year old children also get to make their own space-ships. Religious luddites who throw people off of buildings as a religious ritual â€“ also get to have their own space-ships.

The lore is interesting on a surface level, but the deeper the Plaeyr goes, the more riiculous it becomes.
1/3

Legendary Point

Does this game get the legendary point, so craved and wanted by all and none at the same time? No. NO! How does anyone expect from me to give an always on DRM pile of steaming trash the legendary point? Iâ€™m not giving it to Starbound, no, thank you. 0/1

CONCLUSION

5/10. An average game that gets a bit too much love from other folks. Play it on the lowest difficulty and build. Not worth it for much else, really. Could recommend it to fans of Minecraft or Terraria, but then why wouldnâ€™t they play either Minecraft or Terraria instead?

 On the wall of shame, I hang this game. So much potential, lost. Alas, I canâ€™t save it.
--

Starbound is an epic sandbox adventure that's Kappa-rich with endless exploration, PogChamp-worthy building, and Kreygasm-inducing discoveries. The game's interstellar journey, combined with its pixelated charm, makes it a top-tier content creator's dream, delivering countless Kappa moments and ensuring you'll never ResidentSleeper through a playthrough. Whether you're a seasoned streamer or just LUL-ing at the universe, Starbound is a must-play for any Twitch-savvy gamer.

Pros:
1. Epic Exploration: Starbound offers Kappa-tivating planets to explore, delivering non-stop PogChamp moments as you uncover new biomes and secrets.

2. Build-a-Palooza: The game's building mechanics are absolutely Kreygasm, allowing you to create stunning bases that will leave your viewers wide-eyed in awe.

3. Multiplayer Mayhem: Co-op play is a Twitch SquadW party, perfect for collaborative streams and hilarious multiplayer shenanigans.

4. Pixel-Perfect Aesthetics: Starbound's pixel art style is pure eye candy, ensuring a visually appealing stream that'll have your viewers saying "Kapp."

5. Infinite Variety: With a seemingly endless universe to explore, Starbound guarantees you'll never run out of content, keeping your chat LUL-ing for days.

Cons:
1. Grindy Crafting: The crafting system can feel like a Kappa marathon, often leading to ResidentSleeper moments as you gather resources and grind for materials.

2. Learning Curve: Starbound's mechanics can be a bit PogChamp for newcomers, potentially deterring some viewers who are looking for more accessible gameplay.

3. Storyline Stumbles: The game's storyline can be a bit LUL, lacking the depth and engagement needed to keep viewers truly invested in the narrative.

4. Late-Game Slowdown: As you progress, the action can become a bit MonkaS, with repetitive tasks and less excitement compared to earlier stages of the game.

5. Updates and Development: Starbound's development has slowed down, leaving some viewers FeelsBadMan about the potential for future content and improvements.

Starbound: The Universe's Ultimate Epic LOLventure - 5 Stars and Beyond!

Rating: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…

Get ready for an interstellar epic of astronomical proportions - it's "Starbound," the game that boldly goes where no meme has gone before, and it's got all the stars (five of them, to be exact) to prove it. Here's why this game is so outrageously, side-splittingly, and meme-tastically amazing:

Endless Exploration, Much Wow: In "Starbound," you'll journey to a galaxy far, far away (just kidding, it's in your PC) and explore procedurally generated planets that are as diverse as a box of chocolates. You never know what you're gonna get - whether it's a lush paradise, a fiery hellscape, or a frozen tundra that'll give you "Winter is Coming" vibes.

Epic Pixel Art: So Aesthetic, Much Wow: The game's pixel art is so lit that even the most hardcore memelords will be like, "this is fine." You'll be snapping Instagram-worthy shots of your breathtaking bases and planets with memes as captions.

Le Epic Creativity: Build your own bases, spacecraft, and meme factories. With an arsenal of building materials and decorations, you can create structures that are danker than a doge meme.

Such Quests, Many Stories: "Starbound" throws you into the memeiverse with a rich backstory and quests that are more intriguing than "The Two Buttons" meme. NPCs bring their unique tales to the table, making the game feel as alive as "This is Fine" dog.

Crafting Extravaganza: Get ready for some seriously in-depth crafting, 'cause the options here are more diverse than the "Expand Dong" meme. Experiment with recipes, gather resources, and upgrade your gear like a pro.

Multiplayer LOLs: Form meme-worthy crews with your friends and embark on hilarious adventures across the galaxy. Teamwork has never been this amusing since "Distracted Boyfriend"!

Mods Galore, Prepare for Takeoff: "Starbound's" modding community is more vibrant than a Nyan Cat rainbow. Enhance your experience with mods and you'll be like "Wombo Combo!" every time you launch the game.

Playstyles for Days, Y'all: Whether you're into combat, farming, or meme-hunting, "Starbound" has got you covered. Be the hero, the farmer, the merchant, or all of the above like a boss.

Updates? Such News, Much Wow: The developers keep dropping updates like "Distracted Boyfriend" memes on the internet. They're committed to making "Starbound" the ultimate meme-tastic experience.

Soothing Yet Epic, Like Peanut Butter Jelly Time: The game's soundtrack is so chill that you'll be nodding like "Yeah Boi" while battling alien foes. Play for a quick meme break or lose yourself for hours - you decide!

In a world full of memes, "Starbound" stands out as an epic LOLventure that's as dank as a freshly baked meme. Don't miss out on this one, because the game's just that "Infinite Monkey Theorem" meme waiting to go viral in your heart. Strap in, my fellow memelords, and launch into the cosmos of "Starbound" - your epic adventure begins now! ðŸš€ðŸŒŒðŸ˜‚

Where to begin...This is everything a sandbox should be.  Just a little guidance and story to keep you moving forward (though you can completely do your own thing if you'd rather).  There is an incredible amount of depth, and the space Chucklefish has created is nothing short of astounding.  You can explore, craft, build, recruit crew, fight with an amazing array of some great weapons.  You can even build whole colonies to attract residents, merchants, and quest givers to populate your conquered or created world.  (I took over a penal colony and put a deed in the Warden's quarters and a really cool rare goods merchant moved in).  Explore anomalies in space with your mech.  Truly the possibilities are endless.  And you can do all this with friends through multiplayer too!  I cannot say enough good things.

Starbound is one of those games you really want to succeed, since it just has sooo much potential to be absolutely awesome, but at the end of the day the game just lowkey sucks. The idea of Starbound is that you can travel through an infinitely generated sandbox of a galaxy, upgrading your spaceship and finding cool stuff. But the game just fails at almost everything, such as:

-	There are many unique and cool races, but it basically makes no difference which one you pick.
-	The progression system is a complete and utter joke that doesnâ€™t exist.
-	Story-progression is about as interesting as watching paint dry.
-	After 10 or so planets you get to the point where you have pretty much seen everything there is to see. (The same generated structures show up over, and over, and over, and overâ€¦)
-	The NPCs are braindead, only speaking 1 line per character. 1 LINE.
-	Since you can just decorate your ship, there is no actual reason to build anything on planets.

This is all such a shame, since Starbound is such a unique idea which I really want to succeed. There is so much potential in its ideas itâ€™s almost even more frustrating to play this mess of a game. The races are all super cool and unique, and the music is incredibly good. So good that you wonder how the hell it ended up in this game to begin with. Just amazing *chefs kiss*. 

You can make the game somewhat playable with mods, but no amount of cake icing can fix this fundamentally broken cake in my opinion, and if you really need mods to make your game playable, is it even good in the first place?

I donâ€™t believe all of this is the developerâ€™s fault. Iâ€™ve heard that Chucklefish overall are some pretty shady guys. Iâ€™ve heard stories that they underpaid or straight up didnâ€™t pay some of the Starbound developers for example. (Good thing Stardew Valley escaped their grasp am I right?)

[u] Overall, this game just sucks. Its world and ideas are so rich, but its execution is just so bad it makes me sad. (Music is good though) 2/10 play Terraria instead. [/u]

I find it funny how people, in a sandbox type of game where a lot of what you will do hinges on what you like, criticize a game for being empty. It's a sandbox game. If people have any sort of imagination at all, there is a whole lot that can be done if you're willing to put the time in to do it. Games like this aren't all about the endgame. Cliche and memed to death, but this game is a pretty good representation of that. I've put in many hours in this game, namely building different kinds of houses, commandeering and restoring broken down structures, starting colonies by hand, building up a farm to exclusively produce burgers (which is more complicated than you might think), and so much more BEFORE ever putting a mod in.

But when you lack creativity in a sandbox, all you see is powdered rock and wonder how anyone can see it as fun.

It also helps to play with friends. I forgot to mention that me and my friends started a band playing christmas music on all the different instruments. That was a fun time as well.

Starbound has been a great source of cooperative fun for my son and me. This platformer offers a detailed and enjoyable gaming experience.

One of its strong points is the cooperative mode, which has allowed us to explore the game's universe together, adding to our gaming moments. The game's world is diverse, with various planets to discover, each with its own unique features.

Building and crafting in the game have been enjoyable, and we've had fun creating our own bases. "Starbound" provides quests and missions that offer a sense of progression, keeping us engaged.

As a platformer, it provides some challenging moments without being overly difficult. Overall, "Starbound" is a great game for cooperative play and exploration, making it a good choice for those looking for some casual gaming fun with friends or family.

Starbound is a game that is quite on the fence for me. On one hand, I love this game, and I am grateful I was along for the ride during it's updates. Sadly, Starbound isn't worth paying even 15 dollars for when Terraria exists. This game has such a linear progression that replayability isnt really there outside of modded race attributes and the like, and exploration feels worthless after one playthrough.

The only reason i am rating this positively is because with mods, i find this game more enjoyable than vanilla Terraria (of course, tmodloader exists, making this review pointless). I recommend Frackin' Universe as a start. The combat in this game, especially when modded is incredibly refined and polished compared to Terraria, the weapons and animations feel super nice compared to png sword swing.

This game has its ups and downs (especially the developer drama), however i still find it to be quite enjoyable.

With barely 7h in the game I probably have no right to say this, but the game is EXTREMELY unfriendly to new players. 

UI - has barely any explanations- heck even the fact that you can move it away from the center of the screen is not mentioned or hinted at on the ui itself. 
Planetary travel is not explained anywhere. It would literally take the tiniest little ship assistant AI text blurb to explain this when you first open the menu and the devs chose not to. 

You have to get very lucky with random weapon finds on the first planet to even survive. Since you can't really craft anything remarkably good yourself. 

The combat is also nothing pleasant. Most weapons have combo animations that then go on cooldown, so if you don't have a place to back off to, you are going to take a lot of damage and not be able to do much about it BECAUSE - once the enemy is in YOUR hitbox, they are immune. But they can still hurt you. 

Additionally having been told to get mods to make my experience better is very alarming. The first proper play through any game should not require the help of mods.

Been a LOOOOONG time since I reviewed this for the first time. Lotta stuff has changed and so has my opinion.

When Starbound first came out as a full game, it ran like crap and crashed my PC within minutes of starting a journey. Since then, Chucklefish has definitely fixed this issue, so much so that I rarely have FPS drops, if at all. 

Content wise, the game holds itself up pretty well. Lotta lore to uncover, places to explore, and things to hunt. This, like with many other open-world exploration games, is only amplified with mods.

While the price has not changed since I first purchased this for my ex and I back during the beta build, I'd argue it's well worth the price nowadays.

Over all, solid experience. 9.5/10

I realistically cannot recommend this game in good faith despite the several years I've had and played this game for. The controversy has put a lot of baggage on a game that's quite frankly already bland as all hell with nothing of interest to time sink into. Progression doesn't amount to anything cause everything in this game exists just to railroad you back into the linear as all hell plot nobody even asked for. With how extremely bare bones it is and the now painfully linear story progression making things even worse because it's salad dressing on top of something already plain as fuck. If you are still hellbent on playing this, go get as many mods as you possibly can so it's got something for you to do. If that doesn't sound like a decent enough time or you're one of those weirdos who has a gripe against playing a game modded, then just go play Wargroove instead. It was also developed by Chucklefish and WASN'T made by a bunch of unpaid interns.

Tits?

This game is a never-ending series of small dopamine hits that will have you neglecting all of life's other essentials as you choose to instead wander across the surface of yet another of an infinite number of planets.

Gather and hoard resources.  Craft things.  Completely ignore the main storyline.  Build a house.  Build a lab.  Kill bad guys and take their base decorations.  Make your perfect outfit.  Jump into janky multiplayer with your friends and then wind up at ground zero when one of your friends drops a nuke in a city you're standing in (true story). Play it until you burn out.  Then put it down for a while.  Then come right back to it again after a few weeks or months and do it all again with a totally new character.

Mods.  Mods.  Mods.  Mods are life.  Frackin' Universe is mandatory.  Download new races and tools.  Be a furry space cat.  Abuse the admin commands.  Become God.  Then pine for the simple life, start over, and do it all again.

At times, progression can be slow and the amount of times you are dying can stack pretty high. Starbound is not without its flaws. Despite whatever flaws it has, it does a stellar job in generating random worlds to visit and explore. Excellent color choices and stunning landscapes.

Buckle up, space cadets! "Starbound" is the intergalactic sandbox adventure that puts the 'exploration' in 'extraterrestrial.' From the get-go, you're thrust into an ever-expanding universe, free to carve out your own space destiny. With pixel art that packs a cosmic punch and an atmospheric soundtrack that'll make you feel like Captain Kirk on a good day, this game nails the sci-fi vibes to a T.

What sets "Starbound" apart is its sense of endless possibility. Feel like discovering new planets? Go ahead. Want to build an interstellar colony or dig to the core of an alien world? The universe is your playground. With an expansive crafting system, intricate combat mechanics, and a treasure trove of creatures to discover, you'll soon realise that space isn't just bigâ€”it's chock-full of things to do!

Tired of solo space adventures? Invite your friends aboard for some co-op action! Trust me, battling extraterrestrial baddies and embarking on interplanetary quests are always better with pals. And with the game's active modding community, there's no end to the new content and features you can add to your galactic journey.

So, if you've got the itch for an expansive space adventure where the sky is NOT the limit, then fire up your thrusters and dive into "Starbound." It's not just about reaching for the starsâ€”it's about what you do once you get there! ðŸš€âœ¨

I've played the game since way early beta and it was a unique and enjoyable experience, back when your entire backstory came from just a few journals and everything else you had to discover for yourself. It still felt incomplete however but the base experience was fantastic. With the new story and systems added to the game, it really detracts from your ability to interpret the story, have your own understanding of your character, or even being able to identify with the race you picked. Previously, there were race-specific backstory journals, potentially hinting at upcoming race-specific stories. Now, no matter what race you picked, you are shoehorned into the same story which was equally shoehorned into the game. It is a requirement to even leave the starting planet to follow the story and it drains all potential creativity from a game built on creativity. 
Additionally, instead of being able to find unique, sprawling dungeons in the world, they're shifted to be story content that you teleport to and cannot interact with at all beyond killing the things in your way before reaching the end, entirely removing the building aspect of the sandbox building game for this linear content that it really was never designed for. It's incredibly jarring and like if Minecraft had quests and you couldn't build stone weapons till you completed the associated quest. If you don't mind having to sit through the story and have great patience for superfluous downtime there's a great game buried here.

This game has the basic formula to be a favorite of mine. However the game also tries literally ANYTHING AND EVERYTHING to make you stop playing. but not in the Getting over It kind of way. I mean in pure Teddies, Boredom, Frustration. Or like starring at Discord light mode for four hours strate while also using 2G wifi to beat snake. With that said I did find a way to enjoy this game. and I mean enjoy. 
Step one was Casual only fuck hunger, fuck not being able to teleport underground, fuck lousing 30% of yourself when you die.
Step two, get instant crafting, better platform falling, more planet info, optimizbound(and any others you can find), melee aiming, perennial crops, and more threads. all of these mods are requierd for me to even consider pressing play. 
But when I do get all the """"""kinks"""""" sorted out then it actually becomes playable. I find that the game is an open world, fetch quest simulator where the story isn't important, but instead an excuse to do stuff. 
I like that. That works well. spelunking for metals in a planet is mind easing. doing boss fights is exiting. Squeezing as much efficiency out of the space one your low tear ship appease my OCD. and raiding ships with mecks are so fun when your being over whelmed on the way to the ship and you can barely doge all the enime's attacks whill's also barley being able to hit them as well making it a war of attrition where your tight maneuverability is the only thing keeping you alive is so exhilarating.

So there is fun to be had, Iff (not a typo) you can get the right mods, get pass the bigining, get your teck, have think skin to brush off small things that would get other people angry, And you don't have any DLC sized mods because they completely messed up the delicet balance of an enjoyable experience for me.

A phenomenal game. Definitely buy it if you like the genre!!!
Don't listen to the comments calling it "abandoned". It's not abandoned, it's *finished*. That's a hard concept for some to understand.

It has a smooth building system (with tons of furniture and blocks), space exploration (you can expand an customize your ship), a solid main story, fun missions, lots of weapon options, and mech-building. You can recruit crew, who can help you fight and provide some effects on your ship. You can create entire settlements, attract merchants, and collect rent. 

Fun multiplayer with plenty for everyone to do, as well.

I really hope the team decides to do a sequel!!!

My only complaint is that this game doesn't get updates anymore. Otherwise, it's a great experience. Nothing world-shattering, unless you count both the beginning and ending of the game. I say "ending" in more than one way, here: Once you beat the final boss, the universe opens up entirely. This can either bring about a sense of relief and creative desire... Or a sudden inclination to say "now what?", close the game, and go do something else. It's a real 50/50. Either way, I would still recommend this game, as even if you delete your character and start over every time you beat the final boss, playing up to that point can very much be a different experience each time, you might even find your perfect universe. TL;DR, Good game, can be a bit much for some.

Starbound is a good enough game if a bit mediocre. The main story and progression is fairly standard and short if you just focus on that and not the exploring aspect. The exploring aspect is quite good and while you will notice that once you have visited a few planets of different environments it gets repetitive, it is still fun if you play with friends. Additionally, when you aren't exploring planets fighting enemies you would be building and designing. I found that designing my ship in the style of my character to be very fun and satisfying while listening to the background music which is very relaxing and I would often just listen to the main menu music and relax.

Overall, Starbound is a short but relaxing game to play by yourself or with friends but once everything is done it begins to fade over time.
chillin in space

Starbound is a game of all time. Is it fun? Kinda, but only once. Is the main story absolutely garbage? Yep, glad I skipped over it in my first playthrough. The planets get samey fast, which sucks because you need to visit the different types multiple times just to progress through the story, which really encourages players to ignore it and get the best equipment in the game before doing any of the dungeons. And once you do that, the game becomes really easy until the last two missions, at which point it gets hard. But not in a good way, definitely not in a good way. One of the other things you can do in Starbound is build a colony, but I honestly haven't ever done that because all the blocks that I'd want to use are either require a lot of materials to produce in sufficient quantities, or aren't unlocked by default & need to be found before you can craft them. And furniture? Don't worry, you just have to hope you get lucky and find blueprints for it in random chests occasionally found on planet's surfaces, or that an NPC is selling them.

I do not hate Starbound. I just find it bland. Should other people play it? Yeah, I think so - I know that I liked playing it at first, even in vanilla. But if you want to have fun playing it, and for there to be any amount of replayability at all, you absolutely need to use mods. Mods are the salt and pepper that give the game flavor, and they completely redeem the general lack of variety that the base game has. So I will recommend Starbound not because it's a good game in itself, but because it's a great foundation for the community to build upon.

Starbound is one of those games that seems to keep coming back into my playtime.  It's very similar to Terraria except that you can fly to other planets, build outposts and explore endlessly.  The vanilla experience is okay, but really the game comes alive through the Workshop and mods that add hundreds of hours of gameplay and content.  I very much recommend Starbound if you like exploration, survival, and a game that lets you build creatively in space.

Nearing 1k hours Starbound is more frustrating than it is fun. The base game is shallow and after about a day or so requires mods to remain engaging. Starbound has had years along side its survivalcraft brethren to carve out its own little niche but I find where it innovates is too far and few between. Somehow this expansive potential universe manages to be both grossly linear and mindlessly open ended. Funneling progression through these curated dungeons with an arbitrary 'no edit here' field. Yeah you can sci-fi logic whatever excuse you want but with how each planet is structured and what little reason there is to explore the underground, all perfectly represents all the superficial novelty that is quickly lost to the abyss the second you dig beneath the surface.

Starbound is a game devoid of creativity that relies on its modding community to pick up where the developers left off.

I played this game on launch, but didn't finish it and made a very long pause for around 2 years. 

Developers made a lot changes, but some problems were never fixed.

1) Some mechanics feel pretty gimmicky. For example mecha. Do I need it? Yes, for sure! I can explore empty asteroid fields space what take planet slot near the star. Can use it to land on a planet. But for what? If planet is hazardous your mecha will start loosing hp. Not much sense to do it. Maybe I can use it to fly to other randomly generated space ships? Yes! You will find there details to upgrade your mecha! So you can fly between asteroids for no reason at all even longer..
2) Game turns into a game where single endgame goal is to collect all cosmetic items. Sometimes mindlessly searching for specific planet in hopes of getting chest with right item.
3) You don't have collection tab. Sticker book. I wanna see at least what items ive already collected. You have tab to see captured animals, but not tab with your cosmetics what you have collected.
4) Some items are way too easy to craft and you will never lack any resources.
5) Too little ammount of dungeons. Temples, sewers etc. Most of them are worthless unless you want to have this particular bed from this structure on your base.
6) Performance issues even on decent PC
7) Most bosses are fat and boring. All what you need to do is to hit a lot and dodge 1-3 similar moves over and over again.
8) When you full upgrade your ship\tech\matter manipulator you still will get items what were required for all this upgrades. They are still looted from everywhere.

But thatâ€™s great game what I enjoyed a lot by playing solo and with my friends. Easy 20h+ of very fun gameplay in randomly generated world what has a lot to offer.

TLDR: Pretty fun the first time around but doesn't offer much replay value and endgame is lacking.

Starbound was a game I followed through its beta versions for many years, I still remember how it each update would delete my save files and I had to start over. But despite that it was still fun to start over because there were new content each time so it felt fresh. Needless to say, I really liked Starbound and I was very excited about version 1.0 finally releasing.

Starbound offered a vast universe with interesting areas to explore and cool items to find. On top of that it had a rather enjoyable story mode. But I think the story mode was the thing that hurt Starbound the most, since it killed off all the replayability the game had. After you are done with the story mode once, the game doesn't offer much to you. As you keep exploring the "vast" universe you start to realize that there actually isn't much to explore, you will most likely see all the interesting stuff the game can offer while playing through the story for the first time, after that it all just feels the same over and over again. The game offers different classes to play with; mainly melee, ranged and mage but honestly there isn't much variety to make you want to replay as a new class. There are also different races which you can choose from but they are only for cosmetics as well and don't offer any real gameplay difference, which is a really missed opportunity. Endgame content is equally lacking, you unlock ancient vaults where you can explore but that again just ends up being the same thing really fast. And the bounty hunting quests are dreadfully boring as well.

When I first got around playing Starbound I thought it was Terraria in space, but that I realized soon enough that I was wrong, because Terraria offered so much replay value while Starbound is a one time experience for me. Replaying through the story is tideous because you have to go through the explorations all over again but this time they don't feel exciting, you have to go through the story missions again, which are fine on your first run but again they just end up being boring the second time around, only then to be able to get to the boss. Every time you want to fight against a boss you have to play through that stage again which is not fun at all. 

Despite all of this Starbound is a beautiful game, it has soul to it. There are a great variety of cosmetics and furniture, you can get pets, some vehicles, unique weapons etc. 

So my final verdict is that, Starbound is a fun game, but only for your first playthrough and it doesn't offer too much after that so buy the game with that in mind. But I am sure you will enjoy the game itself while it lasts so I would definitely recommend it if you are not expecting hundreds of hours of entertainment from the game.

So, I love this game. Seriously, it's awesome. It just captures a sense of wonder that I don't see many games accomplishing these days.

Unfortunately, once you beat the main story, you start to see just how empty the game is. There really isn't much to do in endgame but build cool stuff. If you love building awesome bases and such, absolutely play this, you'll have a blast.

And the worst part is, that's where it ends. That's it. Chucklefish has basically completely abandoned this game. Not officially, but it would take a miracle for Starbound to get any more updates.

Luckily, the community comes to the rescue! There are THOUSANDS of mods that add so much to the game. Frackin' Universe alone basically transforms it into an entirely new experience.
So, while I do recommend this game, as it is awesome on a first playthrough, I only recommend sticking around if you enjoy playing with the mods and building stuff. The game will most likely never see another update, which is a shame.

As much as I hate comparing games and especially comparing Starbound and Terraria, Starbound feels like Terraria's older and more mature-- but still fun-- brother. Both games are amazing and unique in their own right but I just can't help but feel like how I did when I played Terraria for the first time. It's a breath of fresh air from the overly saturated fps/tps genre while still keeping the golden elements from both. Now I can't just sit here and praise the game in good faith without mentioning its faults. Without a doubt, mods and workshop support carry the fun but monotonous gameplay loop that is vanilla. While I feel inclined to say the story is good, in truth it is quite mediocre. Like I said before, the gameplay is lightly monotonous and the story is more of the same; go to dungeon, clear dungeon, get item, return, rinse and repeat. In total, 10 of the 45ish hours I have played (at time of review) have been dedicated to the storyline whereas the rest is from  miscellaneous side quests (which are literally copy pasted) and activities that you can do throughout the game. My point of saying this is the vanilla gameplay, quite frankly, is boring. In summary, play with mods, simply because the vanilla game is not worth $15. (Frackin Universe carries)
Highly recommend the mod Frackin Universe to give you a full in depth game experience

Unmodded starbound's state makes me think the devs barely listened to criticism, and kept adding new shiny features instead of fixing old problems with the game.

Apparently there was a core team, and a revolving door of unpaid "contributors" doing a decent portion of the work. anyone asking to be paid was yelled at by tiy, the lead developer of starbound and founder of chucklefish. this made any attempts at gradually changing and polishing the game pointless, because new devs unfamiliar with what the previous dev was attempting to implement would step in, and see the current state of the game as something to add onto, instead of improve. 
https://community.playstarbound.com/threads/polygon-young-developers-on-starbound-say-chucklefish-exploited-their-free-work.157402/
https://www.polygon.com/2019/9/2/20839830/starbound-developers-chucklefish-game-industry-exploitation
The Good Trash made an amazing video about the state of starbound, so i updated this section of the review to include the revolving door section of their video. if you have 50 minutes to look at that instead of skimming a steam review, i'd recommend watching it.
https://youtu.be/2i2_BUffRmM?t=1385

here's some issues off the top of my head:
There are easy to defeat enemies that take actual minutes to fight because they turn invincible for long stretches of time. This wouldn't be a big problem, except they're very common, and since i'm playing on a mediocre computer, the game's poor optimization rears its ugly head. 
You can't die. You can near-instantly heal to full health with almost no cooldown, at the cost of grinding cutting down vines or farming money, except you already have to constantly grind any time you want to explore anywhere in this game focused on exploration to make new tools like ropes (also vines), since the infinite-use grappling hook is inferior to normal ropes while traversing 2D mountains that were intended for a character with x2 jump height when originally implemented, healing items (vines, no matter what tier you make, unless you farm crops for an ultra slow regen buff) or spaceship fuel.

The only late-game way to acquire money without grinding for 30% of your playtime is to slowly kill tanky enemies for pennies, or stack 1000 laggy animals in a corner minecraft style and sell their produce after you harvest by mashing [E] on them for actual minutes

Crafting requires you to stand in front of a workbench doing nothing for several minutes. (you have to wait for a timer to count down before you can craft something else and you have to stay in the crafting window) yet another problem magnified by poor optimization.
You have to do a big-ass 3 hour tutorial to even play the game and you can't skip it.

NPC quests are randomly generated fetch quests with occasional fighting of uninteresting NPCs that always feel the same, and the quests are required to upgrade your ship since they're the only way to recruit crew members. You need to upgrade your ship so you can have space for the 27~ crafting benches you get, and actually decorate your ship.

You frequently need to teleport to waypoint flags, but you have to be at a teleporter, which means you need to beam to your ship, then use the teleporter, which means a series of loading screens that require you to click something every once in a while to actually go where you want, and if you're doing the NPC fetch quests then you need to do the loading screen juggling again to get back to the quest giver, so they can give you the third part of their fetch quest.
There isn't a map to see where you've been in a planet (which is needed, considering how similar every planet is, with miles of barren wasteland and 3 tiny pre-genned structures).
It takes forever to walk anywhere, and you never gain base run speed, unless you barely noticable speed buff items, or use a buggy murder hoverbike you unlock after 30~ hours, since again, the terrain generation wasn't revamped after chucklefish decided to greatly reduce mobility for some reason.

modded starbound is alright though, except the devs keep coming back every 2 years, adding a tiny feature no one wanted, and breaking half the mods which already didn't have great modding support for implementing certain features.

But one thing I really want to talk about:

The Apex Fritter.

You cook it with an Egg, a Banana, and a corn cob.

I did not even know this thing existed. But if I google around, can find plenty of recipes for 'Banana Corn Fritters'.

But the game is right - this is INDEED the Apex of fritters. The Grand unification of savory and mildly sweet fried breakfast battered items.

The negative review isn't just because of skeevy business practices on Chucklefish's part coming to light (though they don't help).

It sold itself as a sort of spiritual successor to Terraria, but it fails in every way to capture the same magic. The combat is bland and often results in just trading or doing cover-based shooting, and feels perfectly balanced so that enemies have just slightly more hp than your energy bar can deal. Progression is barely existent, aside from mining faster you don't feel noticeably different by the endgame than you did at the start, mobility stays the same and enemy HP compared to your damage stays the same. It's also extremely poorly optimized if you have a bad or older PC.
