This game has been a game I have connected with friends with, talked with my brothers and sisters, and though about in bed while SUPPOSEDLY trying to fall asleep. This is the side-scroller space game.

Some people say that this game resembles Terraria or that it's a lesser Terraria, and I absolutely disagree, the 2 games have their own qualities and their own faults, only the graphic style resembles it. Starbound is an excellent game not for its story but for its gameplay, I didn't play it during its beta I bought it on steam on January 29th 2019 and I played it in cracked version before that in 2018. I currently have +300 hours of games on steam and in total I must be around 400/450 hours.

I digress, Starbound is a game with a lot of replayability (maybe as much as Terraria on some points but I'll get to that.) Admittedly the game in Vanilla is rather repetitive after one or two saves and becomes boring with some of its quests, which is why you have to turn to mods. We're lucky Starbound has a huge community active in the modding scene, and even today new mods come out every day, some good, some bad.

With the right modpack or even just friends, the game can become a lot of fun for the price (knowing that it's possible to get it cheaper on certain sites or during sales). I'm currently playing a game with a rather large modpack (Definitive Diverse Universe {Redux} by Kombosabo (a modpack with over 500 mods and still supported by the modpack's creator)) which is also multiplayer compatible.

Starbound is a game where, unfortunately, you don't have to concentrate too much on the story itself but where you have to play as you wish, the game is fun as long as you have a certain imagination, even if I admit that it wouldn't appeal to everyone. I hope my Starbound review helps a few people to finally buy it or play it again.

The game is set in a procedurally generated universe where players take on the role of a space explorer who must travel to different planets and complete quests while building and customizing their own spaceship.

One of the best things about Starbound is its vast and immersive universe. The game features a wide range of planets with unique environments, creatures, and resources that players can explore and exploit. The game also features a rich storyline that adds depth and meaning to the player's journey.

Another great feature of Starbound is its crafting and building system. Players can gather resources from different planets to craft weapons, tools, and other items that they need to survive and progress through the game. They can also build and customize their own spaceship, which serves as their home base and means of transportation.

Starbound also has a multiplayer mode that allows players to team up with friends or strangers to explore the universe together. This adds a social aspect to the game, making it even more enjoyable to play.

Overall, Starbound is a fantastic sandbox-style game that offers an immersive universe, a rich storyline, a crafting and building system, and a multiplayer mode. It's perfect for anyone who loves exploration, adventure, and creativity.

Though Starbound is very fun to play, the combat lacks the ability for you to feel like you'll win a fight your first time. When I would encounter a boss or miniboss, I would think I was going to go through several attempts before actually winning, which I was more than likely correct about. Though it could just sound like I'm not good enough or annoyed with losing, I actually mean it. The way that the character moves is very snappy at times where you would rather be sent a bit farther away from en enemy that hit you rather than get hit and stay in that hitbox to get hit again. The combat of Starbound is surprisingly annoying at times, specifically when you lose all your materials because you died to a random enemy you couldn't fight due to it being a block lower than you when you used your last attack. Also, the game difficulty is made in an odd way. Starbound has a hunger system just like most games today because they apparently get forced into doing so for the "survival rpg" type of game. the hunger system can be disabled in the starting menu for a new save, but turning it to that reduced difficulty also disables dropping materials on death. I may have made that part a little spun around, because I like the hunger system but not the inventory dropping on death, so I decide to keep both on because I don't have a choice unless I want to get rid of hunger, which I don't. But then it circles back to my point of the combat being stupidly one-sided in favor of your enemies unless you manage to persevere against a boss multiple times before actually surviving to the end of the fight. If anyone does find this review under the ungodly number of them, you may think that all games are like that where you need to keep trying to beat a boss. No. Starbound has annoyingly difficult bosses where if you don't know what they can and will do, you are no doubt going to have to fight again, which isn't the case in many other games. Other games give you a chance to survive, with slower or telegraphed attacks. Starbound doesn't have a whole lot of telegraphing, and even when it does, some bosses might use the same telegraph for different attacks. You could play a game like Cuphead and survive a run and gun or just a normal boss in one try, though it would be difficult, you would still actually think you could just barely make it past and survive. In Starbound, all the confidence goes out the window. Not to mention that when starting a new save, you have no armor against all those annoying enemies that you don;t have the resources to see in the dark sometimes. Not only that, but you are more likely to find weapons and armor while fighting enemies underground as surface items are unlikely to just show up and reveal themselves to you, meaning in the early game, you HAVE to face unfair enemies. "well yeah, all games have unfair enemies as you just start. you have nothing good to fight them with." Really? Look at any game that has an actual tutorial which includes combat tutorials. After the tutorial for combat is finished, you may have a starter sword or something for defense. In starbound, you have the same thing. Problem with that. In those other games, enemies with special attacks that you haven't seen before become more common with the difficulty. In starbound, because it's a sandbox-ish game, they are everywhere in unlimited amounts because all you do is survive. Oh wait, did I say survive? I meant die multiple times, regain your items, get your way over to one special structure underground and die to what's inside. So all and all, starbound is a good game, but due to the fact that the combat is as one-sided as it is, I have to give it a bad review. Oh yeah, I also beat the game already, so I didn't just play for those 31 hours grinding for items, but every goddamn boss had their own hellscape of a structure that you had to go through to actually fight the boss. Sure, there are checkpoints, but there are only 2 of them in each massive dungeon-type thing. The god damn ape boss.

Starbound is an intriguing blend of Terraria's 2D exploration and No Man's Sky's space-faring adventure, offering a unique and expansive sandbox experience. The base game, though enjoyable, may not stand out on its own, but thanks to its thriving modding community, Starbound transforms into an exceptional gaming experience.

Pros:

Robust Modding Community: The true magic of Starbound lies within its active modding community. Mods breathe new life into the game, enhancing it beyond imagination. These modifications elevate the game far beyond what the original developers had envisioned.

Diverse Mods: The recommended mods, such as Frackin Universe, Beta Bound, Shellguard Expansion, Arcana, RPG Growth, and Galaxy in Conflict, enrich the game significantly by introducing a plethora of new species, ships, armors, clothing, weapons, quests, pets, and more. They add depth and variety to the gameplay, making each adventure unique.

Endless Possibilities: With the multitude of mods available, players are spoiled for choice. The vast array of modded species and content breathe fresh life into Starbound, ensuring that players will never tire of exploring the game's boundless universe.

Cons:

Lackluster Base Game: Without mods, the base game might feel somewhat lackluster and fail to captivate players for extended periods. While it provides a solid foundation, it is the mods that truly unlock the game's potential.

Developer Updates: Some players may find the developer updates a double-edged sword. While these updates may introduce new content and quests, they can also disrupt the mods created by the community, leading to compatibility issues and diminished enjoyment.

Conclusion:
Starbound, with its blend of Terraria and No Man's Sky elements, is an engaging experience, though the true splendor of the game lies in the world of mods. The dedicated modding community ensures that players have an endless supply of creative content and exciting adventures. If you're eager to dive into a vibrant universe filled with countless possibilities, make sure to start your Starbound journey with the recommended mods. Prepare to be amazed by the depth and richness that mods bring to this unique space exploration game. Whether you're a seasoned adventurer or new to the genre, Starbound's modded experience guarantees a memorable and thrilling journey among the stars.

This most certainly constitutes a 'game'. It's fine, and some people may even find it enjoyable. I did not.

It has a bunch of mechanics that look amazing on the surface, and could make for a unique and worthwhile experience! Unfortunately there's nothing more than surface here.

1 You get a ship, but can only expand its size via upgrades (not building) and change some of the interior.

The right way to do this would've been to let us make a ship on the first planet, built uniquely with our own materials in whatever shape worked.

2 You can't land your ship on a planet. If it took up actual space it would be possible.

The solution? Make orbiting a planet take a minuscule amount of fuel. Just enough to incentivise players to build a flat area for landing.

3 The story is bad. Games don't need amazing stories in some cases, but given how linear the boss progression is via the story, it really should've been at least ok.

4 The game is super linear. Yes, if you have fuel you can go wherever and explore, but apart from ores there isn't much to find. I ended up exploring tons of planets and finding cities and airships and the like, but the loot was not very good. This was compounded by the fact that...

5 One of the game's main progression systems is clicking on background objects from different races. This is bad enough already, but let me tell you something. You have to do it in order. Out exploring and find race C's objects? Too bad, you need race A's objects. I hope you remember to come back here when you need race C's objects!

This actively disincentivises exploring anything but the planet you need. I hate this progression system as a whole, but limiting the order you find the objects in makes it way worse.

6 I hate the boss progression. The bosses themselves are good, but the way you get to them is awful. After finally completing a race's objects you get to teleport to the quest planet. These are handmade adventure stages like you'd see in a regular action game. There's puzzles, decent loot, and npcs with dialog. It's alright. It's just such a jarring shift in gameplay that it feels off to play through these sections. At which point you have a decision. Should I run through all of these levels like it's not a space exploration game? Or should I take my time and enjoy building on different planets while ignoring bosses? Neither is a good option.

7 Now about the building... It's fine. It works, you can make some pretty cool things if you try. Unless I'm mistaken however, there's no manual block change item like Terraria's hammer. And some blocks are really expensive and a pain to build with like the different types of stone. Once I place it down it shouldn't take 15 seconds to break. That's lame.

8 Another thing in relation to building is the npcs! You can recruit npcs to your ship (and I think housing on planets) by completing quests! You can even change their vanity to look like your own so everyone matches! THEY DO NOTHING! No basic shops, help with fights, resource collection, nothing at all. So much potential wasted.

9 Finally, the final boss is awful. I'm pretty sure it and the entire game was designed around having a bunch of people. Which isn't always bad, (see Monster Hunter) but in this case the final boss got butchered. I was getting excited, I finally get to beat the game and play something else. The previous bosses were a highlight. (Even if they weren't amazing) But the first phase was kind of lame. That's okay I thought. The second phase will make up for it. THERE WAS NO SECOND PHASE!

Ultimately it was a fitting end for this game. 1 corny credits sequence later, and I'm finally done. There was highlights, like the gnomes and shadow planets, but their appeal was entirely surface level. If you're looking into this game as a Terraria fan, just play modded Terraria instead. If you've never played Terraria, just play Terraria. And if you really don't want to play Terraria right now go for Vintage Story. It's not on steam, but it does work on the Steam Deck.

I just spent a lot of the game time exploring and creating. Besides that there isn't really much else. The game feels quite lacking unless all you want to do is build and use mods.

After completing all the main missions I had no interest anymore in playing. And will only play when I have nothing else.
There are other things to do but it feels pointless.
Sure you can capture and collect creatures to fight for you but they are all useless and extremely weak in battle, they die after a couple of hits.
Everything else is also tedious and boring and trying to find and collect various things which can take forever and is not at all fun.
Exploring  gets boring as once you've seen all the biomes, it all starts to look the same.
Sure I could build colonies but colonies also seem pointless.
I had some fun with the game for a while so still recommend it and rate an unmodded game 6/10.

If you thought this was a review about the game you thought wrong have a Beef Wellington.

TEP 1
Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7.

STEP 2
Sit the 1kg beef fillet on a roasting tray, brush with 1 tbsp olive oil and season with pepper, then roast for 15 mins for medium-rare or 20 mins for medium. When the beef is cooked to your liking, remove from the oven to cool, then chill in the fridge for about 20 mins.

STEP 3
While the beef is cooling, chop 250g chestnut (and wild, if you like) mushrooms as finely as possible so they have the texture of coarse breadcrumbs. You can use a food processor to do this, but make sure you pulse-chop the mushrooms so they donâ€™t become a slurry.

STEP 4
Heat 2 tbsp of the olive oil and 50g butter in a large pan and fry the mushrooms on a medium heat, with 1 large sprig fresh thyme, for about 10 mins stirring often, until you have a softened mixture.

STEP 5
Season the mushroom mixture, pour over 100ml dry white wine and cook for about 10 mins until all the wine has been absorbed. The mixture should hold its shape when stirred.

STEP 6
Remove the mushroom duxelle from the pan to cool and discard the thyme.

STEP 7
Overlap two pieces of cling film over a large chopping board. Lay 12 slices prosciutto on the cling film, slightly overlapping, in a double row.

STEP 8
Spread half the duxelles over the prosciutto, then sit the fillet on it and spread the remaining duxelles over.

STEP 9
Use the cling filmâ€™s edges to draw the prosciutto around the fillet, then roll it into a sausage shape, twisting the ends of cling film to tighten it as you go.

STEP 10
Chill the fillet while you roll out the pastry.

STEP 11
Dust your work surface with a little flour. Roll out a third of the 500g pack of puff pastry to a 18 x 30cm strip and place on a non-stick baking sheet.

STEP 12
Roll out the remainder of the 500g pack of puff pastry to about 28 x 36cm.

STEP 13
Unravel the fillet from the cling film and sit it in the centre of the smaller strip of pastry.

STEP 14
Beat the 2 egg yolks with 1 tsp water and brush the pastryâ€™s edges, and the top and sides of the wrapped fillet.

STEP 15
Using a rolling pin, carefully lift and drape the larger piece of pastry over the fillet, pressing well into the sides.

STEP 16
Trim the joins to about a 4cm rim. Seal the rim with the edge of a fork or spoon handle.

STEP 17
Glaze all over with more egg yolk and, using the back of a knife, mark the beef Wellington with long diagonal lines taking care not to cut into the pastry.

STEP 18
Chill for at least 30 mins and up to 24 hrs. Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6.

STEP 19
Brush the Wellington with a little more egg yolk and cook until golden and crisp â€“ 20-25 mins for medium-rare beef, 30 mins for medium. Allow to stand for 10 mins before serving in thick

I wrote a few words here in 2016. But I was very young back then and I Changed my opinion. So I am rewriting this. Actually, I don't want to vote a "no" here. It's a clear "meh" but, you know steam doesn't have a natural option.

This game has been one of my all-time favorites during beta. It had so much potential. This is a Terraria-looking like game. So, people who buy it will naturally gonna be sandbox lovers. Who probably would prefer replaying the game with different routes and races every time?

USCM could become an evil faction that you can join and play in some kind of evil organization (But, did USCM has been really evil?) instead of forcing us to become protectors with the 1.0 update. I mean, there should have been pathways, instead of one boring storyline. However, they removed USCM instead of using that potential. Which is a waste... I definitely would keep it as a joinable faction for human characters since it is (or was) a human-based, racist organization. So, I think a human character should have been able to join them.

Also, let's remember that this game has multiple races. As an Apex, I would much prefer to experience civil war between big brother and the resistance. The game should have given us a choice between those two factions for us. That boss battle shouldn't have been our only interaction with apes.

Another thing is that Florans and Hylotl have a bloody past even on current lore. (Which is not even a lore anymore) so why don't we see them act each other in a hostile matter? Florans invaded their home planet and ate them. But we don't see any reference to that between characters. This is unrealistic and disappointing. I mean, this story lonely can create a conflicting storyline for Hylot and Floran characters. Hylots are trying to take their home planet back and Florans trying to keep it. Hell, with the player in the equation, even a Hylot counterattack to Floran home planet would be interesting to see. Just imagine that the imperial Japanese army referenced Hylots are marching to battle. How could I see this and people who work in the game sector don't?

Glitches are another wasted opportunity. AI who achieved self-awareness and eliminated their creator? Can't you see that you can make a storyline that creates a story that could even surpass Detroit here? That could explain why Glitch was stuck in the medieval age even though they achieved space travel.

For Avians, bird people who influenced by Aztec and Egyptians. On their storyline, i would expect to see Mytologic stories. Maybe 'Gods' they fallowed could become other alien races who would try to kill the player because we discovered the trith behind them. We could also try to stop or withness Sacrifices they made, or we could join those 'gods' 

And Novakids are another story, cowboys which became a thing at the very end of the beta test. We don't know anything about them. A storyline that explains their past and even current, while the player makes them 7th race that owned one of the keys to the arch would be possible.

There were lots of random human and ape laboratories on planets. Becoming a mad scientist and unlocking special items, technology, and stuff would also be amazing for players that choose that path.

Also, why don't we see any home planets? Why most of the planets are in liveable condition? In the universe planets that let you live in them are extremely rare and it should have been the same case here. 

I just imagined home planets in some of the storylines that I wrote. So, some storylines could make them useful. Even Earth's ruins would be nice to see. And there Could be Human colonies on Mars (I'd also put an Elon Musk easter egg there) which, would have been a possible home planet for Humans in the storyline. It also could give you another thing, "Biosfer Tech" which could be a way to create life on hostile planets. That could create a colonizer storyline. Your purpose would be to create life on unliveable planets.

Additionally, since I mentioned such a system, in the end game this tech could evolve into terraforming tech. Which could give nonevil path characters a chance to fix Earth's ruins. 
For others -and maybe all-, a change to turn certain kinds of planets (such as Mars) into liveable planets with their ecosystems in the end. And, maybe for evil characters to turn liveable planets into non-liveable

I just gave a single storyline for each race in this summary, along with some ideas of mine that I had since I first saw this game here. The writers of the main story I believe that they could add many more storylines to this. This could improve replayability with a different race and a different storyline in every game. But they choose to make it something bland instead. Which wasn't the case during beta. I mean USCM had a projection of DeathStar (Yes the one from Star Wars) on their secret bases on some planets. I personally can see a planet destroyer evil dictatorship here.

Shortly, this game did not realize its potential and wasted itself in a manner that makes me so sad to see. Because current this there is no difference between different races and there is only one storyline for anyone who plays regardless of their race.

Embarking on an intergalactic journey through the boundless cosmos, Starbound has captured my imagination like no other game before. As a passionate gamer, I can confidently say that this masterpiece by Chucklefish deserves every accolade it receives. This awe-inspiring sandbox adventure has carved its own celestial path, standing tall among the giants in the gaming universe.

Starbound presents an enthralling narrative that plunges players into a vast and ever-expanding universe. From the moment you set foot on an alien planet, the sheer scale and diversity of the procedurally generated worlds is awe-inspiring. Each location teems with life, teeming with unique creatures, plant life, and civilizations waiting to be discovered.

The pixel art style of Starbound is a visual feast for the eyes. The attention to detail in every pixel breathes life into this imaginative universe. Whether traversing the lush forests of Floran planets, exploring the ancient ruins of Avian civilizations, or delving deep into the molten depths of volcanic worlds, each environment is a work of art that begs to be explored.

What truly sets Starbound apart is its boundless gameplay possibilities. Players have the freedom to create their own destiny, whether it be constructing magnificent colonies, piloting epic starships, or unearthing ancient artifacts. The robust crafting system allows you to gather resources from across the cosmos and combine them into unique items and weapons. The sense of progression is exhilarating as you unlock new technologies, enabling you to traverse the stars with ease.

Furthermore, the multiplayer aspect of Starbound enhances the already stellar experience. Uniting with friends to embark on cooperative adventures, construct shared bases, or engage in thrilling battles adds a layer of camaraderie that keeps you hooked for hours on end. The sense of community within the vastness of space is truly remarkable.

The captivating soundtrack of Starbound serves as a celestial symphony, perfectly complementing the ethereal atmosphere of the game. Each track evokes a range of emotions, from the hauntingly beautiful melodies that accompany exploration to the pulse-pounding beats that intensify combat encounters. The audio design is a testament to the care and attention poured into every aspect of this game.

Starbound is a timeless masterpiece that offers an immersive, boundless universe for players to explore. Its engaging gameplay, stunning visuals, and captivating soundtrack come together to create an unforgettable experience. Whether you're a seasoned explorer or a novice venturing into the cosmos for the first time, this game will ignite your sense of wonder and keep you coming back for more.

In conclusion, Starbound is an extraordinary game that pushes the boundaries of imagination and adventure. Its seamless blend of exploration, crafting, and storytelling is a testament to the immense talent and dedication of its developers. This game is a shining star in the gaming galaxy, deserving of all the acclaim and recognition it receives. Buckle up, fellow spacefarers, and embark on a journey that will leave an indelible mark on your gaming soul.

If you've ever wanted to clear out a penal colony and rent it out to the denizens of the universe, this is your game.

Love this game. Pretty normal sandbox. Progression is mostly based on your gear. Endgame tends to focus very much on creativity and base building imo. If you're the type that can immerse yourself and create emergent stories as you play, you will probably have a better time than someone that needs to be constantly fed objectives. 

The writing is probably the weakest part, but even that is masterful in its own way. The story takes itself seriously enough, but also pokes enough fun to keep things amusing. Even little blurbs given by the NPC can be quite hilarious, since you'll have villagers on a fiery planet of doom that say things like "help. I cannot defend myself" when they're being attacked by a bird. 

Game is transformed from its old progression system. The very early alpha / beta progression was a ten-tier grindfest. There are still old pages on the web that talk about that, and it's simply not the current state of the game.

If you have played Starbound or at least tried it when it first became available i.e. the Beta, you might be pleasantly/unpleasantly surprised to see what the game has become. 

I remember, when I first tried it, I was really pulled in to how unique and mysterious EVERY species felt. Finding ruins/settlements/enemy camps felt like an adventure, not only because of the npc encounter, be it combat or friendly, but because you had to try to piece together the cultural influences and specifics for each species. This, in my opinion, left the world up to a lot more interpretation. 

Now, this is simply what I miss, maybe influenced mainly by some form of nostalgia I feel that apart from mainly visual aspects and weapon styles, the once very unique species have blended together (apart from the lore, but not everybody reads everything).

However, I do still recommend the game, it is addicting and replayable, even more so if you prefer the game to as how it is now or simply didn't experience the mystique created by the unfinished world it once had.

Do not be fooled, it is not 2d space minecraft or a terraria/risk of rain 1 clone. It is a game that will hook you with at least one of it's many cool aspects, and if not, you can always play with friends and disregard the main story/gameplay as you mess around and pour acid on eachother.

Starbound has a lot of potential to it. The game has successfully held my interest for years, with a world as interesting and complex as this, it has every right to be a good game. It's story is very linear, which isn't necessarily a problem if done right, however Starbound does not do it right, and the story itself isn't very good either. Though, that's not why you'll play the game anyway. It draws a lot of influence from Terraria, which is definitely not a bad thing, though it focuses more on the building and exploration aspects. Unfortunately, Starbound suffers from "HORRIBLE EXECUTIVES" syndrome. The heads of Chucklefish were not paying their less experienced developers, which is a whole other can of worms, but when called out on this, their responce was to stop developing Starbound for some reason they said it was to help catch a "sexual predator", but this was timed very coincidentally right alongside the accusations gained traction. This is why I say it has POTENTIAL. The game is good in it's current state, but that's all, just good. It COULD be great, if Chucklefish would only keep developing it. However, all that has been about vanilla. If you are to get Starbound, download the mod "frackin universe" from the workshop, it fixes the story issues i mentioned earlier. The workshop is essentially where the community has been developing Starbound FOR Chucklefish. The universe of Starbound is very good on it's own, but with mods, it's phenomenal.
Very good game, No longer gets updated but the workshop has a lot of things to customize your experience with.

Starbound is a game most know about but most do not KNOW the game. Starbound means a lot for me. Charming, peaceful and engaging. Starbound is a great survival, adventure/exploration sandbox game with a simple, yet powerful optional main quest. The concept of having colonies on multiple planets in multiple galaxies is captivating, while still having a home setup on my starship is something I love. There is something for every type of survival/sandbox player in this game- building, farming, exploring, mining, pets, combat, boss fights, side-quests, space travel and more. I haven't even explored the countless mods yet. 

My only critique is the main quest line missions become a bit repetitive and tedious, but it doesn't take away from the game by any means.

The comparison that it's terraria in space holds pretty well, but I think it's unique enough to stand on its own.

It's less boss oriented and more sandbox. Instead of just one world you have virtually infinite planets that you can link together and teleport between, with your ship serving as an intermediate space which you can also expand and build on (although not to the same extent as the planets). If you find yourself visiting a planet frequently enough and you have the resources (and trust me, it's not cheap), you can even place a teleporter so you don't have to beam to your ship, although beware that you won't be able to remove it thereafter without destroying it.

That's not to say there are not bosses and interesting combat mechanics; there are. It's just not what you may be used to. For instance, weapons are either one-handed or two-handed, depending on whether they have a built-in secondary ability, so one-handed weapons tend to be more flexible, whereas two-handed weapons are generally more powerful. The ranged weapons use energy in much the same way as terraria's magic weapons use mana, but unlike terraria, pretty much all armor offers boosts to your energy capacity. 

Bosses are also different, but not so much in combat as in how you encounter them. Unlike terraria, you don't just summon a boss by using an item, but rather you must complete a sort of dungeon that resets if everyone in it dies, much like a party wipe in an instanced encounters in games like WoW. There will usually be a checkpoint before the boss though, so you can keep trying as long as you have resources to keep trying. (It's also easy enough to spawn in items if you get desperate, although obviously that's considered cheating. I may or may not have done this to get through my first encounters with bosses 2, 3 and 4, but in my defense I have a spinal cord injury so the fact I'm able to play at all is a testament to modern technology...)

All in all, whether you see this as a new twist on the general concept of terraria or a game of its own is irrelevant. It is a VERY good game and I've barely played anything else since I bought it. 9.8/10

Vibrant world, robust mechanics, and an OST with a strong case for the best I've ever heard.

Starbound captures better than any game I've played the grandeur and freedom of exploring space. A planet can be calm and serene, brimming with life, or intimidatingly inhospitable; each is a little different, and exploring them never gets old.

Fans of lore and stories will enjoy the thought put into each NPC race, fans of exploration will enjoy the different planet types and structures, fans of collecting will enjoy breaking and shelving everything in sight. There's farming, monster collecting (think pokemon), terraforming, space mech piloting, instrument playing, and so much more.

Mods (while some have not kept up with updates and are deprecated) can tweak gameplay or entirely rework the game's mechanics.

If the game looks appealing and you're worried about complaints--don't be. There's a mod for almost any problem you might have. Inventory too small? Mod for that. Crew experience underwhelming? Mod for that. Clothing system restrictive? Mod for that. Block/furniture recipes too hard to collect? Mod for that. You get my point. 
I think any real complaint would boil down to the ethics of the developer. Chucklefish has been embroiled in a pretty shady exploitation scandal regarding the development of this game. I can't tell you how to rationalize that one, but I will say that this is one of my favorite games ever, and I don't throw that distinction around.

The one thing that brings me back over and over to Starbound over other games is the atmosphere it creates. No other game captures the feeling of space quite like Starbound. Space, and the planets you discover in it, can feel peaceful and secluded (the soundtrack does wonders in this department).

I got really far in this game, like 70% of the way through, but then I got a new pc, and because of the way this game functions, I couldn't get my old world back, so I never finished it.

The game is very grindy, but it's not as fun as terraria grinding, which I why I didn't start a new world. I would have to re-grind through 20 hours of gameplay, and while the game was fun, it wasn't fun enough to make me want to redo all of that progress.

The problem is that while story progress is saved through your individual characters, the world's itself are all connected. Ex - playing on a new character and want to bring it to your other character's base planet? Just put the coordinates for that planet on your ship and you'll fly straight there. The only problem is that this means you can't transfer individual characters or worlds through pcs, so all my progress is stuck on my old DELL in the basement (OR, I'm just a dumbass who couldn't figure out how to transfer it).

The game is perfectly fine, a solid experience that slightly differs from terraria, but just remember to not change systems mid game like I did.

People get angry when this game is compared to Terraria, and vice versa. So that is exactly what I'm going to do. 
The reason people get angry is because it is like comparing Minecraft to Terraria, their only similarity is that they are games, and the up until recently novel voxel based environment system. 
Terraria is about boss battles, its how you progress. Starbound is about exploration. You will do a few boss battles, but they aren't the point of the game. 
Exploring new worlds gathering new materials, creating and finding new gear is the point. There is a real story, there are too many planets to explore. Each playthrough will be different based on what weapons you use or what things you find early. 
For Example, there are many types of trees. They can have dozens of log materials and many leaf materials. Finding a giant root tree early is very good. You can take its saplings and replant them on your farm world for an easy fiber supply for medical and rope usage. Having an abundance of it compleatly changes how you move around the world because you care far less about damage and are free to sling around the map like spiderman on grapple hook ropes.
Finding a good weapon you like with a good modifier you prefer also will change how you fight. Like spears, go for it, like comboing enemies to death with a broadsword, upgrade the one you have.
Another thing I like is that almost all the materials that you gather are useful throughout the whole game. You don't stop using copper, or coal, just find more uses for them. 
DL:DR Terraria in space with a focus on exploration and story.

This game, by itself, feels a bit soulless, (almost like Chucklefish fucked over its developers, oh wait...) but its modding community has made it really fleshed out. You're welcome to play the base game by itself but I strongly recommend playing it with mods. 

The one mod that really makes it feel like an actual game is Frackin Universe, which impliments much needed features and takes away from a lot of the bore. Others like Shellbound are nice too, specifically because I love the crab mech and the numerous amounts of weapons it adds. All of these mods and their dependencies are easily located in the steam workshop so feel free to try them them out. If you want to play the game with friends, just make sure they have the same mods as you do.

This game is a very addictive retro pixel 2d side-scroller. A lot of parallels you might see from other titles. 

The game looks like Terraria, all pixelated and the side scrolling 2d.
You can go from planet to planet, system to system. Just like No Man's Sky.
You can obtain a Mech that is just like one from Titanfall or a Gungdam. 
At the end of the game you can do these Vaults over and over and obtain cool treasure, started by obtaining a vault key. Sounding similar to Borderlands.
There's farming you can do which gives me Stardew Valley vibes.
You can create colony's by making homes for settlers to move in.

Honestly I recommend this game, it has a lot to offer and it is still being updated to this day. I come back from time to time to try out new things from recent updates. I'm happy I've had the chance to play this game and make it a part of my childhood throughout the years and up to now.

The mod community for this game is amazing too, there are an incredible number of mods with enough content they might as well be free DLC. I have been working my first vanilla playthrough still so havent tried any mods personally yet but already know a few I plan on trying for my second play through. Where similar retro 2D games have me debating if ill even finish them, Starbound manages to be one of those games where im already thinking of a second run.

This is the BEST sandbox I've ever played, I've played through the story and have gotten every achievement. If you're considering buying this game, go for it! It has a metric boat load of mods on the Workshop, you can even find mods outside that are just as easy to install like they are in the Workshop.
  As for the story, it has some real nice story telling, it does take time to get to each part, as you need to scan things to progress, but there are also side missions to allow you to get MORE things.
  There is one thing I like the most about this game, if you try to give yourself an item, but you miss spell it, or it isn't in the game, it gives you a Perfectly Generic Item, which can also be obtained after the main story to craft the best armor in the entire game.
  Overall, just play it, if you like 2D sandboxes like Terraria, you'll love starbound, I do recommend getting a mod from the Workshop that halves fall damage or removes it entirely, as the fall damage is too over the top, you can fall from a height equal to walking off your roof and you'll lose over 80% of your health

It could be better than Terraria if the devs were paid, the game could have been tremendous.
Sadly we're getting a game that isn't getting updates and has questionable optimization. Sucks that we're nearing perfection.

The beta was selling the game more than everything, now we have a forced linear story containing boring quests that ruin the replayability.

The game overall is great. Lots to do, lots to see. I have a few modest reservations about this game, but if you like terraria, I -highly- suggest this game. There's a ton of items, and instead of bosses, you get sort of 'story dungeons' that lead to bosses. The story is very 'get the 7 whatevers to access the door to defeat the cosmic baddy' Not terribly inventive, but honestly, the focus is the building anyway. And boy howdy, there are a LOT of items for building.

However, be warned, this game on -some systems- are awful for FPS. My home computer that is 8+ years old, runs like a dream, it's perfect. On my laptop from last year, garbage, like 6 FPS. I'm not sure how you could know if your system will or won't work, but you will know the moment you start a new game, well within steam's return policy.

My only gripe is that there isn't really a clear indication about how some things progress. For instance, A) you make different types of food to learn more food recipes, but that doesn't always apply to other things. It's not clear which do work like that and which don't B) To increase the amount of items you can print, you scan them, but not everything scanned can be printed but there's no indication on which can and can't. C) Some items you expect to find can only be purchased and nothing really tells you that. D) Alternatively, some items found used to have a use and now don't so they are pointless and nothing tells you that so you just hang on to them thinking it'll be relevant later.

This gripes are pretty minor after 275 hours of gameplay. I still highly suggest it.

I've thought long and hard about my review for this game because it presents me with something of a dilemma. 

On the one hand, it's a perfectly "nice" game with quaint graphics and a hint of nostalgia. The idea of being able to dig and build across a large and unusual galaxy is novel in its approach.

On the other hand though, the implementation is lacklustre. The combat mechanics are terrible and the penalty for death is absurdly high which makes it all the more irritating when you go up against a boss or visit a planet for the first time to discover just how under geared you are. 

The building system is unoriginal and uninspiring. Given that there are crafting stations and shops all over the place there is no incentive to invest any real time into building a base or even kitting out your ship and the grind for gathering materials is soul destroying. On many occasions I've had to stop playing because the boredom of having to search ANOTHER planet for whatever ore I'm grinding to move on to the next tier has become overwhelming.

The tier system itself is very poorly planned. Unlike Terraria ( a game which is often used as the benchmark for this type of game ) where the progression feels very smooth and the penalty for dying is not so significant, the space between the tiers in Starbound is way too large and requires far too much grinding.

The mech was again a nice idea but really poorly implemented. After hours of finding all of the blueprints to get the best available parts for my tier, only to be killed within seconds as soon as you progress is really frustrating. 

The TLDR: Starbound has some nice ideas which I truly wish the developers had managed to do something with, but sadly the implementation of these ideas is awful and after 70 hours of trying to find things to keep my interest, it's time to give up and move on to a game that's had more effort put in.

In a word, this game has [b]scope[/b].

Without any prior exposure, something that instantly struck me was just how big the world of [i]Starbound[/i] is. With little more than a couple of tools and the elements against me, there was never an end of things to discover, unlock, or create. The crafting mechanics lend themselves well to someone who never grew up playing Minecraft. Even in the early game, there are endless possibilities.

And it just grows from there. As you upgrade your character and ship, the planets and space available to explore stretch out indefinitely. Just when I thought I'd hit the game's ceiling, something new and vast would open up to reveal worlds without number. The universe is so big, I doubt I could ever truly witness all of the wonders the developers coded into existence. But I sure am going to have a lot of fun trying.

You'll definitely want to keep the game wiki close by. There's a lot to figure out on the fly. But on the whole, the game does a pretty decent job of walking you through the basics early on. There are an unlimited number of ways to approach the game and no set story you have to follow (though there is one contained in the core objectives, if you choose to follow it). Really, you can be and do whatever you want. Even the sky isn't a limit. 

You don't need to wait for a sale to add this to your collection. Get it now. You won't regret it.

Starbound holds a special place in my heart as a delightful pixelated gem. It's a game that I find myself revisiting time and again, especially when enjoying it alongside friends, resulting in countless hours of chill, fun gameplay. One aspect that captivates me immensely is its extraordinary soundtrack, which I believe stands among the very best in gaming history. It effortlessly immerses players in a boundless universe, where they can wander endlessly across diverse planets, each brimming with its own unique allure. Starbound 10/10. Novakid best race.

So poorly optimized, like really really poorly. I can run RDR2 nearly max without losing frames but can't even get this to run consistently for more than 15 seconds at a time. The movement is infuriating, and a lot of the "difficulty" is just waiting or taking your time.

Game was more fun back in the alpha days before they forced you to follow a rigid story / quest system just in order to progress, but the modding community is incredible and really makes the experience.

Played this back when it was in its early beta stages, the game had amazing potential, an infinite amount of worlds to build whatever your heart desired, and an amazing exploration system.
Then the game released and a lot of the potential wasn't there anymore, and a story mode was added that nobody asked for, and while not the worst, was horribly executed.

This game cant stand on its own without mods, and even then, the game has performance issues that mods cant fix. I use to be able to play this game perfectly fine on an old laptop until it was fully released, now I cant without the game freezing every time I pick up an item or interact with anything, and my current PC isn't weak at all and I still have these issues.

Combat is generic and basic, unless you get a overpowered weapon, a lot of fights are more tedious then fun, and there's barely any variety at all. All the weapons are generic sci-fi themed, with the melee weapons having the worse designs in my opinion. Which is upsetting considering back in beta, the weapons looked better, and there were unique racial weapons for each race. Why they removed these and replaced all of it with generic items that aren't pleasing to look at or use, I don't know.

Exploration starts off great, but slowly becomes very repetitive, and not in a good way. If you explored one type of world then you've explored all those types of worlds. The only unique things on these planets are the structures, and there's barely any variety at all. The terrain is too random too use a hover vehicle with since the mountains are either too high or there's way too many large openings in the ground for it to fall into and get stuck. The Mech is slow and bulky on ground it isn't worth using either. Running around normally is the only good way to explore, except the fact that this game has an unhealthy amount of enemies that spawn, especially at night, which makes exploring a planet incredibly annoying.

The building is, actually very fun, excluding mods, this is the one saving grace this game has honestly. Its not better then what Terraria has, but it comes close with its decorations and furniture.

This game lacks progression, its similar to Minecraft in the sense that you decide the goal and what to do. With the story being boring and extremely repetitive, and bounty hunting being the exact same pretty much, the only goals this game has is what you can come up with. You can easily ignore the story and bounty hunting entirely without any issues, especially if you already "beat" the game before, since the entire Outpost is unlocked with all the characters present with a new, fresh character, since the Outpost is a world file and is the same each time. Depending on who you are and how you enjoy games, this can either be a good thing or a bad thing depending on if you like making your own goals and progression, or if you'd rather have a set goal to work towards like in Terraria or other games similar.

The publisher of this game also has drama attached to them, screwing over people who helped work on the game and then proceeded to not credit or pay them for the time and effort spent. Nor keep the promise of hiring them afterwards, leaving these freelance devs to rot pretty much despite the promises that were made.

I'd only get this game if you wanna play with mods, I know I have a ton of hours on this game but a bulk of it is from beta and when the game didn't have this freezing issue. This game is only still alive thanks to its wonderful community. I don't enjoy the game stuttering and sending me off a ledge when I'm already halfway to the center of the planet.  Building and farming are cool but entirely unnecessary, at least for as far as I've gotten.  Someone else would enjoy this game a lot more than me.

My friend put it very aptly when he compared this game to diarrhea.

This game was supposed to be the successor to Terraria but failed in so many ways. 
The gameplay isn't satisfying and it's too convoluted for what it's supposed to be.

Enjoyed progression in the beginning, but the campaign and exploration are ultimately too formulaic and repetitive. Good variety of art assets and building materials, but everything is handed to you - no sense of challenge, achievement, or purpose. Generated NPC side quests seem to be exclusively escort and fetch quests, which feels like a deliberate insult.
Excellent game. A wide assortment of workshop mods also allows for high customization.

I'm a big fan of Terraria and Minecraft, so when i started looking for other games similar to them, I found Starbound. My crappy computer makes it run choppy most of the time, but i still enjoy it. I'm a bit of a nerd when space gets involved into something, so naturally I instantly fell in love with this game.

However, since it's still a beta, there a number of bugs that still need ironed out. The most annoying one would be that teleporting off the ship takes multiple tries.

All in all, I like it. It is my computer that doesn't.
(Edit)
Hooboy it's been years since I looked at this. Got a better PC, and the game has been out for several years. Still a favorite of mine, and it's even better with mods, naturally. If you already enjoy the game, I recommend you look into the vast list of mods, if you haven't already. By far the biggest and probably best would be Frackin' Universe, a complete overhaul and combination of mods, that usually plays nice with other mods.

Well, I first reviewed this game during alpha/beta development.   I reviewed it positively then, while A LOT of people were giving it negatives, forgettitng that "in development" partt of the equation.   

Now we're looking at a finished game, a release version.   It's fantastic.   After the release of 1.0, I more or less doubled my in-game hours from the beta.  This game is amazing, and a lot of fun.  

I don't want to spoil too much, as much of it is a game of discovery as well as creativity.   But it is everything thet devs said it would be.  And that alone is worth supporting.

EDIT:  Almost 10 years after my original review of this game, back then when it was still very much a WIP, I have to say I still think it is a fantastic production.  Some might compare it to if Terarria and No Man's Sky had a baby.   It really does offer endless fun, and the modability doesn't just add to that, but multiplies it.    

This game holds up well today as a great and fun experience for all.

TLDR; FUCK OFF - Just Another Grindfest, dont bother. A Terraria clone without the imagination. Ive tried to get into this game 3 times now, and I end up hating it each time. And I LOVED TERRARIA!

So many missing features that would be obvious in a sci-fi setting, or just in a game in general. ie. mini map, jump jets, better storage options (than effing chests), more vehicle and armour/weapon options (WTF is with medieval armour?!), no ability to break down tech or items, no creative ways of catching things, no good guide on crafting let alone anything else. And thats just off the top of my head... sooo many missed opportunities. PAINFUL death and item retrieval with very little tech to aid in exploration or finding stuff. 1/3 of money lost on death - just gone, no way of getting that back at all. So, I just die over and over, and havent bothered with the shops. I could sell all the shit I make, but why? 
Awkward movement that doesnt improve much, very little in the way of mini bosses. Same monsters on different planets in different solar systems - wtf?! Fuck - the more I think about this game the more I hate it.

The main story let us know that we are a universe guardian and we need to rescue the whole universe from a terrible creature. Aside from a sandbox, the game has its own loot system, side quests, a kind of parkour, mechs, and vehicles. A lot of different and unique places to explore, such as dungeons, catacombs, civilizations, research centers, tombs, challenge rooms, hostile and friendly spaceships, space stations, planets... A TON of items: melee/ranged weapons, shields, decorations, musical instruments, food, poke-balls, and many others. We can also have pets, our civilizations full of NPCs, and crew members for our own spaceship (that can be upgraded later).

At the beginning of the game, the interface is a bit awkward, but over time it becomes very intuitive. Your progress will be very slow too, but over time and upgrades, nothing will stop you from doing anything. The gameplay, once we repair our ship, will leave us free. From there we can loot all we can, make huge civilizations, complete side quests & the main story, build whatever we want, travel and meet new places and civilizations,  be hired for search and capture of criminals, or just stay on our spaceship and sort all the things we have obtained previously. There are also boss fights. If we get bored, we can put mods!

I recommend to play it on the easy difficulty since you don't lose items when you die, and you don't need to eat to stay alive. It can be very frustrating to lose a lot of things when it happens. And if that the case you can lose interest in this game.

[h1] Pros [/h1]

+ One of the best pixel 2D graphics.
+ Original and relaxing music that changes to intense if we meet a boss.
+ Our own spaceship (We can expand it and hire crew members).
+ 7 species to choice between (Your spaceship look and pet depends on what you've chosen).
+ Our own mech, which we can deploy whenever we want and use it to sabotage hostile spaceships.
+ An incredible amount of biomes.
+ A TON of items.
+ A massive arsenal, range, and melee. Each weapon has its elemental damage.
+ We can visit and make civilizations.
+ We can explore an infinite universe without limitations.
+ We can explore, fight and loot a lot of places, enemies and items.
+ We can catch the fauna inhabitants of the planet with poke-balls.
+ We can play music with a big variety of musical instruments.
+ We can make collections of bugs, pets, fishes, books, food, auction figures, and fossils.
+ We can play with our friends.
+ Fishing.
+ Ability to put mods.

[h1] Cons [/h1]

- Too much grind.
- There are no spaceship fights.
- Without friends, it's less playable, but you can still enjoy it.
- It can be too addictive.

[h1] Is it worth it [/h1]

As you can read above, this game has a huge content. We can start enjoying this game as soon as we have familiarized with UI and upgraded fair enough our multi-tool, and skills. After playing for about 10-15 hours, it will be much easier for us to fight, explore and do other things. At first, it is a bit difficult, but it is worth the time spent. So is worth it!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

A little bit like [b]Terraria[/b], but in space and some.

At first, Starbound seemed quite complicated (coming from Terraria, of course), but once I understood the mechanics, Starbound got more exciting down the road/travels. So not only can I go deeper into the planet *pause* "Wait, what?". Yeah, not only can I go deeper into one world, but I can also [u]go to other solar systems[/u] and dig in different planets for materials to my heart's content or colonize; possibilities are almost endless. 

Once you get your spaceship back up and running, you can farm to end-game equipment without progressing on the story; [spoiler]besides the quest to get your spaceship up and running again.[/spoiler] Pretty cool if you like to prep yourselves for the upcoming explorations and not have to farm for them later on; it makes things a lot easier.

It is highly recommended to all players! NPCs can become your companions under specific criteria, either with friends or playing solo, so you are never alone in Starbound (virtually). The Soundtrack is soothing while building a home/settlement, depending on the planet's condition.

There is more to cover, but enough with this review; you can get Starbound if you haven't and discover all the sweets this game offers. The possibilities are almost endless in Starbound.

This game is very good, but i hear people complaining about replayability...
And it's honestly true. While there are mods that can help with that, if you came here because you thought its similar to terraria, it'll be worth the money and fun, but not hit quite the same after a while.

A really fun game to be played either alone or with friends. The world is very huge, the activities to do is abundant, and the customization is interesting.

The downside is some worlds get very repetitive and its quite boring to see the same town in a different galaxy, or even similar critters in different biomes. It also can get pretty laggy sometimes, although my device is well above and beyond the system requirement, which I understand since maybe the developers consider this game a finished product and will never touch it again.

7.5/10, would recommend.

It's a bit like a reskinned terraria, which makes it pretty excellent. Everyone knows terraria, so I won't explain that. This just puts a space exploration spin on it where you can travel to a nearly infinite number of worlds to explore. My only objection is that the boss fights and story missions occur in specific levels that you load into. You can't alter those levels in any way. This does prevent cheesing the bosses, but I think it was more fun in terraria to organically encounter the boss areas/biomes, and sure, cheese the hell out of the fight if you wish to. This kind of makes it feel like two different games; the game in which you explore new planets and break/build to your hearts content, and then the game in which you play through story missions with the layout they give you and with the gear you've acquired.

[b]TLDR[/b]: the game had potential, but the end result is very lacking. Every element of the game is designed to steal your time, giving you an illusion that you have something to do, but you essentially stare at the screen holding one button waiting for something to happen. Some artworks are cool looking, but there are not that many of them and they start repeating very early into the game. 

With more than a hundred hours with this game - very little of it was actually worth the time spent. The overall experience is very shallow and extremely slow. People who compare it to Terraria clearly have never played Terraria, because Starbound is a shell of a game. I bought this game way back in early access and it still feels like an unfinished alpha version rather than a complete game. Initially I just wrote it off as "It's in early access still, devs will polish it up eventually", but after I decided to try it again much later - I was baffled at the complete lack of fun. Almost nothing changed from the alpha, and things that were added are on the same lacking level of polish as the elements that were not changed since alpha.

jUsT uSe MoDs - how about I get an actual game when I pay for it instead of an 'engine' to play mods on? The fact that so many people say that you need mods to play this game only reinforces the fact that the game itself is bad. Mods are supposed to enhance the game, not to make a game playable in the first place.

[b]Gameplay[/b] is extremely slow paced. There are no good movement options. You eventually get some movement techs and even a hoverbike, but they are still slow. That would not be a problem if the world was diverse, if there were things to find, places to explore. Alas, every planet is the same: same structures, same mobs, same terrain consisting of flat land and 1 or 2 mountains.

[b]Combat[/b]: before you get decent armor and weapons almost every mob removes half your health on hit, and even when you eventually upgrade - you have to go to more dangerous planets, where mobs remove half your health again. It is easy to stun and knockback them, which enforces a single viable playstyle: hit and run. There is no variety in weapons, and the amount of energy you have limits how fast you can kill any mob. stretching every fight into eternity.

There is a crapton of [b]downtime[/b]. Flying between planets take an extremely long time. Ship has to change orientation, play hyperspeed animation, and change orientation again. That amounts to 30 to 60 seconds of time where you can't do anything but decorate your ship or craft. Slow mining, aforementioned slow movement and lack of exploration variety makes the game 85% downtime where you do nothing or hold one button while moving or mining with nothing else happening.

[b]Inventory and hotbar[/b] are horrific. You cannot use items from inventory: you have to move item to your hotbar and use it. Very fun when you have 10 blueprints and you can't even tell which ones you already have. Hotbar has a very limited amount of slots, it is very far from inventory, and its slots are extremely small, turning inventory management into a nightmare.

[b]The story[/b] is terrible. Plot is meaningless, lazily written and terribly executed. [spoiler]Big Bad out of nowhere destroys the planet of the Big Good guys and you are the only survivor, then absolutely nothing happens until the very end where you teleport to the Big Bad and kill it. No flavor, no connection, no explanations for anything, no progression beyond "go collect these 15 unrelated things so you can activate this ancient teleport".[/spoiler] And of course, every story event has SLOW UNSKIPPABLE "CUTSCENE" WITH NO USEFUL INFORMATION IN IT. Cutscene in quotes because those are not even cutscenes, its just an image of an NPC sprite on a black background and nothing else happening, padding that downtime even more.

Developers keep adding 'new' systems, but they never expand on them, or even finish them.
[b]Inspect[/b]: adds absolutely nothing meaningful to the game. Basically an additional descriptor for some decorations that you have to spend extra time to access.
[b]Moons[/b]: I actually remember using wood and coal for ship in alpha version, and it was still more fun than moon fuel gathering. There's just one single line from the ship AI that "there are weird readings from every moon in the universe". Now every single moon has an unkillable 'ghost' that always chases you, giving you a limited time to collect fuel. Except you can collect some, return to the ship, and then do it again on the same moon. In short: they took out natural accumulation of fuel from mining\exploration and replaced it with a timesink to pad that playtime.
[b]Mercenaries[/b]: another flavor of companions, except with no bonuses. Straight downgrade.
[b]Mechas[/b]: literally a single layout for space battles and 3 enemy types that take 50 shots each to kill. No depth to the battles at all: you have tons of HP and every enemy drops a refill,  and it takes forever to go through enemies because weapons deal so little damage. A frustrating time sink.
[b]Archaeology[/b]: randomized collectathon. Kind of okay on paper, actually, just not my thing. More of that instead of downtime please.
[b]Hunger and cooking[/b]: you don't know how much hunger food restores or what bonus effect (if any) food grants. Way too many different recipes, feels more like another collectathon + time sink instead of something more engaging.
[b]Colony management[/b]: feels very undercooked. NPCs sometimes give quests and pay rent, but neither really matters.
[b]Random NPC quests[/b]: literaly just 3 quests: kill someone, escort someone, talk to someone. No variety, investment, or even good rewards. There is no reason to do any of it.
[b]Bounty Hunter[/b]: an abomination system stitched from the worst parts of every other mechanic. [strike]Random[/strike] Identical quests [strike]with detective elements[/strike] where you just spend several minutes to use 'inspect' on everything in the building and [strike]chases[/strike] 90% of travel downtime. And of course, the introduction has and unscippable cutscene with nothing of value in it.
[b]Missions[/b]: actually really good, in a way. Interesting to explore the first time, and has a metroidvania elements where certain areas are unreachable until you unlock better movement tech. Who would have thought that carefully designed content is almost always better than an ocean of randomly generated stuff. Still has its problems though: mobs are still overbeefed to hell, and there isn't really a reason to do each mission more than once (or twice if you want to reach every hidden chest and area).

[b]Optimisation[/b]. Given that 2D games do not need GPU or a lot of processing power - I hoped that at least I could play it on my laptop that only has i5 processor. Despite seemingly having nothing complex or demanding - the game still manages to stutter, lag, and have a lot of graphic artefacts while comparatively larger games run with no issues.

[b]In conclusion[/b]: my most optimistic take is that the game has lots of different systems, but none of them polished enough to be compelling in any major way. It feels like the developers were just going through a checklist of every know game-system, adding a barebones version of it, and then never addressing it ever again. On paper all of them add at least some flavor to the game overall, but none of the elements stand out and it turns the game as a whole into a bland mess. [i]Some[/i] things are [i]kind of[/i] neat, but not good enough to justify the time investment required for any of them.
The more pessimistic take is that the game is deliberately designed to pad the playtime as much as possible for every drop of low-quality content it has, with artwork candy and (long gone) hype as boosters.

EDIT November 8, 2020, 1199 HOURS LATER ACCORDING TO STEAM: Game still sucks. This review is very old, all the problems still exist or have been made worse. Chucklefish literally spat in the face of the community by removing CORE FEATURES on the 1.0 launch and then panicked and suddenly "were able" to re-add them when people started demanding refunds. Chucklefish told the roleplay community, to it's face, that it wasn't valid and that this was a survival game only... when survival coop still lags to hell and back and having three people on a planet will lag to hell and back without a bunch of mods and outside fixes. Hum...

Just get Terraria or Stardew Valley if you want a good, stable game with an actually decent story. Hell, Minecraft's got a better story then this. Have you seen the scrapped story pieces that they tossed during the beta because /roleplayers were using it as sources for developing deep and interesting cultures/? God FORBID interesting lore!! Oh, and let's not mention they scrapped individual intros in favor of whatever this horrid protectorate storyline. Yuck. There was so much potential that a large community loved, but Chucklefuck panicked because roleplayers weren't "playing the game right" and tossed it all away. (this isn't all just me assuming or making stuff up: there were full on-threads about this on the chucklefish forums where devs openly admitted they didn't want a community of roleplayers, it was a survival game, just try playing it right maybe???? ofc they deleted the evidence, chucklefish could neeevvverrrr do anything wrooonnggg... sigh. fun protip to future game devs: if literally, by poll, 80% of your community is there to do a certain playstyle, don't try to disable that playstyle in a mad panic bc it wasn't the game's original intent!!! Okay, listen up. I've been playing this game for a long time, and I've got to stay this:
The only reason, the only goddamn reason I played for so long was because of the communities I was in and the mods I could install. None of the core features do ANYTHING for me. Combat is boring- get rushed than quickly get killed, or have a good weapon and one-shot things. The healing system sucks. Oh, and did I mention ACID RAIN that gathers on the ground as POISON POOLS? I understand it is nice and colorful, but there's no meaning unless you toss mods or a nice roleplay community into the mix.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+You have different races and ships to choose from! Cool! Wow! Yeah, that died out quickly.
+Randomly generated planets(for the most part, see 'Cons' below) and enemies.
+Randomly generated.. weapons? O.. okay?

[h1]Neutrals[/h1]
=They screwed up the modding community and keep doing so EVERY. SINGLE. FUCKING. UPDATE. Oh, and they also screw over servers too. Hey, you want someone to make a gun that ignores hitboxes, destories blocks in a 10000 block radius instantly, and to place down unbreakable block while PREVENTING SERVERS FROM BANNING IPS? Yeah, yeah. We all see who's side you're on, Chucklefish. You're on the griefer's side.
=Griefers and hackers storm multiplayer. The only reason I'm not putting this as a con is because some of them can be kinda funny and actually interact with the community. Example: Some guy's placing unbreakable sewage blocks. Someone makes fun of his choice to put lava in the sewage after trapping someone. He, the nameless griefer, states in chat 'well let's make it a dirty job than!'.. and puts poison water instead. Actually was worth a laugh, despite the endless loop of dying.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
-Chucklefish empowers griefers and inhibits servers.
-Chucklefish keeps changing it's goddamn base code so that modders have to learn a new custom language and completely rework mods EVERY SINGLE UPDATE! May you rest in peace Starbound Save Editor. You were killed by the heartless chuckling fish.
-You need mods to customize your character beyond the base color. Without SBSE, you need to recolor EVERY SINGLE PIXEL using Starcheat or do another method- either way, it's tedious and annoying.
-Weapons can attack once every .0001 second and can do up to 7,000,000 damage per hit while ignoring armor. Oh, and did I mention Chucklefish got rid of the IP banning feature? 'Cause, they did. They screwed a lot of people over.
-Server stability. It used to crash every five minutes and they've managed to reduce that to every twenty minutes- oh, but it still lags like hell, chat will freeze up sometimes so it stops working until someone restarts the server, and you need grade-A computers to be able to stand being on a planet with ten people on it standing completely still. Mining? Ohohoh, the server can't stannnnddd that. Don't even THINK about survival co-op!
-Early access for over four years..? I mean, I bought it when it was cheap and a looong time ago, back when it was still a 'new' game, but.. I don't see any improvement? Okay, you screwed over the modding community a few times. Okay, you screwed over custom weapons more than once. Okay, you ruined server security. What's next? Are they going to take away the ability to ban people completely and force all the good roleplay servers to have to use whitelists to even stand ten minutes without a griefer attack..?
-All dungeons have a set layout. All 'Avian Temples' are the same Avian Temples as the last temple you saw. All 'Apex Labs' have the exact same buildings in varying states of decay. There is no creativity. There is no meaning.
-I seriously don't trust chucklefish. 

TL;DR: Don't get this. It's only gone downhill and Chucklefish is actively making it harder for the people who make the game fun to make the game fun. Just leave this sinking ship alone- it'll die out someday, just like The Stomping Land. It was fun while it lasted. /salutes

The first and easiest way to describe your experience is going to be a classic "Terraria in space" vibe. That's also not very descriptive so let me elaborate.

Both games, along with Minecraft and all that it inspired, have a resource based tier system of technology that the player has access to. In Starbound these tiers increase your raw power via stats but more importantly they expand the mechanics of the game, revealing more of the game in a measured way rather than simply dumping them into all the many fun systems in the game at once. This rocks and I hope you think so too after you give Starbound a shot.

Starbound is a fun and engaging game that offers a unique experience for players who enjoy exploration and adventure. The game takes place in a procedurally generated universe, offering endless possibilities for discovery and exploration. The game's graphics are bright and colourful, and the music is atmospheric and relaxing, adding to the overall immersive experience.

Players begin by choosing their race and character, then set out to explore the universe. Along the way, they encounter a variety of creatures, including friendly NPCs and dangerous monsters. Players must gather resources, build shelter, and craft weapons and tools to survive and progress through the game's many levels.

One of the most exciting aspects of Starbound is the ability to customise and personalise your gameplay experience. The game features a deep and detailed crafting system, allowing players to create unique items and structures to suit their needs and preferences.

TL;DR - Were I to purchase Starbound today? I would refund it.

Most of my in-game hours were spent a whole decade ago (or somewhere near that) when Starbound was in Early Access, 'Koala' experimental or whatever it was called.

With no rose-tinted glasses, I thought Starbound was an amazing game (for an Early Access title!) with a solid future ahead of itself! Gameplay needed a fair amount of polish - as befits an Early Access title - but the rock-solid foundations for an incredible sandbox game was set in stone; I could see myself sinking thousands of hours into Starbound!

...Come the combat update all those years ago (experimental 'Giraffe' build or something), all I could think was "Oh dear. Oh no." and on behalf of Starbounds' initial design philosophy, I felt an impending sense of doom at the direction Starbound suddenly shifted towards; from open sandbox to... linear story-based.

I ended up forgetting about Starbound until some time passed since its 1.0 release. Gave Starbound a shot, was total [REDACTED] and, frankly, confusing. 

Starbound was the game where I adopted the mantra of 'Never buy Early Access games'. Thank you for the lesson, Chucklefish!

Years after that, like the carcass of a whale at the bottom of the ocean, is where I found Starbound in my Steam Library. "Holy *(&# I forgot that I had forgotten about Starbound!" I thought to myself.

"With tempered expectations, I will give Starbound a try after all these years!"

And so I gave Starbound a whirl, and after a fresh installation... for 5 minutes I'm stuck trying to load the main menu? No problem, I'll just use Task Manager to close out the progr-- Oh! Hello Blue Screen of Death.

I do (another) clean installation... and once I'm in the game?

Oh dear. Oh no.

Entities sometimes freezing/stalling when they take damage? Doors still open and close on the same tick? Logs and crops from harvested trees and plants STILL falling/phasing through 1-3 tile thick floors? Moving platforms suddenly lose collision when they reverse direction, causing character to phase/fall through them? The game stutters as it tries to render 80+ dropped objects?

After all this time and Starbound still is a... buggy mess of a game? You're telling me my rig can run a cheese cannon in Skyrim on ultra settings, but my rig will struggle to run Starbound?

The art direction and music is still a solid 10/10, though. Starbound has a lot of love put into its visual design, animations, and the music... apparently that all comes to the detriment of almost every other aspect of Starbound.

Mods will not save this game for me. Maybe for you.

HOPEFULLY for you.
