Starbound is a 2D sandbox-style game that stands out from other games in the genre thanks to its unique features and immersive universe. Fans of sandbox games appreciate the freedom to explore and create in a virtual world, and Starbound delivers on that front with its vast universe filled with planets to discover, each with its own unique biomes, enemies, and treasures.

One of the game's most significant draws is its sci-fi setting, which sets it apart from other sandbox games like Minecraft and Terraria. The game's art style and soundtrack create a sense of wonder and adventure as players explore the unknown reaches of space. Fans of Starbound appreciate the game's immersive universe, customizable spaceship, and quest system, which provide a sense of purpose and direction for their exploration.

Players can gather resources, craft items, build structures, and engage in combat against various alien creatures, similar to other sandbox games like Terraria. However, Starbound also features two-dimensional side-scrolling action that gives the game a different feel from other sandbox games. Additionally, the game's boss battles provide a challenge for players to overcome as they progress through the game.

Starbound's customizable spaceship is another unique feature that sets it apart from other sandbox games. Players can use their ship to travel between planets and store their resources and items. Fans of sandbox games appreciate the ability to customize the game with mods to tailor the experience to their own preferences and playstyle.

In conclusion, Starbound is a must-play for fans of sandbox games or sci-fi settings. Its unique features, immersive universe, and quest system provide a sense of adventure and exploration that is hard to find in other games. Whether you're looking for a new sandbox game to sink hours into or just want to explore the universe and customize your spaceship, Starbound has something for everyone.

I really liked this game, but the developer's incompetence killed it. They were too busy not paying their teenage workers and making broken updates to fix the countless problems Starbound has, and now it's sadly been abandoned.

In order to fully enjoy this game past your first or second playthrough, you will need lots of mods and likely some friends to play with as well; and even then, you will mostly just be screwing around because the story mode is beyond fixable without a complete overhaul.

Anyway, I will probably still be playing this game in the future, because it is fun (with mods), but I just can't recommend it because of how unfinished it is. Also, the fact that it was made with unpaid """"volunteers"""" is pretty cringe.

And if you are wondering about my 493 hours of playtime, most of that is AFK time from when I used to leave games running constantly for some reason.

I amassed most of my hours in beta when it was just the gameplay loop and I quite liked it back then. 

Since then they changed the things that did work to the worse (such as reducing jump height but not changing the world gen to account for that, making exploration tedious) and added many more mechanics that don't really go anywhere, don't interact with other mechanics, and feel half-heartedly added.

The only real way to enjoy it nowadays is with intensive modding. If you're fine with that it can be fun, but at that point I'm not recommending Starbound anymore.

Another aspect that should be noted is the exploitation that got us Starbound in the first place. Passionate people with a love for the game worked (in some cases) hundreds of hours for no compensation except a potential future position which of course never came.
 
Be it a signed contract or not, it's massively unethical and this game does not deserve a recommendation, even if it were good, which it isn't.

EDIT: After a good few years since I've made this review, my opinion has changed slightly. I still recommend this game for its incredible sprites, music, and modding community, but on its own, Starbound is quite hollow. It's story cries out like a feeble whimper in the vast cosmos this game offers, yet somehow that vastness possesses little to no unique content on it's own. If you like this game and want to buy it, more power to you, I loved it and still play it on occasion, but know that any playthroughs after your first one will feel boring. The Workshop is Starbound's saving grace, please be sure to check it out.

Starbound feels like the original release of No Man's Sky but in the format of Terraria. There's a lot of superficial variety, but no depth. Building a base on a planet is discouraged since you would have to travel back to it to do anything, and you can just put crafting stations on your ship instead. Once you get a mech, exploration and mining become easy and boring. Almost all the boss battles take place in immutable, handcrafted worlds, disconnected from the rest of the universe. I kind of regret playing through the whole game.

I've played this game for nearly 1,700 hours, by far the most time of any game i have on steam, i love this game and have been with it since it was in early alpha, got to watch it grow and blossom into the beautiful thing it is today, this is a game designed to cater to one's joys, fun storyline that intermingles with the main gameplay nicely, plenty of fighting, mining, farming, exploring, decorating, fishing, modular mech design, space combat/travel, a bounty system, and so much of it is procedurally generated that you'll basically never run out of new situations to be in, while by default the different races are not much different apart from aesthetics, this game was designed to be so easily modded, that if you feel your world in this game is missing something, you can either find it, or even make it yourself if you so choose! with a lively and robust modding community already around, new and unique races, weapons, decorations, biomes, ect added frequently to the workshop, you'll never truly have to worry about running out of new things to explore. this is a game that will easily last you for months at least, most likely years! even if you are someone like me who quickly gets tired once they learn the ins and outs of some game types, this game is well worth your money. 

if you'd like some comparisons to understand it better, i'd say it is similar to terraria, in having numerous items and gadgets to find and use, but also like minecraft in that, while it does have an "end goal", comparable to terraria's moon lord, the real draw is the gameplay itself, the weapon types may not strictly be as diverse as terraria, but it's a lot more diverse than minecraft (a lot of weapons are randomly generated, but i am mostly referring to weapon types here), all in all, i'd say that this game is a cross between the two, with aspects of the refining and progression you could expect of terraria, mixed with the endless world exploration and fun hobbies available in minecraft, i hope this explanation helps some of you out there, have fun!

If you're new into this, think of "No Man's Sky" if it was "Man's Sky". 
(Pun intended: No Man's Sky became a pretty fine game during the years.)

Think of a space dungeon asteroid adventure survival mining farming cooking building exploring discovering looting shooting pixel sidescroller with very minimalistic core RPG elements where your equipment develops and you level up as yourself playing the game with more skill. All of these with simple game mechanics where the game interface doesn't stand between you and the game world.

This little gem of a game delivers with ease that many other open-world games claim (or even boast) to have but fail to deliver, some of them miserably. For sure, creating an open-world game with an ample of interesting content of many layers like an onion is not an easy task. Well, here you can even drill down to the liquid core of the planet if you wish so. As a matter of fact, in weeks you can remove the outer hard dirt / stone layer of the whole planet, leaving the liquid core only. 

Want to create a space station? Any day. Build a crew of space chicken or feudalist robots? Of course. Digging through rocks made of flesh with a mining mech? Naturally. Assassinate a UFO penguin dictator? Surely.

I haven't even scratched the surface yet.

This game surprised me, the good way. Absolutely recommended.

[h1]Starbound: A Cosmic Adventure[/h1]

[b]Starbound[/b] is a game that captures the essence of exploration and adventure, as vast as the cosmos itself! As a Decepticon who has travelled the universe and seen its wonders, I must say that this game has impressed me.

The game's pixel art graphics are reminiscent of the G1 Transformers show, taking me back to the time when I was battling Optimus Prime and the Autobots. The soundtrack is also noteworthy, it takes me to a time when Soundwave was a mere cassette player.

In Starbound, you play as a space explorer who has crash-landed on a mysterious planet. From there, you'll need to gather resources, build a base, and explore the vast universe. The game has an extensive crafting system that allows you to create everything from weapons to spaceships. The ability to travel from one planet to another is as exhilarating as the first time I transformed into my jet form and flew.

The game also has multiplayer mode which allows me to team up with my fellow Decepticons, Ramjet, Thrust, and Skywarp, to explore the universe together.

Overall, Starbound is a game that I would highly recommend to anyone who loves adventure and exploration. I give it a Starscream 8/10. And if you haven't played it yet, do it.

Very fun game, don't treat it like a terraria rip off, for the games play quite differently. Starbound does struggle with far less replayability due to having a story. While the game is pretty dead update wise, it still has an active and strong modding community which has given the game 100s of hours of more content to enjoy.

Just for positive comment (I'm going to remake my reviews, but not now). It's the best sandbox game where your do anything what you want to do. Build farms, hunt for treasures and bounty, build colonies, trade, create your own worlds and dig to planet core.

[b]What I think about â€œStarboundâ€, my favorite space-themed survival game about befriending other species to defeat an evil planet-sized octopus.[/b]

Before you get the game, Starbound hasnâ€™t been updated in a long time so it might lag at some parts. When I got my new computer and put Starbound onto my drive to move it onto there, some things slightly broke. The game still worked, but the screen size was off and the resolution was blurry. While fixable, glitches like this could come on newer computers since the game isnâ€™t updated anymore. I thankfully got my old user fixed, and itâ€™s cool to see how I left my original world. Some other features can be inconsistent, such as not being able to aim your sword while being able to freely aim spears. Even with the game being discontinued for a while, Starbound holds up pretty well and is still super fun. The game by itself feels like a complete package, and it took me 75 hours to beat the final boss!

While Starbound might seem like a survival game, after the first planet Starbound instantly turns into a 2D exploration/quest game. The game isn't easy, but your ship has everything you need and you don't need to find food that often when you can fill up your inventory by purchasing food from stores. Some people might like the easier survival, and after getting highly protective armor and gaining all the unique blocks you're free to build whatever you want without having to find food or worry about losing much. Platforming around unknown planets while avoiding monsters can still be difficult, though!

Starbound's exploration is super enjoyable, and none of the planets feel empty compared to other space games. The first time you play the game is when the exploration is the most overwhelming. You start off the game in your ship, which is broken down, and you have to find a way to repair it. I wonâ€™t spoil too much, but the goal is to get enough resources to fly to other planets and explore each raceâ€™s village, eventually unlocking the villageâ€™s boss. There are 8 bosses in total and each one can be replayed at any time. The first ones, though, are super hard! 

The exploration, like I said, is very well-made with each planet having many secrets. While planets can get same-y without mods, you can still find a giant castle on a desert planet, having to parkour over broken bridges, or a lava-themed dojo where you have to turn into a ball to sneak past enemies. I still remember going to a giant volcanic castle and fighting off a giant 100-eyed miniboss bird. I eventually got it to low enough health, before finally throwing a â€œcapture podâ€ to lock it inside forever. Just in case, I kept the pod in a highly secured metal locker... it was a nice one, though!

A lot of people advise downloading mods to make the game better, but I think that the first time you play Starbound you should play it without mods. The game is charming enough on its own and the normal story isnâ€™t bad- it just slows things down. Because of this, the story is more of something you should only play through once. Actually, once you finish the game there are still multiple secret quests to discover. After completing the main story, you can adventure to different portal gates and defeat the bosses in them before they close forever. For me it felt really cool going into the short metroidvania-styled levels and defeating the epic randomized bosses, then jumping out before everything inside disappears.


I think Starbound is one of the best space games in terms of space/planet exploration. The game is made on a super big scale, and after you complete it the game definitely â€œmakes an impact.â€ Even though the game doesnâ€™t fully expand on the survival part after the beginning, and instead tries to become an exploration game near the end, there are still a lot of fun things to find. I might be biased because of how much fun adventures I got from it, I would give this game a 9/10!

(9/10) -Nick29Nick92

I really wanted to love this game, and after reading a review that stated "This game moves like an old grandpa" I still went ahead and played it anyways, I should've listened to the review. I bought this game thinking it was the ultimate 3rd person 2D space game to find that every planet has pretty much the same enemies and dungeons with different looks and levels of difficulty, every specific item you need will take an hour or several just to find/get, and the boss gameplay is pretty predictable after the first 2 or 3 times (sometimes first go) facing them. The last boss made every mission seem worth while but once your back on the ship you get that feeling that this could have been better  as a short film or animation than 54 or so hours wasted away on an experience easily satisfied with Terraria or even Minecraft to be honest. I have no hate towards this game, and I don't want the creators of this game to read this and think "wow this guy thinks I wasted all my time and sweat over this" for a 3rd person 2D space game to really be great, it would need to have a huge amount of data with a higher processing power needed than most computers use for games. I'm going to close this review with saying this game was a nice try, a beautiful nice try, the artwork of the game is aesthetically intriguing and full of wonderful aw, which was probably the one reason I wanted to keep playing and save the universe. Peace.

After just 4 hours i can tell this game is fantastic.
For years i wanted to play this but being a PC game only i had to wait to get it.
I love dying, that my favourite part of this game, aside from the beautiful graphics of the game and the depth of potential it holds.
i like getting far into a dungeon/cave system and dying from falling/coconut turnips/snapping hair girls/giant chameleons, i also like dying by a surrounding swarm of bats every few minutes too.
i also like dying because of confusing janky WASD controls. my PC is literally screaming controller support at me.
I totally understand why people love playing video games with a CV and cover letter style game-pad, it makes the experience of gaming so much more real and easy to grasp.
I highly recommend this game if you love getting stressed out/disappointed/frustrated and not progressing in games, but also love pixel art and the attention to detail.

Another thing i thought was really good was the size of the font, and the speed of the dialogue, i have no idea what is happening with the main story because the text is so small and by the time i have made out the first few words it moves on to the next set of dialogue, further more its a nice touch that you can't enlarge the text or have a "click" or "tap to continue" the dialogue function. 
The inventory menu is very small as well which is pretty cool because i hate looking at my inventory to see what items i have.
Another thing that makes this game great is its abundance of weapons and armour. I got some armour right at the start that i still have now. i haven't found any more yet but i'm sure if i die enough ill find some eventually.

Overall i give this game a 10/10. It lives up to expectations and even though i got it in the sale i would have bought this game for full price. It rightfully deserves the overwhelming positive reviews. A true masterpiece.

If i manage to get my ship repaired and can progress further in the story ill update this review with other things i love about this game.

Overall this game is just amazing. I give it a strong 10/10!

Starbound is one of those games whose base content is not the greatest, but whose modding community more than makes up for it. Seriously. Starbound mods are some of the most impressive, thorough, and detailed works that I've ever seen throughout my gaming experience. You get new spaceships, new planets, new structures, new races (playable or not), QoL changes to vanilla content, and even near-complete overhauls of the game's mechanics and storyline. Combine that with the expansive space sandbox/RPG/whatever that Starbound is, and you have a game that will suck you into its inexplicably fun and sometimes immersive gameplay.

After years of maintaining a Negative Review for Starbound due to technicalities here's what I got to provide for the game as a whole. Now with over a thousand hours spent in-game.

Is it worth the cost?
YES - You can easily get plenty of enjoyable time and adventures out of it this title.

Do you need mods to do it?
YES & NO - Frackinuniverse is probably the #1 way to multiply the content and enjoyable bits to it.

Is Multiplayer easily taken advantage of?
Absolutely is, anyone can go into singleplayer and /admin in a bunch of bs and destroy your content if you are not playing whitelist. Feature that was promised in early alpha never made it in requiring server-side files for a character.

Does Chucklefish care about it's community?
-They were banning people asking about promised features very early after their "Official Release"
-If they like you yes they can be helpful
-They could potentially release a big update destroying the core of the game -AGAIN- but not lately.

Starbound is a sprawling, imaginative space adventure that leaves players with endless possibilities and an overwhelming sense of wonder. From the moment you're dropped onto an alien planet, the sheer scope of the game is evident, and the sense of discovery never fades.

The pixel art visuals are charming and incredibly detailed, and the soundtrack sets the perfect tone for your journey through the universe. The gameplay itself is a seamless blend of exploration, combat, and crafting, allowing you to build everything from humble huts to sprawling space stations.

What really sets Starbound apart, though, is its boundless sense of creativity. With nearly infinite procedurally generated planets to explore, each with its own unique flora and fauna, there's always something new to discover. The sheer variety of weapons, gear, and items to find and create is staggering, and the game encourages experimentation and exploration in ways few other titles can match.

Despite its depth and complexity, Starbound manages to strike a perfect balance between accessibility and challenge. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or a newcomer to the genre, there's something here for everyone. Overall, Starbound is an absolute masterpiece of a game, and one that every fan of sci-fi and adventure should experience.

Game has been abandoned, the base story is awful, and they scammed a bunch of naive devs. (Including figures such as Toby Fox.)

This game is a very badly put together mess of stories that don't really feel rewarding, and the variety of dungeons/planets is not good. The only really decent part about the base game is the soundtrack and some of the unique uncraftable weapons. (That the craftable Violium Broadsword can outperform)

Alongside all of that, the Beta was way better. It did not have a railroading story, the planets were more diverse, and there was even more types of weapons. The Beta felt more like a fun sandboxy game you can break. You need to download a mod in the current state of the game just to get similar movement capabilities to the Beta.

Speaking of which, this game has some amazing modding potential. There is basically a mod for everything you can think of. I won't list them because you can just take a look at the workshop and see for yourself.

Overall, the base game is a 2/10, with mods it can easily be a 10/10. The only thing saving it is said modding community and Steam's feature to play older versions of the game. I would get it on sale for as cheap as possible.

I enjoyed playing the game back in the day. Unfortunately, no new updates for the past 4 years. According to some posts and comments I saw, the argument is that the game is "finished", which is obviously not true. Endgame content is kind of lacking, the sandbox is really nice along with building options but could use some more stuff to actually do. Performance issues make me not want to play the game for several years. My general feel about the state of Starbound is that it *could've* been something truly amazing, but instead it has been completely abandoned by the devs.
Yes

Unfortunately, Stardbound falls short in many areas, making it a disappointing experience for players looking for a deep and engaging exploration game. While the game initially draws you in with its colorful graphics and unique setting, it quickly becomes apparent that there's not much substance to the game.

One of the biggest issues with Stardbound is its lackluster storyline. The main questline is short and uninspiring, offering little incentive to keep playing once it's completed. Additionally, the game's world feels empty and lifeless after about 10 hours of gameplay, leaving players with little reason to explore further.

Another major disappointment with Stardbound is the lack of good mods available. While some mods do exist, they are often buggy or poorly designed, and the game's community is not as active as it could be.

Overall, Stardbound has the potential to be a great game, but it falls short in too many areas to be truly enjoyable. We would like to ask the developer to consider adding new additions or DLC to the game, to help keep the world feeling fresh and engaging for players. Until then, we cannot recommend Stardbound as a must-play exploration game.

What a gem! Starbound has an addictive game play loop. Starbound has exploration, inventory management, base building, decorating, farming, crafting, combat, and MORE. All of the mechanics interplay very well, culminating in a satisfying and intrinsically enjoyable sense of play and progression. To the degree you allow space in your heart, the game will put a system there to facilitate your imagination. Mainly through variety and challenge.

It isn't perfect and becomes easy pretty quickly. It is also not super original and could be expanded on massively. For a 2d space game it is well worth a try, Just make sure to have something playing in the background to keep a steady state of flow.
This is a great game.

Just not good. For the first few hours it's a blast, going through the first couple missions and exploring some of what the game has to offer. By the third mission, it's just tedious and nothing else. A lot of games have a grind as part of the game, and that's okay, but with Starbound, grinding IS the game. I've found myself spending little to no time on missions and story compared to just pressing my mouse down looking for this one ore that only ever spawns 6000 blocks from the surface. Even by then the missions aren't great, the only way I could find to even beat a boss was by doing some completely unrelated sidequest to get some stupid item that made the boss's quite literally unavoidable homing attack that does worth half of your hp in damage even SLIGHTLY tolerable. Half of the enemy AI is just either actual aimbot or a dumb fast creature with a large hitbox that does 400 damage and instakills you. I've beaten the game once, I'm trying a second playthough, but if you REALLY want to play Starbound: just play modded Terraria instead. Even on easy mode, this game is a literal nightmare.
Definitely would recommend if you like the general image this game gives you.

Starbound is a rather straightforward and simple game that doesn't particularly have any idea what it wants to be. Although it seems to and was initially a sandbox exploration game, its story mode is definitely a scuffed and forced addition. I'd say that you can enjoy base Starbound and not get bored by the repetition through at least one playthrough.

Though the game may be abandoned by its developers, the community is still going quite strong in both terms of the fanart and modding community. With the supplementation and addition of community made mods, extra depth and polish can be seemlessly added into the game to support vanilla Starbound's mediocre content.

The soundtrack is an absolute godsend though and is one of the most memorable and unique things about the game.

TL:DR - It's like Skyrim, but instead, the parent company doesn't milk it and decided to let it rot and suffer in the dark instead.

Overall, I'd say its an okay game at least and pretty good when modded.

Starbound is an excellent and relaxing exploration and building sim in the same vein as Terraria or Minecraft, in an infinite procedural universe. 

It has much the same vibe as Stardew Valley in the sense that there is no absolute requirement to do anything in any particular order, and you are completely free to ignore saving the galaxy in favor of building that cottage with the secret genetics lab underneath on that volcanic island in the middle of an ocean of lava that you've always wanted. The tech tree, types of building materials, and amounts of gear are surprisingly robust, and the planets that can be explored (while predictable once you've seen all of the types) are filled with a multitude of biomes, creatures, and gear to better murderitize (murderatize?) said creatures with.

All in all, the vanilla game can give you MANY hours of fun, and the mods make that fun essentially endless. I would heartily recommend this at full price, on sale, or otherwise stolen from or manipulated out of your coworkers or friends. Now get out of here. I have a Hylotl adventurer to get killed.

(Disclaimer: The author of this review does not condone stealing or manipulation in any form. Even in the case of this game.)

One might think at first glace: "Terraria in space" which, to be fair, is not totally wrong, but with a few mods such as Frackin Universe and Arcana, this game can be turned into quite the expansive and complex crafting and automation survival sim approaching Factorio levels of progression layering. On top of that the game's got a decent amount of personality for a procedurally generated survival craft. It does however feel like the ages are catching up with it. There's some decent amount of issues in the way of jankiness, performance and glitches. A planet's blocks are not generated off world. Which heavily limits what is supposed to be an exploration based game to more of a 'find a planet and settle' game. Because if you decide to automate a planet and then go do something somewhere else, everything is put on pause on said automated planet. Your ship's not really an option either as there's various memory leak issues with storing, moving and creating blocks on the ship. Make sure you don't automate too much though because with that, comes inevitable performance issues even on top end PCs, I suspect the game is quite CPU bound which is not uncommon for older variations of these types of games. But I can't say for sure as I've not done the testing. If you're able to get past these issues, who for the most of your playtime will disappear in the background, you've got yourself a pretty damn addicting and genuinely complex survival sim that's worth the very little cost of entry.

Starbound is fantastic. I can't put into words how brilliant this game is, so I'll just list a few things you can do to see if any of it catches your interest; I play with Frackin' Universe among a handful of other mods. 

- Explore an unending, procedural generated universe with dozens of planet types, and even more biomes within them. 
- Capture critters and beasts a-la pokemon, by throwing capture-pods at them once weakened
- Build a ship and recruit a crew, designed as per your own imagination
- Start a farm, build some houses, make a colony and collect income from your rentoids; who may have cool info or jobs for you
- hook up an electrical system that automates all the tedious crafting and smelting for you
- Build and customize your own, space-worthy mech for zero-gravity salvage efforts, or for storming a ship's defenses before boarding
- Get into archaeolgy and dig up bones of extinct alien creatures for display
- Admire the Beautiful pixel art design on both the environment and items, with very expressive lighting and particle effects.
- Explore the random universe and find weird settlements, dungeons, and items - be they a funky hat or a sunkiller laser
- Import your own MIDI files so that you can play the better call saul theme song on ANY instrument in game
- Easily do all of the above with friends, because multiplayer doesnt need your own dedicated, paid server.

This isn't even scratching the surface of what's available with just a little bit of modding, and at 16.99: Canadian it's an absolute steal. Seriously. Play this game, build a baller ship, then play "The Middle" by Jimmy Eat World on your Ocarina overlooking the cosmos, then come back to thank me.

I definitely recommend this game to others!! Not only is it very immersive and creative, but it's one of the best crafting games out there. If you adore crafting and creating dream homes like me, then you'll love this one. It also has many cosmetics to dress your character in. The only parts of the game I personally don't care for are the missions and the limited character customization you have in the beginning. Besides its challenges with planet environments, you truly get to roam around the universe and make it your own.

Edit: For the past month or so, I have been using the FU mod and it has increased my enjoyment of the game immensely! Compared to the vanilla version, FU feels like a much more complete version of the game, and it adds many additional elements and new items. The storyline quests are more or less the same, but they have added more dungeons and special quests to do. The research part can be tricky and bothersome, especially in the beginning, but I believe most of the perks outweigh this con.

Took them a year to add "bounties" which are just the already existing quests but you have to go to a different planet for them, and a small amount of useless crap.

Other than that the game just isn't fun at all in the first place, poorly designed and has a badly written story involving you being 'space Jesus', 8 crappy missions and with each their own god awful boring bosses all crammed down your throat, and the combat makes it even more boring.

And even if their wasn't a badly written story with terrible missions and awful bosses forced up my anus along with terrible combat there still wouldn't be anything to do anyways, boring and repetitive exploration is all there is otherwise.

Starbound is an amazing game, easily one of my favorites to date. What else need I say? Every planet is different, every enemy is unique, every weapon is special! Even just the vanilla game is a treat to play! There's no need to follow the story if you wanna just play and do what you want! Speaking of the story, while it is fairly basic and takes a fair bit of time to complete, it's still an interesting one that includes elements of prophecy, god-like beings, and a sense of scale amongst the science fiction!

The gameplay is simple enough to where anyone and everyone can play, yet complex enough for players to do some really cool and interesting things in combat! You can wield an assault rifle that shoots grenades like the Pulse Rifle of Dead Space 2, or you can dual-wield two machine pistols and play like you're in Last Action Hero!

And don't even get me started on the customization. While it may first seem like there's not much in customization, that's just to start your characters off. You can wear tribalistic attire from the Florans' fashion shops and pretend you live in a native tribe millennia before space travel, or you can dress up like Starfleet with the Apex's clothing and set out to explore the infinite universe!

But wait! There's more!

If your vanilla experience is getting too basic for you, hop onto the Workshop and download some mods! House of Ashes, Frackin' Universe, there's no end to the mods! Tired of using a basic pistol? Grab the Dead Space mod and get yourself a freaking Plasma Cutter! Want a mod with a new race and interesting aesthetic? Download the House of Ashes/Shadow Expansion mod and follow the voices that lead you to Shape and your final peace!

All-in-all, Starbound is a must-play for anyone who likes survival, sci-fi, customization, and moddability! I give this game an overall rank of a solid 10/10!

Starbound might possibly the best pile of broken dreams and wasted potential I've ever had the pleasure of enjoying. The graphics are immensely charming, most of the music is some of the grandest, relaxing, and comforting, orchestration I've heard out of a video game, and the gameplay is fun, familiar, and easy to get used to, albeit somewhat clunky here and there.

And it breaks my heart that the developers have dropped the ball so hard.

There's a major lack of biome diversity for what should be an expansive alien universe, the races in the game feel surprisingly one-note and shallow, the code is horribly optimized, and the story is some of the worst jumble of generic, shoehorned, railroading afterthought I've had to suffer because of how boring it is, as well as for the fact that it actively discourages exploration and allowing the player to figure things out at their own pace. It's okay for a first playthrough, if a bit annoying, but there is no nuance, no attachment to most of the characters, and the gravity of the overarching narrative holds zero emotional impact, making it utterly worthless to bother with more than once.

That said, the modding community is very much active, very much alive, and they are the blood and soul that keeps the abandoned heart of this game beating. There are so many mods that expand features, add new alien races to play as, new biomes and worlds, new mechanics, materials, gameplay styles, and anything else you can think of. These people who volunteer their free time to fix the things left broken and unfinished in Starbound are the biggest reason why I can feel comfortable recommending this game to anyone.

Edit:
I have grown to enjoy the game a lot more overtime, largely in thanks to mods. Sadly though, everything in my original review still holds true. So the vanilla game is still a do not recommend from me, but the massive modding community makes up for the short comings that originally caused me to leave a negative review.

Original Review:
I enjoyed this game back when my friends and I played it in 2014. But as it is now, I hate it.

-There really needs to be one more difficulty setting, between casual and survival. I don't mind, and in fact enjoy, having the need for food. But I absolutely loathe dropping items on death, especially when that can include key quest items.
-The movement feels extremely slippery. The difference of 0.05 sec on a key-hold can be the difference between taking a small step and throwing yourself off a cliff to your death. This is only worsened by the abundance of deep pits both above and below ground.
-The hotbar feels extremely restrictive in comparison with other similar games. (apparently there is a second page to the hotbar accessed by pressing 'x', but of course the game fails to mention this at any point.)
-The intro feels like it skips explaining a lot. You learn to dig, you learn to fight, but not to craft. No explanation for hunger is given until you are already near starvation.
-And you are almost immediately told to dig to the center of a planet after having just touched down for the first time. Intro quests should aid the player in learning the game before throwing something that ambitious at them. (Edit: This doesn't really apply anymore since they added the Poptop Mother's mine to the starting world.)

tl:dr - If you like terraria, get starbound
Starbound is a sandbox adventure game in the same vein as terraria, however not just in space but also with a full story. The game has a more piano and soft soundtrack compared to terraria and has many different components when it comes to mining, interacting, the works. However this game is still largely a lot of fun to play and mess around with, especially with mods like the saturnians (moth mod) or Frackin' Universe. Even without the mods, the base game still has a lot to add to it which helps improve the game even more, if you like terraria get this game.
Good stuff

Final product has fallen short of what was promised. The vision was not realized and was either dialed back, lost, or changed somewhere along the way. There are some good systems here, and i'm sure mods fix a ton of the shortcomings, but I just went back to other games instead of spending my time finding a perfect combination of mods. Instead of searching through endless planets, settling on the cool ones, clearing content... you end up picking one to progress your story, playing a bit with all the systems, and having a lackluster single player experience even while playing multiplayer. I've been wary of Chucklefish since this game and they have yet to impress me. There are other games your time will be spent with, and looking at reviews you will see which one I am talking about right away, and they are right.

Me being wary of Chucklefish since this project has proven true. Wargroove was mediocre. Pathway was so bad it's been free repeatedly. Starmancer has barely seen work done on it since I picked it up. I don't actually even buy these games for the most part, they just end up included in Humble Bundle and I give them a go, and am not impressed again. I grabbed Starmancer because the trailer made it look a lot more done than it actually was. Careful with buying Chucklefish stuff.

Sad to see a project they were so passionate about fall short. This was my "No Man's Sky" failure.

Starbound is the casual version of Terraria and the sci-fi version of Minecraft. Highly recommended for anyone who thinks both of those ideas are good.

[DISCLAIMER: lots of comparisions to minecraft and terraria]
If Minecraft is about building and Terraria is about fighting, Starbound is fundamentally about exploration.
Building is relaxing like it isn't in Terraria, but block variety isn't restricted like in Minecraft.
Progression is ignoreable like it isn't in Terraria, but dungeons aren't an afterthought like in Minecraft.
Starbound also has good worldbuilding and lore, and the character species options add a lot of roleplay potential.
The multiplayer experience is also really good. If you can play this game with your friends, you should.

[h1]THE TRUTH ABOUT STARBOUND[/h1]

I decided I would make a full review of Starbound because I am so incredibly sick of my friends summarizing Starbound as just worse Terraria. If you are one of these people, [b]this is the truth about Starbound, good and bad.[/b]

You will often see people compare this game to Terraria and concept wise, Starbound is the winner. It is basically if Terraria had a never ending universe that you can traverse with thousands of diverse planets with their own creatures, gravitational pulls, weather patterns, cores, bosses, and cities.

[h1]But, Starbound is more complicated than that.[/h1]

[b]Starbound is abandoned by their developers.[/b] The company that made the game, Chucklefish, stopped updating the game because they had some controversy regarding exploiting some of their unpaid workers. I am not thoroughly educated on what exactly happened, but as soon as those accusations came out Chucklefish wouldn't touch this game with a ten foot pole. 

[b]The game is incomplete.[/b] They were going to add more depth to the game and were updating it regularly before this controversy. [b]The main story line is EXTREMELY repetitive.[/b] You go to a town on a specific planet, scan the terrain in search of information regarding the race in the town you are visiting. Then you go and fight a boss and rinse and repeat about ten times. For some reason one of the races don't even get a boss or a part in the story, those are the Novakid. There is simply not enough to do in the base game. There aren't enough bosses, the weapons are boring, quests in the game are often just crafting an item or helping an NPC make it through a dangerous area. [b]None of these things got the chance to be fully fleshed out before the game was abandoned.[/b]

[h1]Why is this a positive review then?[/h1]

[b]When Chucklefish abandoned us, the community took matters into their own hands.[/b]
[i]Introducing FrackinUniverse[/i], a collection of [i]hundreds[/i] of mods compiled into one download. I am not kidding when I say playing Starbound with and without this mod is like night and day. New bosses, new races, new structures to discover, new quests, new mobs, new planet types, new crafting menu, new crafting tables, new weapons, new crops, new building materials, new furniture, new ships, ETC are all added to the game using that mod. [b]They are even slowly rewriting the entirety of the story line. It is compatible with the majority of other mods on steam and they have consistently updated it since the ability to mod the game was added.[/b] There's even new systems added entirely, such as beekeeping and collecting fossils. 

[b]The modding community for Starbound is extremely dedicated and hardworking, keeping this game alive for many years now.[/b] They are the real reason that I and many others love this game so much. [b]Starbound with mods is extremely entertaining with endless content because of its cult-like modding community. It was my favorite game for a long time.[/b]

[i]PS. play this game with friends, you WON'T regret it.[/i]

Update: after finishing the game I hate it even more now. 
-The story is garbage with the important characters being one note and barely getting any screen time.
-The ending is so unsatisfying and shallow that I sat through the credits expecting some kind of fakeout only to realize the game didn't end with a bang but the wet soggy impact of a stuffed animal drenched in milk being thrown against a wall
-The beginning of the game is overly difficult then after 30 minutes in you're completely overpowered, the only enemies that will ever pose a threat to you are the ones in the tutorial and the ones in the post game dungeons
-The post game doesn't exist, just a few dungeons to grind for supplies for base building.....which assuming you beat the game, you already made a base
-The combat is repetitive and consists of spamming bandages and using swords/spears because the other melee weapons are awful and the ranged DPS is normally too low to justify using guns
-The hunger system would be perfectly fine, except food doesn't stack and goes bad quickly so it becomes a nuisance 
-The ship requiring fuel does nothing but pad your time for the game
-The game barely supports multiplayer and many bounty missions will break with multiple people
-The game has no built-in mod menu so in order to turn off certain mods you have to manually unsubscribe from them, this makes multiplayer significantly more difficult to set up because the game completely breaks if everyone doesn't have the EXACT same mod list
-The UI is cryptic at best and straight up fights you at worst
-Have I mentioned how overpowered bandages are? Seriously you can heal through every boss with ease, every slow healing item is completely useless in comparison to bandages
-Member recruiting is tedious and takes forever
-The mobility options are hidden behind an optional mission and are vital to get to avoid some boss attack patterns
-There's only one boss who will pose any kind of challenge and that's only if you don't have the double jump, the other mobility options are optional

OLD: This game is, fun if a little hard at times, brought to a level of excellence thanks to a vibrant and lively modding community and a developer who really cares about the product.

OLD: That is indeed what i felt at the time. However due to the now toxic behavior of the developers and the community shifting to unsurprisingly reflect that fact i can no longer in good conscience recommend this product.

 The lack of updates from the developer and childish actions of a few and the moderators unwillingness to punish their buddies has caused the community to stagnate and fester into a disgusting cesspool.

Good Bits: some of my personal favourites

If you like terraria but want a more open world exploration aspect then this game is for you. It doesnt have the fancy boss driven progression like terraria but rather an exploration driven progression. This doesnt get repetitive imo as you have a plethora of things to do while exploring to the point where this game can be played for hours in various styles, whether that is becoming the strongest hero in space, or just a farmer on the first planet you spawn on.

There is also a great amount of customisation you can do with both the characters race, armour, vanity and backpack slots to really design your characters appearance. On top of this there is the ability to dye your armour.

The music, art style, light rays, different weathers, and so forth really make this game immersive. You can even find musical instruments and play set songs from them such as clare de lune (which when sat by a campfire in a cave while it rains hits different).

There are also different "classes" you can play which is determined by the armour you choose to equip at the time, and you can even capture pets to fight for you in a pokemon style way.

There is also mechs you can create, space stations to trade with, friendly and enemy ships to board to fight while in space. 

MODS: The base game is good for about 40hours of play. However with mods you can easily achieve 300+ hours and thats conservative (Frackin universe is a really good mod)

Bad Bits:

Ive played this game across three platforms of pc gaming, IMac, laptop and now a higher end gaming pc. For me, the optimisation and bugs were found with the lower power systems (like my old laptop). 

Once youve done the story once, there isnt much reason to do it again. It is fun and really engaging however it is quite linear. But, it isnt necessary to do. You can just ignore it and do whatever you want. Progression isnt locked behind the story.

The base game planets have dungeons and a variety of generated enemies and weapons with each planet having a danger rating. However, while there are plenty of dungeons, once youve played the base game for 40hours youve pretty much covered the surface content youre going to see. 

Long story short: The game is what you make of it. It is only limited by what content you want to do. If you play the game for 12 hours, complete the story and thats it then youre missing the point of starbound. Take the time to utilise all the content added and it is some of the most fun you can have. The mods arent necessary but they really enhance the experience making the game and never ending universe feel alive.
A decent game based around exploration, digging, crafting, and (optional) base-building.

Pretty fun at first! You feel like some han solo type guy jumping from different systems and doing quests. but it doesnt take long for you to realize everything is put together in a real lazy way. The weapons are broken down into a couple different catagories but there's no difference between one grenade launcher to the next ect ect. The worlds are all randomly generated but theres no difference between one ocean world and the next so ie theres really no difference between one solar system and the next. Everything just feels redundent. And don't get me started on the story, you have to use your special tool to find clues about different races so you can get the special artifact. Fun right? Nope, cause you have to do this exact thing for at 6 different races. Over and over and over again. Not to mention the clues are hard as hell to find. I spent 2 hours trying to find clues for the second race. And was only a third of the way done. Plus the combat just feels lazy, either its way to hard or its way to easy. This game could have been so much more :/

This game is not worth your time if youre looking for a fullfilling experience. First of all everyone should know how this game was made. Almost every part of the game (visuals, sound, mobs, worlds, mechanics, bosses, dungeons races, etc) are all made by different people, who most of them at the time were underage and tricked into working without getting paid. The game is built on trickery and thats a big reason everything is so lackluster and unfinished.

 Whist the trip of the adventure is fun, you achieve nothing. The main quest is extremely boring and the bosses suck too. There is no mining in the game, no fun caves, no underground biomes, nothing. There are "infinite amount" of stars and planets however nothing about them is unique. Same villages, same dungeons, same npcs and same npc missions.
You do not have to work for a single thing in the game, everything is free and you find it while walking around the same planets in different colors, while youre doing the same quest 8 times. 
Nothing feels finished and this game is just overall so lackluster. Post ending the story, the game offers you absolutely nothing, no replay ability. 

I recommend you dont support the main dev, who is a horrible person. And this game is not worth it, in the end it's unfinished in most aspects and very dissapointing, especially with how much potential this game had. Very sad.

Better than No Man's Sky and Terraria if you install the 3 largest mods for this game, Frackin' Universe, Arcana, and Galaxy in Conflict. 
The pixel art is a 9/10, the gameplay, construction and exploration is a 7/10, but with the mods I mentioned it becomes a solid 9/10. 

The only problem i have is the poor optimization.

Starbound is very well paced between space exploration, survival and resource gathering, and base building. It's easy to get attached to certain locations and characters, and the game is at it's best when you have a dynamic, unscripted set of stories involving those places and people. There is an extremely warm atmosphere to the entire thing, which I really ended up prizing the game for.

The story is so absurdly boring that the game would be better off without it, or a mode that ignores it entirely. Your personal stories of getting stuck in crazy caves and adventuring with random members of alien colonies is always infinitely more interesting. That said, interactions with NPCs is very barebones quest-based stuff. If the AI was better and the interactions more fleshed out to really give the feeling that each NPC is a unique being, the game would be the best in it's genre.

I bought this game 8 years ago, and it has shaped my interest in games. From getting me into modding, sending me into years of tons of different types of side scroller survival games, and just down a rabbit hole of survival becoming my single favorite genre in general. It all started from Starbound for me, and every game I enjoy and everything I do in the games I love can link back to it somehow. It was the first game I picked up that wasn't free to play, and even if it's abandoned now, I'll always come back to see what legacy the community still wishes to build. From Frackin' Universe to newer mods like Arcana, Starbound doesn't look like it'll ever end, and I couldn't be happier.

Thank you, Chucklefish, for everything Starbound brought me and my friends over the near decade I've loved it for.

Starbound has an incredible concept and I would have loved a more fleshed out version of this. For quite a few reasons, this game falls short.

Firstly the main story line is just garbage, you go around 'scanning' things around multiple systems and that somehow shows the locations of a challenge map where you conquer its boss. This is done over and over again until the last, much more interesting boss. Seems like a way to force players to see the vast arrays of planets.

Secondly, the combat system. Its just, horrible. Its based on an energy system and it is just so sluggish. It makes the very interesting bosses just garbage. Just like the combat system, almost every system and feature in this game is just so shallow. Fishing, Mechs, and catching monsters and so much more. And most importantly, the selling point of the game, the space and ship system.

This game could be... so much more, would be one of the best games out there, but after a bunch of bad decisions, we get Star bound. Don't get me wrong, I have played this game twice and am playing a third modded time, this is a decent game. But it is a very shallow one. What also sours the experience is knowing that this game involved unpaid child labour to some extent. What you could do to better your experience ten-fold would be to install Frackin' Universe, a very fleshed out mod. It almost makes you think that the creators of FU put more time, love, and effort into the mod, than the devs did for Starbound. Frackin' Universe expands upon all the shallow features (unfortunately not the combat system) and involves a much better progression system.

With a loving and loyal dev team (*cough cough* terraria), this could have been one of the best games of all time.

TL:DR; decent game, questionable development process, play with mods.

Starbound, the Terraria that tries to offer alien diversity.

The Good.

1. Two dimensional gameplay with low resolution pixel art that exercises combined cursor and keyboard movements for planet hopping interactions, with visually pleasing menus for keyboard keybinding customization, that end up with shifting WASD to ESDF because of that usability F indentation.

2. There is lots of written lore among each planetary settlements, as players try to collect enough fuel for further travels to make hospitable civilization for in-game characters.

3. Gameplay, last remembered, is a smooth process to play on a desktop Personal Computer.

4. The art style is charming and adds to discovery and exploration, with multitudes of planets to build houses and farms for questing support.

5. There is a main storyline quest to keep players engaged throughout their discoveries within the Starbound universe.

The Bad:

1. It is not Terraria. There are no encountered epic boss fights with repetitive run and dash gameplay that shows with the same boss fights that clip through built terrain. The boss fights that do exist, seem relatively easier in difficulty, even with an imposed Xbox controller on the left hand and a trackball peripheral on the right hand with the associative button mapping. 

2. It is not Terraria, in the sense that Terraria allows for simultaneous usage of a Xbox controller and a cursor with built-in menu options without additional third party software installed, a Xbox controller easily can be mapped with the in-game menus for movement and jumping controlls while a cursor device with multiple buttons, more than the typical Microsoft Surface Mouse or Apple Mighty Mouse device, to map useful quick reaction menus and item scrolling functions. It is not intuitive to remember to use Shift + Tab to use some controller overlay that does not work with some Steam updates.

3. It is Starbound. Menu User Interaction designers should try to consider Xbox controllers for movement. But those Steam Deck devices never have good cursory approaches, compared to Surface Pro gaming. Starbound lacks in-game menus or mod listings to know which applet to overlay inside Starbound to have customized controls that User Experience designers try to present pretty menus for keyboard remappings, but not account for things outside of laptop keyboards.

4. There is a very specific nuiance problem with Starbound, evident with walking and platforming with simultaneous usage of some Xbox controller for movement and a cursor trackball movement for precision block placement. Due to the polling rate of wireless bluetooth periipherals, not seen with Terraria because of the designed gameplay of known building paces with a player's movement, it is not known when a player all of a sudden does not place building blocks while walking at a pace. That leads to tip tap motions, and that is not very good User Experience intuition.

5. The main quest line is very very short, after players focus on obtaining the best armor and weapons before continuing through each mainline quest. It is not particularly a bad thing for many players without lots of time and Starbound allows for players to not obsess about mining and digging, unlike Terraria.

6. Non-Playable-Characters that accompany a player on a planet can be very dumb. Such is regarding about avoiding bad terrain, and do block the way of furniture. There is not any way to truce with settlements found if a player Matter Manipulates to destroy furnishings.

7. Very linear main story questing that falls into the bottleneck McGuffin progression. That is on top of disrupting the immersion of what seems to be an open-world building video game that is actually very linear if players then see that Enviro Protection Pack is just another linear unlock to progress to titanium and durasteel tiers.

8. There have been several times Starbound in single player crashed on a Surface Pro device, that no other Steam Personal Computer video game has demonstrated crashes, such as single player Minecraft, Terraria, Borderlands, and Factorio. Crashes usually occur during boss fights with many rendered assets on screen, and significant slowdown occurs with many Non-Playable-Characters at a settlement.

The Simulation Of Long Distance Dating:

1. Starbound happens to build up civilizations with some player acting as some automated robot process, despite multiple organic races to select from, that builds up towns on other planets. Starbound does not simulate what economies occur on a massive planetary scale. There is some space station cargo trading that does go on within Starbound, but finding space stations to greatly increase a player's currency is alot slower with such method compared to fighting off hostile ships upon jumping to a solar system.

2. Even if Starbound does simulate economies for those strange fruits grown in gardens, some looking like fruits for robots for some strange reason, meta interactions would have human players just Skype, Discord, Whatsapp, or any other fragmented mod apps on the side of their Windows Personal Computer or Steam Desk, and that in itself is a clunky multiple device experience with webcams only looking at side profiles of human heads.

3. Multitasking Deep Space Waifu does not make a good phone game experience, on a meta call level if Starbound has such snarky features. Those Non-Playable Character quests about secret notes seem to be very much recycled plays for the player to get weapons and armor to obtain and sell, since mining for ores does not get the best playable weapons suited for a player's reaction timing.

4. Shortswords, spears, and axes are worthless, especially regarding boss fights. Players would quickly render such items as vendor trash. Wands and staves have significant delays for their abilities, that tries to bring in wizardry range and uniqueness with multiplayer gatherings, that is useless for single player.

Such a not recommend thing would shift back to a recommend, if stagnant developers do implement the same customization Xbox controller options and simultaneous cursor button mapping usages with a trackball that can use eight buttons, as Minecraft Bedrock, Terraria, and Borderlands. That is because Steam's controller overlay function fails to operate. It is difficult to advertise Starbound of fifteen dollars needs a twenty-five dollar purchase of reWASD that brings such video game one-time cost back up to the Nintendo price tag of forty dollars with Nintendo 3DS titles and some Nintendo Switch titles. Emulation video games also fall into such categories.b

I am a 63 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Starbound is kept alive by the modding community. And that's all. Official updates eventually killed the game - what was once a unique experience for each playthrough ended up being an extremely streamlined and repetitive incident.

I once loved Starbound. Honestly. I remember playing it with my friends - we would meet in one of our spaceships to play Zelda songs in our recently found instruments and to show off our new skills, and then we would descent into unknown planets to look out for NPC villages... Man, those were the days. This game was [b]REALLY[/b] good in the past, giving players freedom to advance on their own or settle down as they wish.

But then the story nation attacked. And now most core aspects of the game are hard-locked behind a boring and dull story progression which will make most casual players give up.

Starbound went through several game advancement changes during its development, but it was never so linear as it turned out to be in the [b]Cheerful Giraffe[/b] version back in 2016. It should have been named the Lethiferous Giraffe instead, considering that on that very release this unholy forbidden story arc was added. Starbound has currently [b]ZERO[/b] replayability - you'll unlock skills in the same order, craft stuff in the same order, visit the same planets, do the same quests, have the same adventure over and over, over and over and over and over and over and over...

Most beta players complained about the released changes. And then immediately the game was officially launched. Stonks af.

[i]I wonder what goes wrong with development for all those 2D space-themed games. Jesus, look at Edge of Space. Ew.[/i]

If you want the "good" Starbound, give its older versions a try. Also bring some friends. It'll suck less. [spoiler]Or just go play Terraria instead.[/spoiler]

Edit: Apparently word got out that Chucklefish is also a terrible company that doesn't pay their workers. Amazing stuff.

Starbound was a game I absolutely adored when I was younger, but overall my opinion of it has gradually worsened over time.

It is a game of tons of variety. You can play as many different races of characters, explore the galaxy, mine for resources, make a colony, capture 100 different insects, get trophies of every enemy, capture the animals in pokeballs, fly around in a mech suit fighting sentient rocks, fire a rocket launcher at a giant piece of poop, fight actual bosses, go fishing, cook the nearly 200 recipes, become a bounty hunter, terraform planets, swim under water to find futuristic japan in order to scan an arcade machine and much more!

I love the variety in activities, I love the music, the artstyle, the ridiculous weapons, the funny dialogue. For the first couple years I had it I loved it. I enjoyed venturing throughout the universe in search of collectibles to decorate my ship and base, and to have the most impressive lockers I can.

But as soon as I revisit the game, much older as I am, the whole thing collapses.

The galaxy awaits you! Do whatever you like! in a completely preset order. For a galactic spanning open world sandbox, the game is extremely linear and restrictive in how you progress, you have to get one tier of equipment and then the next and then the next, no sequence breaks. The story missions have to be done in a specific order, making the linearity even more noticeable, and to add insult to injury, story progress is shared over all saves, so you cannot truly replay the story. The lack of replayability is absolutely catastrophic for the quality.

The wide variety of features earlier comes at a cost, none of them are fleshed out, many are superfluous, some hurt game balance, and even worse many are clunky or poorly executed. Fishing for example, is completely pointless, no rewards for any of it, it can't be used for unique recipes, traded for cash, you can't even place them in an aquarium or something. It is superfluous. Mechs are awesome, they allow you to traverse space and find all new stuff, as well as interact with other ships. However they completely derail the mining, as it gives more ore in larger quantity then you can get while mining, while also being less engaging. The animals that you capture have no real utility, so they are strictly for fun. This makes so much of the game feel directionless and without purpose.

The core mechanics are not really deep, especially compared to contemporaries like terraria, the core movement doesn't jive well with the terrain generator, the hotbar is really tiny, the enemy designs don't get all that complex, there is something resembling classes in the endgame but it makes no real impact, and the building is intuitive, but lacks depth, the furniture is sparse and inflexible, there isn't many ways to modify block shapes, the paint is terrible, the wiring doesn't lead to many interesting contraptions.

A feeling of repetition can easily wash over anyone who explores the galaxy for very long, as each species has only 1-4 structures dedicated to them, and each planet type reuses the same structures and sub biomes. There are also tons of unique, hand crafted enemies, who manage to spread themselves throughout the galaxy. The missions too are procedurally generated, so you better believe the same npc might give you an IDENTICAL quest two times in a row, with the same objective at the same exact place. This wrecks the game's staying power in my catalogue, because I will never see anything truly new again, and I won't gain anything from repeating it I haven't already gained.

On top of all that, the performance of the game is very poor, with it struggling to maintain 30 fps on good machines during the missions, and crashes are way to common for how simple the processes occurring on screen are.

tl;dr, the game was initially enjoyable, and there is a ton of variety, but it suffers from unpolished core gameplay, shallow mechanics, poor replay value, inadequate rewards, repetition, and a slew of technical issues.

I didn't like the beta much, and the final version doesn't improve this game at all. Combat doesn't come close to the diversity and fluidity of Terraria, the occasional varied planets become familiar and uninteresting after a few travels around space, mining is unnecessarily tedious, the story is tacked on and actually worse than the freedom offered in the beta, performance issues cause enemies to stutter around even when online options are turned off, and overall the whole thing gets stale fast.

One positive: the wonderful avian race (which I'll always play as), as well as modded races like the adorable avali. Mods such as "frackin universe" can definitely make this game more enjoyable and interesting, but even with mods it doesn't match vanilla Terraria's gold standard for the genre.

Game has been my stress relief for last year and I will always love, for it's music and atmosphere. I really recommand trying it out, it's not Terraria (for the people seeing the similar style) but I love it because it's different and unique in its own way. "I was the Sun before it was cool" and "In a Distant home" are some of my favorite ost to this day.
Life doesn't have any hands, but it can sure give you a slap sometimes.

It really is a lot like minecraft, but in space and without any of the dream like liminal spaces you get when you play by yourself. It has the same rhythm to it when you go out adventuring but you have a ~mostly~ open world. It doesn't feel limiting in any way except that the types of planets that you can set out on are based on how much you level up your crafting stations based on resources found exclusively on certain planet biomes and the story (Think of iron being on one planet but tungsten on another and that gives you stronger armor). 

 However early on there is a good set to explore as every world you start out on is unique. I've played a few playthroughs (5 at least) that were cut short every time and every beginning I ever had there were slight variations to the trees or the types of blocks or NPCs  (if you find any) to make everything different on the starting level. It was enjoyable and while  mining, if you dig deep enough, there is variety in the blocks also. I've encountered even weird blocks such as flesh like ones deep underground in the starting level. Obviously it's e 10+ but still. You can find this level of variety in every single planet even with the same biome type of atmosphere. 

Some of the drawbacks would have to be that you if you ever use a laptop, for the love of your sanity,  USE A MOUSE. Do not throw your poor laptop out of the window out of frustration. I've used a an older potato laptop Win 10 with around 1.5 GB RAM with a trackpad before to play this game and on some tries it was between laggy and smooth. Playable, but the trackpad was awful. Would not recommend. With a mouse you have faster response time.  If you use linux though, this game runs natively on that particular OS without the need of HAVING to run Wine. I  haven't even checked proton settings when playing on it with linux booted up but it runs clean as a whistle. 

The only people I would not recommend this to is if you are looking for a hardcore dungeon crawler experience. The only setback is your armor and how you play. It's a maybe, but if you REALLY crave something in terms of in depth world building or difficulty in something like Morrowind or Dark Souls out of a game then this likely isn't for you either.  That's not a negative on the game's part, it's just how the experience is. Starbound is a fun experience you  can have while sipping tea and then being at the edge of your seat when a certain "creature" instadeaths you while you are mining in space.

[h1] Better than Terraria! [/h1]

[b] The Positive's [/b]
+ Ever expanding workshop
+ Endless sandbox adventure
+ Amazing soundtrack
+ Multiplayer/Co-op

[b] The Negative's [/b]
- Nothing -_-

[b] The Aspect Of The Game [/b]
You are one of the last protectorates that are still around from the unfortunate event's that take place in the prologue. Starbound is game where you play your way and do whatever your heart desires. Be it you play alone or with friends you will spend at least 100+ hours in this game. The campaign is optional where you can enjoy the game without ever even progressing past the first objective. There is also a never ending online community where you will eventually find a server with a common interest.

[b] The Value Of The Game [/b]
This is one of my top 10 most played games. In my opinion it is worth every penny to embark on this adventure.

I don't think my previous review, that states, "Best story game of all time, its a story/survival game with quests, heaps of fun." is an adequate description of how fantastic this game is. If you enjoy linear story games with lots of exploration and side-quests, this is the right game for you. While most find issues with the fact that this game has little replay-ability, (Not really a problem in my eyes, but is a very big flaw for most.) it's main story is so much fun to go through, (Ignore the fact that most of it is just the same thing with a new puzzle and boss at the end, it hurts me o think of the lost potential.) and a fantastic ending. I love progressing through this game on a new planet every time, flying my spaceship to the nearest moon when I need more fuel, mining in deep caves, finding challenge doors, dying in challenge doors, starting a colony, murdering innocents, and just the peaceful act of sitting outside my brand new house, tending to my farm for food. This game means everything to me, and I hope you find yourself journeying the stars too. (Even if you don't end up enjoying the game, give the soundtrack a listen, you'll love it i promise!)

Starbound is wasted potential. form what I understand, there was a very shaky development for this game, held together by like duct tape and dreams. This game feels half complete at best, and overall you will probably have a pretty horrible experience. THAT IS until you install mods. The community refuses to let this game die, and breathes new life into it regularly, keeping this thing alive and well for the most part. Sure, 50% of the mods feel like the community is either too dumb to be modding, or too horny to be modding, but the other 50% is where it shines. People restoring cut content, people making whole new galaxy and planet generation, new missions, new gear. The community is where this otherwise horrible game shines, and that is why I can without a doubt recommend this to anyone who likes games like Terraria.

Starbound has been a fun progression game that shares similarities with games like Terraria. But it can take a bit of time just to get to the mid/end game which sometimes feels a bit repetitive. Go to a planet, mine specific ore, build new armour that lets you survive the next planet, go to next planet, mine specific ore etc.

The "campaign" was a fun addition with these adventure like dungeons that explore the story more. The first human dungeon was a personal favourite had a horror game vibe to it which was cool. Plus being able to wear a horse's head whilst in a wedding dress as you duel wield grenade launchers has always been entertaining.

I do recommend playing this with some friends.

I am a 38 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 15. My son downloaded Stars Bound and in less than a week, he had already played for over 11 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

The game is absolutely amazing the first time through. The world, music, mechanics, combat, and story are engaging and fun. I found myself losing track of time quite often while playing. However, the game suffers a complete lack of replayability. The game hinges on it's vast and unique ecosystems, locations, quests, stories and lore. However, after the first play through, the game doesn't have much more to offer. Everything I mentioned before becomes boring, and before long, you will find yourself at a lack of things to do. And this is further impacted by the shared universe feature. As you go through the story, permanent changes will occur to your hubworld and npc's will appear. At first, this adds atmosphere to the game, and new vendors and dialogue. But, if you play through again, even at the start, the same people will be there, acting as if nothing changed. The peacekeeper expansion was a breath of fresh air, but it suffers from the same issues after a while. The game suffers from a major lack of replayability, but I will never forget the those feelings of wonder and awe as I explored new planets and learned about an amazingly crafted universe. There's not much I wouldn't give to feel it again.

In the vanilla game, after playing a little it gets really boring and, at least in my opinion, building becomes the only fun part.

I love this game, and I've spent so much time in it, but if you're looking for gameplay, get mods for it.

Sunk more hours into this than literally any other game, and was once my favourite but since I've soured a little to it simply for being such a huge mess. I absolutely still think it's worth your time if you like 2D survival games in the vein of Terraria, especially because of the mindblowing variety of mods, but yeah it's got some huge problems that have gone seemingly unchecked by the devs. It's notoriously unoptimised, the progression quests are as bland as they come in this genre, and several features (most notably mechs) seem to exist only on the sidelines and never converge with the main storyline in a satisfying way. However, if you're willing to look past that, I hope this game's beauty, scale and incredible soundtrack are able to create as many extremely endearing moments for you as they did for me.
