Starbound is a 2D survival-sandbox game that centers around driving around in a starship base and beaming from planet to planet to gather materials, advance the story, or build more permanent settlements. It has some very nifty takes on the genre, generating a galaxy with quadrillions of planets to visit, each with a host of biomes and aliens before No Man's Sky was a thing. Plus, you can play as a space furry, that's always a plus in my book.

Unfortunately, this game is slow, in a lot of senses. It's slow in the sense that the main story is padded out in a way that's unfriendly to the player, it's slow in that most of the secondary tasks and achievements are even more of a grind than the main story, and slow in the sense that it's poorly optimized. The optimization is probably the easiest to explain - the whole game runs on the CPU, and only on one core, and in addition to that there's a memory leak you can regularly encounter in gameplay that makes things grind to a halt.

I would recommend not going for the achievements if you choose to play this game, as well as getting a decent amount of mods to make things as efficient as they feel they should be. You can get mods to make crafting instant, or to remove the screen transitions that quickly add up as you beam from place to place with your ship's teleporter, or even skip the entire storyline that feels tacked on and adds little to the gameplay aside from a few really cool pre-made dungeons, but nothing can be done to fix the slowdowns caused by the poor optimization.

There's one more thing that people may want to consider before buying this game. Around 2019 word got out that a dozen voluntary contributors were exploited during Starbound's development, logging hundreds of hours with no compensation, many of them in their teenage years. A bunch of people who used to work with Chucklefish came out to confirm this happened, and it falls at the hands of company director Finn Brice, who also harassed nearly everyone else working there. I know it doesn't matter to everyone, but when looking at the worlds of this game, it pains me to think that people went through hell to get this game together and they weren't even given what they deserved in the end.

Despite all the flaws, Starbound is still one of my favorite game of all time

For the first hundred hours or so of playing this game I did enjoy it. But as my playtime dragged on and on I begun to notice the cracks to the point I do not particularly enjoy this game anymore, so I want to take a moment to break down what starbound does well, and where it falls flat compared to other games in its genre.

On the positive, starbound has great artistic direction. The visuals, sound effects and music is great, and I think it frankly is what kept me going through the game. Additionally the world of starbound, its races and technology is great and really creative.
However were this game begins to fall flat is its gameplay, I am going to cover this point by point as theres a fair bit to get through.
1) In starbound, the boss fights and the story is progressed through story missions. In order to unlock the next story mission, you must travel to planets in order to find evidence of specific alien races and then scan enough objects to unlock the mission, issue is, this process of scanning is really, really boring. When you decide you want to attempt the scanning, it consists of you going from planet to planet of the correct type, wondering across the entire planet looking for any signs of the race, then running through the civilisation mindlessly looking for green objects only to realise you didn't get all the stuff you need so you now need to go find another planet so on and so on. This gets tedious quickly, especially so on repeat runs, it really bogs the games pacing and I do wish it was not a mechanic.
2) Enemy design. Starbound attempts to make each planet feel different by randomising its enemies a bit. But in reality the enemies are really bland, they are the same 5-10 enemies copy and pasted across every world on the game, the only difference being minor sprite differences. And the enemies themselves are not interesting, they range from enemies that run into you fast, enemies that run into you slow. Enemies with a single range attack, or ones that suicide or cloak. They are not fun to fight, it makes every planet feel the same and it feels really bad for progression. 
3) Progression. After 20 hours of grinding the best gear, you are no better at killing the enemies around you which behave and look identical to the ones you were killing on the starting planet. You never get that sense of strength like you do in games like Terraria unless you backtrack to earlier areas in the game which has no benefit and is just a waste of fuel. Your end game gear isnt more flashy then the beginning gear, at the end of a playthrough, my best weapon, the one that took me all this time to get, was a generic looking gun that shoots bullets, the exact same generic guns that I was finding at the beginning of the playthrough just with a better damage stat. Between this and having no reference for the enemies you are fighting (as they all look the same) you never get that sense of progression that you are in fact getting stronger, the longer you play the more you notice this and the worse it becomes.
4) Bosses and combat. Combat is lackluster, it mostly consists or running into some enemies, hitting them a few times, runnign a way, popping a heal, then running back and hitting a few more times. If you are ranged, this is the exact same but from a distance, theres no skill or excitement. The only time combat gets remotely interesting is the bosses. I am now going to talk about the bosses which is minor spoilers, got to point 5) to avoid them. The boss quality varies wildly. The tutorial boss, the crystal is really solid for a tutorial boss. It has simple attacks, but it has you moving around alot, and at this point in the game you have to be quite resourceful as the enemies in this mission are really strong at this level of progression. Its a fun boss, no complaints. The ixodoom is.... underwhleming. It is very easy and you can beat it by just running left and right until its vunerable and then just attacking it for a few seocnds then it continues. It is not an interesting boss, all the attacks feel weak, the music isnt there and its just dissapointing. Even with the bosses that are more difficult, they still have the tendency to not feel very strong, have meh music and have uninteresting fight mechanics. The only late game bosses I think dont go y this, is the ape and the heart of ruin. The Ape is the only other boss other than the crystal that I would say is a solid boss. It isnt amazing dont get me wrong, but has interesting enough moves and is difficult enough that I dont mind the fight. The heart of ruin solves my weak feeling attack problem, which huge laser beams and tentacles everywhere. The issue lays in two things. A) It is a huuuge bullet sponge and B) Its 90% just a spawner boss. Overall the bosses are just underwhelming and not interesting to fight. (This goes for bosses I havent mentioned too like the dreadwing).

5) Endgame content. The primary engame content are the vaults. The vaults are a cool concept, have good loot and, the vault bosses... are not bad at all. Despite point 4) I think the vault mini bosses are pretty solid as they dont need to be incredivle as they minibosses, they have enough variety of moves and you are moving around dodgin enough that they arent boring to fight. My issue is with the rest of the vaults, they are just room after room of the same boring enemies like mentioned before, and they are just so long. Vaults are not 5 minute in and outs, they take a while to complete, are fairly tedious in their rooms, and to get the best gear you often have to grind quite a lot of vaults.

CONCLUSION:
While I have more points, I believe I have said enough to explain my growing disconnect with this game. Starbound is a game with great visual style, and a great world but suffers from a lack of substance behind its primary gameplay loop, with unrewarding combat, tedious missions and gathering, repetitiveness and underwhelming boss encounters. Despite playing almost 250 hours of this game I can not recommend its purchase.

If Terraria is essentially 2-D Minecraft but 10x better, then Starbound is Terraria meets Minecraft, add 3000 years to the future, and have a better modded workshop than either. Installing Mods is as simple as clicking "Subscribe" instead of needing tModLoader or downloading external clients or mods (WHICH YOU CAN STILL DO!), with a community composed of shitposters, builders, speedrunners and straight-up furries. It's a crossroads for all sides of the world to just explore pixelated space.

- With mods      8 / 10

Pros
- Have a lot of mechanic and cool stuff. You can also explore other planets. This game is like - - terraria but cooler. It also lore.
- Hard to get bored for first-timer.
- Mods are very refreshing and make the game feel like a new experience.
Mods and mods

Cons
- Technially "abandoned" since 2018 because the game story and mechanic already finished. (The devs did not say it is abandoned, but they are trying to find someone who continues it, so yes pretty much abandoned)
- Not many mechainc are teached in tutorial or quests. Many you have to figured it out by - yourself or you can just read the whole dialog. They highlight the most important part.
- After you get to know the story mechanic. It is pretty much boring. after you play for a while. [spoiler](Scan objects to fight bosses in a loop)[/spoiler]
- Only mods make the game feel refresh again.

Summary
 A pretty good game, but sadly abandoned by the devs. It is a fun and enjoyable game for a long time and if it becomes boring mods can help with that.

I'm not going to lie, I didn't expect much from this game. I got it for cheep, and it's not the high graphics game I normally play. But WOW is this game good! There's so much to do! Farming, collecting, crafting, building, exploring, fighting, story...I'm 50 hours in and still have a ton of things I want to do. There was obviously a lot of feedback from the community that went into this game, evident in the small quality of life improvements. Your stuff doesn't despawn for one, which has helped me to not get frustrated when I die (*cough* Minecraft *cough* It's just an overall extremely polished game that has a huge variety of things to offer its players.

This game was fun and enjoyable but these moments of enjoyment was so short lived that I cannot recommend it to everyone.

-Exploration is the main enjoyment of the game but the problem is that you are not really given much incentive to explore to these planets. The terrain is consistently inconsistent with most planets being this jagged mess of mountains and caverns with only a few flat areas and these proportions are completely random so you cant scout out a specific planet with a neat terrain. Finding chests and loot are common and rewarding but the challenge of having to scale a fuck ton of hills with enemies knocking you down and dying to fall damage made it feel unrewarding and more of a chore than fun. 

+Cave exploration I have to put in it's category with them doing well with it, mining is fast and exploration is fast, the amount of connecting caverns and large chasms it easier to get materials along with adding a sense of most likely unintended challenge of making sure to map out the caves with lights or else you get lost or end up falling down and dying.

=Combat, is a thing

=Enemies also are also just very basic with only a few unique ones that end up being really easy to kill and end up being forgotten along with the randomized enemies with their basic attack patterns.

=Bosses are a chore to beat with most being bullet sponges with a few special attacks that cycle repeatedly, these bosses end up being farely simple and predictable until it uses its one specific bullshit attack, but atleast its the part of the game where you are not told to walk around 50 planets hoping for a village to generate to progress the main story.

There is alot more tiny annoyances in the game but its just best to instead ignore this game and spend your money on something better, buy at your own expense kind of deal.

I am a 44 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started Starbound and in less than a week, he had already played for over 30 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. Alright, writing a better review than before...
Starbound as a game is interesting. The gameplay itself is honestly kind of meh, but the interactions with lore and friends you can have is what makes the game super enjoyable. All these concepts it throws at you is, to me at least, the true best part of this game. In the vanilla game alone, we get 6 new species to play around with, each coming with their own backstories. Florans? Plant humanoids that see everything meat based as food, which certainly makes for great player interactions. Avians? Extremely religious bird people. Apex? Technologically advanced but more ape like than humans. Novakids? Player's interpretation. That's the one thing I dislike about the game, novakids have such potential that is just never met. 
The workshop is perhaps the next greatest thing about this game, as the community is just so darn creative. Entire species, worlds, hell even story lines can be found. That just adds to the gameplay and concepts that you get, and with the right mindset you can turn a simply pixel game about killing a planet eating tentacle monster into practically anything else. That tentacle monster still might prevail but that's okay, cuz it's a badass creation. 
Alright last block: Starbound is a game I'd recommend, only for you and your good friends where you can say the most random things. The game is amazing, the lore even better, and it will take up a lot of time if it hooks you. Optimization is god awful but if you've found this game and review then you likely already knew that.

The best moments I've had in this game and the most enjoyment I get from it are from mods, the work the that's been done here is solid, but years of development hell, especially under how development was done, casts a pretty big shadow over the entire work, it's way more mediocre by itself than it used to be, historically there's been objective downgrades in a few different places, story being a pretty big sticking point, but that doesn't compare at all to how the sausage was made here, I don't remember it well enough to recount in full confidence but I'd seriously recommend looking it up since it can really make or break whether you'd want to buy this given the making, I will still play this sometimes because friends sometimes have it and it's an option, but the cognitive dissonance I get from it is unreal, I'd have never bought this game had I known what was going on.

Starbound is a beautiful combination of level design, atmosphere and the experience of discovery and adventure. If you enjoy RP there are several dedicated servers friends of mine spend countless hours on. If you have an imagination and you enjoy exploration, this is a game for you.
Think terraria, but in space

Pros:
- nice soundtrack
- good visuals
- a lot of different stuff to do
- many quests
- a really big universe to explore
- you can be a bounty hunter!
- you can also build your own space station

Cons:
- quests get repetitive and boring fast
- after exploring a few of the different solar systems, the planets all start to look the same
- main story feels forced and boring
- the choice of the player race has no influence on the gameplay whatsoever
- the npcs feel superficial and don't have a personality

Conclusion:
While Starbound is game with room for a lot of improvement, you can lose hours and hours in this game before you don't have anything to do anymore. For a lot of the cons mentioned are also a plethora of mods available to fix almost all of them.

Personally, I recommend installing Elithian Races and/or Fracking Universe for a lot more content to explore and lose yourself in.

This is my take on the game. I'd heavily recommend it to all sorts of people across the globe due to how rich in adventure the game really is!

Pros: Infinite exploration, tons of things to explore and discover, a diverse cast of characters to play from, and unique sets of weapons to use and mess around with. It's got a rich environment with a really charming pixelated style that goes with it, and honestly? I'm all here for it! There's been a lot of changes in the recent years that make this game worth coming back to for, and a rich modding community that really brings it all together, take your pick of the liter and go hog wild!

Cons: The story is super short, and leaves you feeling like, "Really? That's it?". The game is horrendously optimized, basically being held together by bubblegum, duct tape, and a dream. The lag can get horrendous sometimes, and really leave you wondering how it even got jumpstarted in the first place with the spaghetti code it's practically holding onto for dear life for. It needs mods to really extend the game and its replayability, otherwise, I hardly see it being worthwhile trying to play this game again without mods like Frackin Universe, and so on.

Overall Review: 5/10 game without mods. 9/10 - 9.5/10 game with mods.

I bought this game almost 10 years ago as a birthday gift for myself. Now all I feel about it is just, sadness. 
Every choice made post-beta seems to have been made with the express intention of ruining what made the game fun in service of some dickhead lead dev's ego, and it's horribly sad because the overall aesthetic of this game is incredible.

But i think it says a lot that the races in the game have far surpassed the game itself in popularity, and will definitely outlive it.

Looking back on the dev history, the best I can describe this game with is that it was a bait and switch; It retains virtually nothing of value that the original concrpt had in service of a forced story that no one wanted.

The different races used to have unique background histories, traits, and so on. Weather used to be important. Traveling the stars used to mean something because the further you wanted to go, the more fuel you needed.

So much has been lost. Maybe one day I'll see about grabbing a pre-1.0 version of the game, but the current game is horrendously boring.

I am a 44 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started Apex Legends and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This game is a masterful combination of all the things you love about Terraria and No Man's Sky. It takes the mining / progression aspect of Terraria and beautifully combines it with the nothing-to-do concept from No Man's Sky. A wise man once said, this game is like a bread sandwich. You think it's a sandwich, until you mine for 13 hours and find out you can't fight any bosses until you collect all 700 pinecones. 3/10, get shit on by spinning turnips all game.

TLDR: Overall, Starbound is a good game with enough variety and modding to keep you busy. It's "almost" like No Man's Sky meats Stardew Valley. It satisfies in its own unique way but unfortunately that's where it ends. It plays more like a proof of concept rather than a full experience.

---

This will be my fifth or so time playing through the game. I've done 3 unmodded playthroughs and 2 modded ones using Frackin' Universe. While I can positively say modding can help push the game in desired directions the game overall can be described as unconcerned for anything that isn't forced progression.

There is a main story. It's rather short all things considered and the length is made up of about 60% planet exploring and 40% dungeons. It's not a terrible spread however the implementation leaves a lot to be desired. The game is centred around galaxy exploration and while it does succeed in giving you plenty of room to explore there is zero incentive to re-visit any location beyond your own curiosity or creativity. Frackin' Universe helps alleviate some of the problem here but it's still a persisting issue. There simply isn't any actual reason to care about these locations.

Exploring the galaxy gets progressively more difficult and by extension annoying as you progress. The idea itself is awesome and the planets themselves are cool but the reality is so much more painful. The issue, for me at least, is that there's zero incentive for you to do anything beyond just explore and mine a planet, build a set of Tier "whatever" gear, do a dungeon, and move on. By the time you complete the dungeon you've wiped the slate clean. Even if you do get better gear you aren't likely to get anything that improves upon the experience leading to this point. 

A lot of things like colony management, space stations, vehicles, and tech are more proofs of concept than functioning features. None of the aspects of this game beyond exploring planets is essential to progressing. Just as you aren't required to take part in these extra additions you are not required to complete the story missions beyond the Erchius Mining Facility - it's that dungeon that's just tutorial filler (Frackin' Universe does this better, just FYI).

PROS:
- Soundtrack
- Modding
- Things to do
- Combat is rather satisfying
- Dungeons can be appealing depending on your perspective
- Open-ended gameplay
- Non-forced story
- World generation is alright

CONS:
- Some planets feel too generic and bland while others are just too annoying to explore despite being cool. They are essentially just "running simulators" where you might as well just destroy the landscape mining for that one material. Some vehicles trivialise walking at all to the point it's depressing losing your ride, like losing a Sparrow in Destiny 2. 

- Story kind of just "ends". There is next to no real content or story after finishing the main story. There is an end game but with few environments even being much of a bother at this point it doesn't matter. I barely understand the end game myself as I simply can't care enough to really dive into it. All I know is it seems pretty shallow.

- Planet exploration is used as filler during the story leading to essentially run length padding and needing to rush one of the game's core defining aspects. I would prefer visiting these worlds and learning about the species in a natural and organic way rather than through pointless fetch quests. There's no variety whatsoever in how it's handled and you learn nothing about the universe you're in. Padding, nothing more. I'd rather learn about each race's artifact by doing special quests for them where you can learn about their culture and gain their people's trust. Instead you just "invade" people's worlds, steal their planets resources, pilfer through cultural centres and holy ground, and then just expect people to give you their whole race's most treasured belongings.

- Colony development and NPC settlements are seriously lacking. It's literally just fetch quests and bounties. Even in your own colony you are simply an errand boy. Every settlement and colony feels and plays the same way all that changes is the layout.

- Side quests are non-existent. I find it ironic how Dreadwing and the penguins might as well be one of the most iconic and interesting parts of the game - even so much as to have a penguin as the game icon at one point - yet they consist of one of the maybe 3 side quests.

- Everything Erchius related just being so annoying people made mods that remove them. Seriously.

- Dungeons don't have enough variety in their design and encounters to be memorable. If anything it's the grievances that you remember more than anything.

- The Matter Manipulator sucks when trying to build. Like honestly. Tell me why I need to have an 8x8 mining grid destroying my build when it'd be simpler to just do what Terraria did? Unless there's something I'm missing this really is a negative for me.

I feel like the game, really, has been abandoned by the devs. Entire sections of the game could use some tweaks and overhauling. It just doesn't feel refreshing to play the game after a while. Once you've beaten the game and explored a bit of everything you say "Wow, well that's another game done."

Here's a quick summary of the dungeons:

Erchius Mining Facility: If you don't have good enough gear this place will be annoying. So annoying the modding community even made mods so you don't have to go here. It's essentially a tutorial dungeon, but it doesn't do anything to improve or expand upon what you've learnt leading up to this point.

Ceremonial Hunting Grounds: Ranged combat is forced a decent amount here. It's got a good mix of traps, puzzles, and combat. A proper first dungeon.

Grand Pagoda Library: It's a dreaded water level. The lead up to this place is tedious. Scanning Hylotl planets is slow and boring. The library is guaranteed to kill you via fall damage at least a few times.

Sovereign Temple: Annoying. Everything about the temple is annoying. It's an ancient Avian temple full of guardians and traps but everything hurts a ton so you're mostly just heal stalling. Not a fun experience.

Miniknog Stronghold: Actually not a half bad dungeon. I just REALLY wish the focus was actually what was going on the surface. 

The Baron's Keep: The fight you wish was in the dungeon before this one, tbh. It's that one Terraria invasion event nobody likes. You'll know what I mean if you get this far.

Ancient Vaults: No difference between these and those ancient challenge doors you find sometimes on planets. These ones have a big bad boss and a reward you'll probably never care too much about. I barely even know what these vaults are about because by that point I activate admin powers and Thanos snap the vault guardian away.

So the end verdict?

I rate Starbound a decent 6.5/10. It's a good enough experience to be considered a game but it isn't fleshed out enough to be considered a full experience. Some elements are simply too barebones to even be considered any more than beta tests. I think with some overhauling either from devs or through mods it can be brought to a 7.5/10. I don't think the game will get better than that though.

EDIT 2 (11/22/22): Found the love of my life through playing this game. 10 / 10. :)

EDIT: Bumping this down to an 8 / 10 for two reasons: 
1.) Found out that Chucklefish didn't pay their developers. I do NOT support that and will NEVER support that. 
2.) There are bugs and other issues in the game that made it hard for me to keep playing. The three big ones were (a) the game crashing (or slowing down to the point of near-crashing) whenever I fought a boss, (b) a slight lack of direction, and (c) the learning curve. 
In defense of my first major issue, the computer I played Starbound on likely had the minimum requirements for the game. I'll definitely get back to this point once I give the game another go (I haven't played the game since 2020); however, other friends that have played Starbound with much better specs have complained of the same issue. 
In defense of the other two major issues I had, the game has quests and plotlines. However, I didn't always find it easy to remain consistently interested. 
As for the learning curve, it could have just been me having a skill issue -- I like exploring new places, but I'm more of an architect than a fighter. That being said, when I moved from the starter planets to the next difficulty level of planets whilst decently equipped, I still struggled at times. Again, maybe I just need to get good, and I'll update this review once I play the game again. 
The issues I have with it aren't enough for me to stop recommending it, however. I still love the music and artstyle of this game. Furthermore, the game's exploration process can be really fun, and I had a blast building to my heart's content. If you like building and exploring, this game might be fun for you -- especially if you have friends to play with. Just keep in mind this experience might not be the most polished. Also, Novakid best playable characters.
On a side note, I can also recommend No Man's Sky if planet exploration is your cup of tea.

I am a 54 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 15. My son recently started playing Starbound and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This game is just adorable. It offers a variety of fun stuff, whether it is fighting spawns, digging, building colonies or farms, fighting with mechs or building them or searching for loot, playable instruments and items. Planets and star systems are generated procedurally and never the same, similarly the enemies can vary in a number of aspects. Even lots of Workshop items offer more and more customisations â€“ especially "Frackin' Universe" is a blast!

While being fun, Starbound also has some issues. Even single player games suffer from memory leaks resutling in lags (PC versions get better when playing in 32 bit versions), also the end game content gets boring after quite a while, whereas the campaign is a little bit too repetitive. Since it is rather old (released 22nd of July 2016) no more development appears to be taking place.

It offers a lot, but still lacks some minor stuff.

On a side note the developer's logo animation and sound (first after starting the game) are probably one of the cutest there is. ;)

Overall, this game is okay, but my recommendation on this one is somewhat lukewarm.   Still, I can't play a game for as long as I have with this one and say it is bad.  It is fun to come back to every now and explore another world, or build another base.

It does a lot of interesting things, but it can get very grindy and slow at times.  I've for example played this game for close to 100 hours as of this writing, but I have never had the patience to invest the time in building a good mech.  

Some of the bosses were frustrating and much more difficult than the exploration part of the game, but there is a lot of variation and they do something different with each one.  I also think it loses a few points for being derivative of other games that do similar things, often doing them better.

In general, this game has a lot of good ideas included, but they are executed in ways that feel just off enough that they fall short and it is easy to focus on the areas in which it falls short.  At the same time though, there is a lot of game here, and most of it works pretty well.  

Still, this game is a solid C+.

this game sucks so hard oh my god. it sucked when it was in beta and it sucks now. the platforming sucks, the imputs suck, the loadtimes suck, the unskippable cutscenes suck. I remember being so frustrated with it in its earlier builds, and at one point i just gave up and didnt touch it for years. i picked it up the other day, though. i was thinking "well maybe since its finished, it might be fun."

its not, its not fun at all. im not even past the tutorial. i wish i could be, the game looks very fun beyond it, but theres just no way to play it casually. the beginning of the game locks you on rails, providing you with a very vague mission to "repair your ship" so that you can explore the rest of the world. it then deposits you on some hostile world, with only a little arrow to guide you in the general direction of where your supposed to be, and no idea what you're supposed to be doing. your only weapon is an old sword that requires you to get very close to enemies, all of which are faster and more agile than you. did i mention how bad the platforming is? you get caught on the slightest thing, and the second you do a mob decends from the sky and chews up half your health. there are no checkpoints, everytime you die you have to start all over. 

the game just doesnt tell you what to do. this wouldnt be a problem if i could do whatever i wanted, but its story really locks me into this one garbage planet and provides you with one borderline useless navigational tool. exploring isn't fun, its agony. its hard to tell whats in the background, and what's in the foreground. transversal is difficult, youve got to hold the spacebar down to get your full jump height. if you're just a little bit off, it leaves you wide open for some mob to come and kill you.

the mission hints exist, but they only update when you are within proxemity to wherever you're supposed to be. these planets are very large, and you can spend hours, directionless, until you trip over something thats actually relevant to you. once you've accomplished whatever it is, you're back to square one, because it certainly wont tell you whats next. 

i did the first mission out of order. i went to the mine first, where some sort of prompt prompted me to collect a bunch of little red gems. turns out what you're supposed to do before that is go a million miles in the other direction, find a teleporter that doesnt work, turn back around, find the mine, and then return to the teleporter with the gems. if you missed the teleporter, because maybe you decided to go RIGHT instead of LEFT, you'll have no idea what to do with these gems. the game tells you to collect twenty of them, and once you do, its radio silence.

i ended up having to google the solution for this mission, and the next. it wasnt too hard, because google autofilled the problem i was having, and provided me with pages and pages of forums of people also not knowing what they were supposed to be doing.

sometimes, you have to talk to NPCs. they talk very slowly, and their dialog is unskippable. dungeon crawling is agony, as the little direction indicator doesnt guide you around pathways. if you save at all before your first checkpoint and close the game, youll wake up back on your ship, requiring to transverse the entire world again and again. 

im playing all of this on casual mode. i didnt really anticipate my platforming skill being key to like, get past the tutorial.

Game is kept by mods at this point. I love this game and it sad most of the content is half assed. Fun to play once without mods, but for a second playthrough i seriously reccomend modded. I bought this game just about 6 years ago when I was in middle school but I didn't really get to fully appreciate it until a few months ago, so while it's fresh it'd be nice to finally leave a review!

Starbound has always been one of those consistent games I fall back to when sifting through my owned steam games, if there isn't anything else, booting this game up every few months to even years just made sense because the visuals and general gameplay are inviting and cater to what I want as a player!

This game is pretty, and you can make pretty stuff with it, even with just the base game (the modding community is VAST and has carried this game's playerbase for a while now)

I adore the game for what it is and what it's good at, and finally actually finishing the campaign this year felt like a long-awaited and satisfying thing to do in itself. BUT that's the exact issue
*It took me FIVE SOME ODD YEARS to finally getting around to finishing it*

The campaign is the weakest part of the whole game honestly, the story is linear and the whole "search-and-scan" progression style is repetitive and not very engaging, in a game where you are meant to explore the universe there sure isn't much to really look for here, besides a few books and some dialogue blurbs you don't get any real eye-catchers. From what I hear about the promises that the devs made for this game in early development and what the final product ended up being, it seems like this aspect of the experience has disappointed quite a few people, but personally even with those short-comings, what the game DOES execute well is enough for me.

It's fun to make a vibrant and fun settlement with friends, to pick a race and learn about the little details each culture has. It's also fun to upgrade your ship and fill it with penguin crewmates, or to customize and deploy a mech to different missions and planets.

I go back to Starbound for the things I know that I enjoy because I've had it so long and know what to expect, but if what I've described doesn't seem like enough? I would give it a pass, you won't miss too much.

*TLDR*

I've had this game for years and love the sandbox portion of it but the campaign is lacking and the world isn't as vast as it feels like it should be. I like it for what it is.

PROS
----
>Very nice, timeless visuals.
>Interesting Race Choices (Plant People, Conspiracy Apes, Backwards Compatible Robots)
>Great potential for fun nights with friends
>Large library of interesting mods (This can practically be the selling point of this game with how much more you can add)
>Satisfying sandbox elements
>Cool looking Weapons/Armor to find and craft! (Some of the unique weapons are genuinely very cool)

CONS
----
>Bland, boring, linear campaign
>Lack of push to explore very much
>Fun (but limited) amount of environments to see (dungeons, settlements, etc.)
>Enough content for the price (But you'll need quite a few mods if you have the itch for something new.)

I'm never going to forget this game, I'm glad I found it and I'm even more glad I finished it, I'm still going to come back to it again at some point but that doesn't mean it's for everyone, I don't recommend going in expecting the whole world, but what you do get is more than enough for me.

Also Florans are the coolessssst motherfuckersssss and I'll sssstand by that.

I played this game [u]a lot[/u] in the past days trying to figure things out, but I simply can't give it a positive review. 

[b]First things first[/b]: this game is different from Terraria. In Terraria you dig down, everytime finding better ores to build better tools that you let you mine even better ores. In Starbound, you have a tool that can mine everything from the beginning. also, early in the game you get access to a mech suit capable of mining everything even faster. so the focus is moving between planets, because no planet has all available ores or monsters or materials. in the meantime, you can build houses in  these plantes (teleport is available, too), build starbases, and upgrade your spaceship. and do quests. there are lots of NPCs across the universe with quests. 

[u]now, the bad part:[/u]

[b]there is no serious tutorial[/b]: only a five-minute 'mission' to show how to use some tools, and that's it. you don't really know what should be built, or how to grow plants. the Don't Starve series title is more informative than the Starbound tutorial.
[b]the battle system is completely unbalanced[/b] from the very beginning. it's so unbalanced that Thanos would have seizures by just looking at it. The first monsters can kill you with 2 or 3 hits. they jump and dash towards you.
[b]the first mission is completely crazy[/b]. you need to get to the core of a planet. you just started the game and have to get to a planet center, with lame digging tools and almost no fighting equipment. with monsters that can kill you as fast as saying "blarrghh". oh, and you constantly falling in holes/caves full of these monsters.
[b]you can't aim up and down when fighting[/b]! I mean, with guns you can. but not with swords. why??? plus, the terrains have LOTS of mountains, so you find yourself constantly swinging a sword 10cm above a monster that is not hit by it.
[b]the hunger system[/b] adds NOTHING to the gameplay. really nothing, its just boring. a hunger bar that lower over time, so you must eat to avoid losing health. no other needs, only hunger. it gives the impression that when the game was ready, the devs said "hey, let me just add a hunger bar in 5min before launching the game".
and last, but not least: [b]NPCs are RETARDED[/b]. you constantly get quests from NPCs, and lots of these are about rescuing someone from some other place in the planet you are. so you fight all over the way there, with all the combat issues, find said NPC, and start to escort him/her back to complete the quest. but remember, NPCs in this game are RETARDED. so the NPC keeps moving around you like a fly moving around a lightbulb, even when you are figthing hostiles! not only they do that, but they also constantly fall in holes or caves and get killed by monsters you aren't even fighting! and there is no option to issue them an order to keep standing in some place; they are always around you. I have no words to describe this situation other than infuriating. they do that ALL the time. oh, and you can try to protect the NPCs, but remember: you can't aim your sword.


so, these are the issues that moved me from a positive to a negative review. but the battle system, unbalanced gameplay and NPCs IA are the worst ones.

[b]EDIT[/b]: the game becomes much more playable and enjoyable with some mods from workshop: Frackin' Universe, Melee Aiming, and Frackin' Universe - Melee Aiming.

It's a good game with mods, but the company chucklefish has terrible ethics as well so I can't honestly recommend this game. If you do get it, I'd recommend the frackin' universe mod.

I would only recommend this game to a very specific niche, which is people who are looking for a very chill and honestly kind of boring game to turn their brain off to and just vibe. I think this game has a very similar appeal to me as something like death stranding or no man's sky pre updates. It's very barebones, very repetitive, but the visuals are nice and there's just enough challenge for it to be engaging.

Mods are pretty good for this game, I personally never play without my giant bloated modpack I've been gradually adding to for nearly a decade. I'm usually not the biggest fan of games that advertise themselves as having 'lots of mods' because most of the times the mods for those games don't really add any new content and if they do it's usually pretty mediocre, but I actually really like a lot of the mods here and I think a fair amount of them are up to par or even exceed the base game in terms of quality. It helps that one of the main drives to this game is the exploration, and when you add a ton of random mods, you're really just giving yourself more things to explore.

The devs who made this game are pretty horrible though, there's a long history of worker abuse coming from them. Consider waiting for a steam sale or partaking in 'royalty free entertainment consumption' if you want to play this game.

When words reached me about the existence of a potential "Terraria in space" game made by the same developers of Terraria- which I absolutely loved. Getting this game was a no brainer. Frankly I was expecting quite literally "terraria in space" which would have a direct transfer of everything from terraria but in a space setting. Boy I was pleasantly mistaken! This game is so much more. Perhaps the one thing missing from Terraria was the absense of a story/lore (left mostly up to the player's interpretation). This game makes up for it with a central story and various side quests to justify the in-game setting and keeps players progressing. The quests also serve as a guidance to what players need to go next, as opposed to the rather confusing "what now?" issue that new terraria players have. It was great to see that the overall mechanics of the game remained similar to terraria with the extensive crafting, combat and customizations - shaping Starbound into yet another fantastic open world rpg survival game by Re-logic and Chucklefish

Starbound is in a weird spot for me. Overall I recommend the game, but I enjoyed previous versions of the game more than the current one. Back when there were different sectors, hunger, temperature, and you had to summon bosses to get to the next tier is where I made my fondest Starbound memories. I felt like expanding on the survival aspects would make the game even better.

The devs took the story direction instead. Temperature was removed, bosses were reworked into the story (with some bosses getting the axe), and hunger (after being removed, then re-added) was made optional. The story is all right, although not my favorite.

I don't often play Starbound anymore, when I do I always play with mods.

Chucklefish is one of the few honest developers/publishers on the market. While starbound's development was shakey at best, in the end they came through in delivering a fun, wholesome game. They haven't bothered their consumers by cutting out content and telling us to pay extra for it through DLC. Instead they've done exactly the opposite - they have developed intuitive, exciting gameplay delivered by free updates. You don't even have to click the "buy this FREE DLC" button, it's just given to you. What bros.

Starbound itself is more of a game about building than it is about exploration, which is where Chucklefish went right when they came through with the Colony update. Exploration isn't exciting what so ever, almost every planet is the same. And this is where they fall short - a major point of exploration is that you can see all these sights and views in the distance. This is impossible with the 2D format - where you'll only know you that the planet has impressive mountains until you're climbing up them.

So it could be said that this game is Anethema to No Man's Sky - where No Man's Sky has beautiful views and encourages exploration, Starbound presents a game with challenges, difficulties, and generally fun content for the trade off of lack of an incentive to explore. It does however make up for it's lack of explorative incentive and the restraints of the 2D world by having creative and alien biomes with unique monsters and animals inhabiting them. The only problem is, is that those biomes are still fairly common sights.

The challenges it presents can be in the form of evading rampaging monsters to fighting god-like boss monsters to bringing in bandits (the next free update ;D) to navigating platform obstacle courses. Surviving the night can be a challenge if your equipment simply isn't up-to-par with the local ecosystem. And as an aside to this, the rewards for some of these are actually worth it and interesting - it could be a randomly generated sword that shoots lightning or the pre-scripted sword that rips a whole in the time-space continuum - or a staff that heals allies, or a gun that sets enemies on fire or even the flamethrower. It isn't all weapons either. You can get pokeballs (fucking try saying they aren't pokeballs, Chucklefish), resources, valuable components, generally stuff that is actually kind of hard to come by and is needed to advance in the game.

Yes! There is advancement. There is even a story (this was exciting for those of us who bought it a long time ago)! Personal advancement comes in the form of your ship - which is different for each race. There are 6 (? I forget, might be 5) upgrades which can only be unlocked by recruiting 2 crew members per upgrade. That is unless of course you're a dirty, dirty scumbag who buys a fake license to upgrade your ship, but I won't judge.

The characters you'll find in the game are lacking at best. They typically say one thing, and one thing only, but they pay me to live in my huts so I'm okay with that. I do, however, wish they'd have some variaty in their words. Chucklefish is fairly wholesome, with the NPCs being typically cheery or humorously depressed. You can get them to live in your houses by buying a deed, and if you don't like how they look you can evict them by destroying teh deed and puting it back up. NPCs will walk around and converse with other NPCs, although you can't hear them. They'll run from monsters, or fight back if they're guards. They're fairly worked out - just need some more pathfinding (they tend to get stuck at the bottom of places even though they can walk out) and some new dialogue.

In short, I recommend this game.

EDIT 2022: This uh, didn't age well.

A very polished game with all the aspects that make a sandbox game good. BUT some elements of it almost made me want to not reccomend it.
Pros:
-Decent amount of content
-Vast semi-randomly generated universe
-Terraria-esque progression
-Game has its own plot and story, which is totally optional
-Instances and missions (some procedurally generated, and some are designed by devs)
-Plenty of things to do once you've got the best gear and finished main questline

Cons:
-No map of current planet you're on
-When you die, you may have a lot of trouble finding your items, since there is no map, and the planets are huge and loop around
-Even though your spaceship orbits around planets, you still aren't able to change your spawnpoint on a given planet, so going back to some locations on bigger planets can be really tedious

So, all in all, a decent game, BUT Its lackluster of essential elements - like a map for example -is really off putting

This is honestly such an underrated game. When I first bought it I put an hour or two in and didn't really care for it as I was coming from Terraria expecting this game to be something it isn't. But now that I came back to it a few years later I can see how horribly wrong I was for not giving this game a second chance. The amount of content there is just in exploring different planets and seeing whats in the universe is amazing. The fact I can go to a planet and build a base and put down a teleporter to instantly travel between my base and ship is incredibly satisfying. Then to implement the space stations as another way to make a base (although they are incredibly inconvenient) just adds more depth to late game exploring/creation. As someone who is a sucker for customizing and having different options for bases I find this game incredibly enjoyable just in that regard. Not even mentioning the enemies, bosses, allies, and the dozens of other mechanics that I left out. I give this game a solid 8/10.

This game isn't bad... but it does have issues and quite a few at that. Most notable is that even when playing Singleplayer you'll likely experience latency issues due to everything essentially functioning on a server. This is because the game calculates the time and position of all planets in a system, or even throughout every system you have generated. Worst part is that enemies will still be able to move even when you're seemingly frozen in time briefly, making the enemies not very fun to fight against. This issue more or less vanished when you're going through various instanced dungeons/missions and the combat becomes tolerable. So... more or less too big of a universe that operates based on a server even when you're playing by yourself and enemies that can still move even you can't. That's the big two. There's another minor complaint in a lack of planet variance where if you have seen one planet type then you've seen them all.

So... what's good? As I'll almost always point to, the OST is pretty decent and I never noticed it ever getting repetitive. Every planet type has its own playlist of music that'll play as you explore the surface or the underground, which has its own playlist of themes too. Also, the building I'll say is better than Terraria's. You have countless block and furniture types to choose from when building a base planetside or customizing the interior of your spaceship. There's even plenty of cosmetic choices for your characters between cosmetic items and armor. Also, the races you can choose from are mainly for looks and some minor weapon variance when crafting. Also, your various mining tools have the ability to mine multiple blocks at once and you can switch between placing blocks 2x2 or just single blocks just by holding down your walk key (shift by default).

So, overall the game has issues but it's not all bad. Even some of the things I listed that I think are bad can remedied with mods if you so wish. Though I'd advise playing through completely vanilla at first before delving into mods.

Starbound is one of the most fun games I've played! It scratches the itch for exploration, with sooo many planets in different galaxies all over the place, you have lots of weapons and cool tech, and one thing I love about the game is the many NPC's you encounter and that you can make your OWN colony of people that move in, even Merchants and Guards, and they pay you rent in money (Pixels is the game currency) and they can give you other gifts too and more if they ask you to do quests for them. And not only that but when exploring planets you may come across a village of npc's who can also sell you items and give quests. Even if your deep in the world you may come across a house in a cave with some merchants hanging out! And when exploring the depths or mining you can come across chests with loot! This game even has a Pokemon like mechanic where you can catch monsters and have them fight for you. This game is just very fun. Yes the game lacks updates and development, but I just don't see the hate that other reviews say that the game 'lacks content'. It has been a really fun experience that feels like a epic adventure. Dont be afraid to give this game a try!! And of course if you want more, there are lots of mods for the game.

Despite being a 2016 game, this game basically expands on Terraria's basic concept, except this time, many themed worlds are available, each with their own unique ecosystems, and there's no shortage of mods to further build on the experience, like Frackin Universe, which seamlessly integrates mostly-realistic science into the game itself
However, it doesn't come without it's flaws - development has laid stagnant since the Bounty Hunter Update 3 years ago now, and performance suffers badly because it's designed to use 1 physical core (and one physical core ONLY, not threads) to compute everything from physics, logic, NPC AI, quests, and even the GRAPHICS. So yes, after a while, especially with a few mods piled on (particularly Build Your Own Ship (BYOS)), it will start to lag quite badly; using the 32-bit version (x64 has a memory leak related to Lua scripting whenever loading gear) and a small bunch mods online can attempt to somewhat ease the load, but won't get you anywhere too far.

Overall, 8.5/10, but best to buy during a sale!

A side-view 2D game in an open sandbox world. Clearly heavily based on Terraria, so most of my review will be comparing it to that.

I am writing this a while after I played it, so I may be fuzzy on some details.

Where Terraria has a single, large world, this game has many smaller worlds that wrap around horizontally and can be visited one by one. The goal is sort of to make your way through these worlds collecting resources and completing quests. Worlds can be revisited to build a farm or a cool structure or just to get some more resources.

You travel between these worlds with your spaceship, which is a little, expanding build that you bring with you where you go. You don't get much much creative control over it, but it lets you bring all the stored items with you.

Personally I never bothered building anything nice on planets, but I don't really do that in Terraria either.

Compared to Terraria, there seems to be a more focused progression, with a storyline and a clarity of goals that Terraria lacks, as well as an actual ending. The combat also seems more measured, as contrasted with Terraria's crazy speeds and variety of approaches.

I played the game with a mod that makes storage inventories huge, because I find inventory management to be terribly uncompelling in this type of game. To the game's credit, it made it very easy to use that mod.

Overall, I think this is a solid game. It doesn't give you as much [i]game[/i] for your money as Terraria does, but not many games do. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoyed Terraria and wants a bit more. Perhaps I would also recommend it to people for whom Terraria is too vague.

If you like playing Terraria then I'm sure you'll like Starbound just like Terraria it's a 2D sandbox survival game except with loads of differences. Instead of having one world to explore and play with, you instead get an infinite amount of planets each with their own biomes, ores, resources, atmospheres, and etc. Instead of having a housing store npcs you have npcs that could work for you, join your crew, heal you, sell you stuff, and give you never ending quests that you can deal with or ignore. Best of all unlike Terraria where the only mods you use are resource and world mods, (excluding tModLoader because that game has more mods than the original game) Starbound has a plethora of mods to play with from race mods to planet mods, from armor mods to ship mods, heck there are even mods that changes the whole layout of the game.

Now I know this sounds like I'm saying Starbound is better than Terraria but trust me I'm not, Terraria has more bosses, monsters, weapons, and armors than starbound does without the mods. Terraria has more features and updates that makes starbound look like its outdated. But overall both games have their own unique experience and I highly recommend trying both games at least.

I recommend this game cause it appeals to the builders, the miners, the collectors, the fighters etc. The universe is quite large and it is easy to download. The game can get annoying at times but it is so amazing it doesn't matter. I'd give it a 9/10 because, even though the game is amazing some of the bugs (like the ones where you teleport to a friend's ship and you just turn invisible) can get quite annoying, but this is a beta so I'm sure when some of the bugs are straightened out it'll be a 10/10 game.

EDIT: I was thirteen at the time I made this review lol. Also the game is disappointing now unless you mod it.

This game makes me so happy. My bf recommended it to me last year and ever since then I have absolutely adored this game in every way. I love decorating my ship and doing fun little side quests, collecting animals, running from a terrifying purple monster as I try to get fuel for my ship, building random buildings on random planets (I also love that there's SO MANY planets you can visit and none of them look exactly the same), and making cute farms next to my house :). There's so so many things to do in this game, it's pretty much impossible to get bored of it. You can tell so much time and effort went into every aspect of this game; from the soundtrack, the characters and their personalities, the different races to choose from, the small details in the back round and the little items you can place around. Even the monsters are so incredibly fleshed out. I will never get over how amazing this game is, so if any of the things I mentioned in my review sound appealing to you, I recommend you pick it up and give it a try :) <3

Starbound is boneless Terraria in space. It forfeits the conquest progression format for a loose narrative and quests whilst happening also to be in space. The space aspect of Starbound is it's biggest boon, your possession of a space faring vessel makes the game at the least "big Terraria" at a glance, as you can travel to literal millions of stars each with dozens of planets and moons. However, the comparison to Terraria is only surface level as Starbound takes a far greater interest in building lore, narratives and colonies than battling increasingly challenging bosses. 

If you've ever wanted to explore a oddly mundane sci-fi future, or just wanted to build your idyllic blocky pixel settlement into the side of a hill that just so happens to have aliens in it. Starbound is the game for you.

I love this game. In my opinion it is better than Terraria and has potential for endless hours of game play with mods. There has been no update as to how to fix this issue since 2018 and none of the troubleshooting methods have worked. If this issue were to be fixed, the game is a 10/10. But it causes the game to not even be able to launch.

Yes, objectively, I can recommend Starbound as a game. The story goes that you are a member of a massive intergalactic alliance of intelligent civilizations in the far-flung future called the Protectorate. This alliance was formed in response to the birth of an entity known as The Ruin, which was an incredibly powerful cosmic entity that had a bitter hatred for all life and goodness and sought to destroy all of it. This entity was stopped by another equally powerful being called the Cultivator, who sought to protect and nurture life in the universe. But in doing so, the Cultivator gave up their powers and ceased to be. After that, the Cultivator chose six different intelligent species to protect the universe from evil in his absence and gave them "keys" to a failsafe that would allow them to defeat the ruin should it ever rise again. Well, when you start the game, a ceremony on earth officially welcoming you into the protectorate is abruptly brought to a halt when the Ruin makes a sudden reappearance and destroys earth. You hijack a small space vessel and flee the planet, taking much damage in the process but nonetheless making it out alive. The end result is that you awaken in your ship orbiting an uncharted planet, and it's your goal to fix your ship, travel the universe, and find the six keys you need to destroy the ruin forever.

Honestly, it's got amazing gameplay. It's in the 2D style, much like Terraria. But the difference is that you have a massive universe full of procedurally generated planets to travel around and harvest resources and build neat things. You can expand your spaceship and build practically anything you want in it, even turn it into your own cozy little home. You can acquire a great deal of weapons, clothing, armors, gadgets, collectibles, and even vehicles. You can visit all types of settlements on planets, each with their own aesthetics and architecture. One type is modeled after an orwellian dictatorship. Another is modeled to be like a feudal kingdom. Another is a theocracy. They all have their own fully fleshed out cultures, traditions, languages, and history. It's incredibly fascinating and frankly, All of this, combined with the fact that this game is highly moddable and has a large, thriving modding community, I would dare say there is thousands of hours of content even after beating the main storyline. If you're looking for your next addiction, this is absolutely worth the price.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

EDIT; 2nd time review

I've come back to this game as I've gone through a game drought throughout the year. Do I still recommend this game? To an extent. It follows a specific niche as with any sandbox orientated game; you're forced to create your own story alongside the main game's story, should it be provided.

Starbound has a interesting story; not in a good or bad way. I believe that the story was much more illustrative with its mission designs + music to show you a story, rather than tell you. Not to say that it doesn't tell you anything- it does, but it isn't super deep. The jist being that you're finding artifacts from a select few races to face and destroy the Ruin. There's not a whole lot of exposition regarding why we should deem the Ruin as a threat, as they are hardly ever seen in the game excluding the two missions that are at the start then end of the game. My guess would be that the Cult is meant to stand in for them, but I never found them to be super imposing. They weren't "progressive with the story", even when you do the Peacekeeper quest; they didn't act like a cult but rather a generic goon-based faction.

The Loyalist Apex being under the Miniknog issue was a story in of itself but it was never expanded beyond the mission you learn of their antics- a mod expands upon this (Starforge, I believe?) by adding the Unbound. Anything expands the (arguably) short and simple story can make the game more enjoyable for people looking forward to playing a story-orientated game.

That being said, if you're looking for a story orientated game, I advise checking other games unless you want something short and sweet.

A huge talking point to me is the atmosphere and music of the game. All I need to say is that this is the type of music you'd vibe to in many scenarios. And if you're not vibing, you're relaxing to a methodical orchestral melody. The music alone is far more expansive than the story is trying to be and what it wants to be- recommend listening to the "Jupiter" track (a fine damn shame that it isn't on the OST...)- it's a strong song that can easily sum of the premise of the story ("Everything you had was lost. All your friends, gone. Nothing remained but you and your ship. But the stars out there beckon for your arrival and exploration. And who knows... maybe there is a small remnant of what you remember being what used to be a part of you- go on and be free.")

Starbound is one of the few games that I've played that has a OST that is complementary to the scenarios you are- the other game being Halo (especially Martin O'Donnell, Michael Salvatori and Steve Vai). I was surprised to see that Toby Fox was involved with the game when I glanced at the credits the 2nd time I played through the game. However much involvement he had, if any, I can tell there was some influence. 

The music is simply exemplary, nostalgic, and timeless. A quality that few games I've played and heard of that reach this qualitative perfection. But that's my opinion.

I'm not a huge gameplay nerd unless the experience is too janky. Starbound's control scheme and UI is simple if not a bit annoying at times (your inventory always going to your middle), but it's not horrible or unplayable. 

Comparisons to Terraria? They're there, but it's often something very specific and niche; I believe there's enough difference between the two games to make them much more distinct. I'd give many examples but I'd end up making a document on the differences. The main ones I'd like to point out is that Starbound as a actual by-definition story, bearing that you go on a series of quests from the start and end with a motive. Does this mean Terraria has no story? Not exactly, if you want to count obtaining all the Town NPCs and defeating all the bosses as a story whilst understanding the original out-of-the-game 'lorebook' of Terraria.

If you can find significant replay value with Starbound- friends or not, then it's a good game. But I would strongly advise looking forward to the content-based mods (stay away from the workshop if you're extremely sensitive to NSFW, apparently people have a pixel-kink...), as they heavily improve upon the game. 

If you're looking for a time killer, I suppose the base game + various amounts of mods make this a good game for killing time. There's alternatives for sure, but I do appreciate some time into this game from time to time.

All in all? I'd give it a 8/10. I like the atmosphere the game has alongside its music, but the story could use some improvements in its length and depth. The music is simply astonishing and I'll never forget it.

It's an okay game. Honestly my first impression was bad and I even wanted to neg review it, then I got out of the first planet and it blows your mind with stuff, but once I sorted everything out 50 hours later I was, like, "that's it?". 

Starbound is a game that lacks depth. It got breadth instead. I might even go as far as to call it a collection of minigames. 

The core of Starbound consists of the following:

[list]
[*] [b]main game[/b] - it's your classic minecraft-like survival that consists of a cycle of search minerals - upgrade equipment - go up a difficulty tier - repeat; do it six times and lose reason to dig down below ever again. Only reason it'll take more than 5-6 hours is them making the baseline mining speed damn slow. 
[*] [b]main story[/b] - it's a combination of exploration and metroidvania, it's cool and I got nothing bad to say about it.
[*] [b]sub story[/b] - a roguelike game mode where you take the role of a space cop and arrest criminals hiding on different planets; kinda grindy, but arguably one of the best experiences the game has to offer and the benefits are adequate. 
[*] [b]sub game[/b] - a side scroller shooter where you pilot the mech through space. Looks neat at first but it's kinda pointless, repetitive, clunky and not very fun by itself, and very, very grindy, honestly I couldn't bear to see the end of it. What's a high end mech is good for? Well, it's necessary for some of the sub story missions. Other than that you can beam mech down the planet and use it for exploration, but it isn't terribly efficient and you've got a time limit. That's about it. 
[/list]

There are also several collection minigames:
[list]
[*] [b]Cooking[/b] - a minigame where you scour planets for edible plants, build a megafarm and explore the cook book. Just in case you miss Stardew Valley for some reason. 
[*] [b]Fishing[/b] - your typical fishing minigame, very grindy, very stupid and virtually no reason to play it seriously. 
[*] [b]Monster Taming[/b] - a minigame where you capture monsters by throwing a ball in them, then you would be able to use them in combat. Unfortunately there are no evolutions and no gym leaders, cocky rivals and single letter evil teams to beat the crap off.
[*] [b]Archaelogy[/b] - a minigame similar to battleship where you scour depths for fossils so that you could build your own theme park, with blackjack and dinos. 
[*] [b]Bug Catching[/b] - a nerdier version of Archaelogy, just in case you've got a spare several dozen of hours so that you could brag to your friends about it.
[*] [b]Figurine Collection[/b] - a simulator of the korean MMO drop rates that will make you wish there was a real money cash shop. 
[/list]

The endgame offers you random metroidvania dungeons where you could grind for resource to be able to do things that are kinda redundant by that point anyway. Or at least that's what the game sells you as endgame, but it's not a true endgame. True endgame is building gigantic colonies and populating them with NPCs so that you could brag about it on Reddit. If you haven't turned a single planet into Coruscant you didn't really play Starbound, sorry. 

Bottomline is I liked the game a lot and it was very much worth it for me, but it's not really the kind of game to come back into because every new playthrough will feel rather same-y as the previous one.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Very adequate

This isn't a game. It's an experience.

The story isn't anything impressive but it's not all that important after the initial start to the game. You will make your own story. It will be born of your experiences and desires. I've had numerous characters live completely different lives.

Wanna be a bounty hunter? A freighter pilot? A colony manager? A farmer? A soldier? This game's got you covered. Keep your expectations realistic and you won't be disappointed. The systems for all these things exist but when you have this many all in one game, you already know that they can only get so deep. However, you can switch gears anytime you want and do whatever interests you in the moment.

Artwork and music are charming. Combat kinda favors melee weapons which is disappointing but, you can brute force your way or use mods to achieve viable ranged options. Lore is actually pretty interesting (wasn't really expecting much in that regard but found myself collecting books and reading them as I went).

I definitely recommend watching some Let's Plays just for diligence sake but I doubt you'll regret buying this.

Also, check out Stardew Valley (by the same developer) if you haven't already. Completely different game but also amazing.

If your a terraria fan, you'll love this game. it has things in it similar to terraria, but much more and it is in my opinion much better - as it has much harder bosses and a better tiering system for items and has different planets and ships and stuff, and in a later update you will be able to make your ship bigger and make a whole storyline yourself for a public server and even more! 

edit, as of 11/21/2021: Was a beautiful, great game, but slowly cannibalized itself and never finished/updated features that were being added that were genuinely good at the same time, leading to what deserves to be a 10/10 game to being mediocre at best, and the modding scene doesn't REALLY fix it unless you like Frackin' Universe and don't care about anything else, despite how many good mods USED to exist in the modding scene.
Still can be fun but.. I don't recommend buying this game anymore, not at the time being. Would love for that opinion to be able to change.

If you've always wanted to go left or right and end up exactly where you started, this is the game for you. This game has it all: Teleporters, flags, a cat that gets in the way of operating your spaceship controls, and murderous penguins. You will die on regular mode, a lot. You can gather lava with your mining tool and drop it on top of people's homes, causing their homes to disintegrate. I forced an entire village of peaceful medieval robots into a pool of lava. Now I am the Butcher of Melianal II. You can't join a cult, but you can kill cultists, so if you hate groups of people who wear purple robes this is great. I spent way too much time building land bridges across vast lakes of lava, and I would do it all again.
