Chucklefish has officially dropped support for Starbound and the game is now supported only by it's community.

In most cases, I would say this meant the official death of the game - but in this case... It's a win for us.

The last two major updates for Starbound increased lag both incrementally and with major lag spikes happening due to some kind of processing in the background (I believe these are related to the Bounty Hunter system, but the lag occurs even without accessing the bounty system so... I could be wrong)

Many months have passed since Chucklefish stepped away and yet today alone we've seen another 4 mods added to the Workshop and hundreds, possibly thousands, of mods are still being actively updated. If you own this game and use a lot of mods you will undoubtedly see daily downloads added to your Steam Downloads page each day because of mod updates, (But each update is like 200 KB, so it's nothing lol)

On to the pros and cons...

PROS
~ Unique universe is generated when playing for the first time, giving you a one of a kind universe populated with countless stars, each of which is orbited by roughly half a dozen planets and/or moons.
~ Randomly generated gear means you can get some really cool stuff with interesting abilities even very early on.
~ Hundreds of unique blocks you can use to build with, and all building blocks can be placed in the foreground (where you can walk on them) or the background (so they form a backdrop) which is a vast improvement over things like Terraria's "wall" blocks that drastically limit creativity by ensuring you only have a couple dozen blocks to use as background blocks for your builds.
~ Beautiful sprite based graphics, with sound quality to match.
~ Clean user interface, allowing for ease of use and ease of learning.
~ A main quest line that has you visiting many interesting places, introducing you to various mechanics along the way.
~ Dozens of unique instruments that can be used alongside an expansive music library to play music in game - even in a band with friends!
~ Jump-in/Jump-out multiplayer with no need to set up dedicated servers! (But you can set up and run dedicated servers if you choose to!)
~ Combat is well balanced (for those who don't want things too hard or too easy)
~ Casual difficulty option for those who want a simpler, easier experience (also useful for just building for fun!)
~ Active community, even after the developers/publishers have completely given up on the game - With over 800 members in the Group Chat as the writing of this review! (And I didn't even know that feature existed until today lol)
~ MODS.

CONS
~ With so many things randomly generated, you will soon lose interest in the tens of thousands of planets you've never seen.
~ Drops being completely random means that you might have trouble finding exactly what you're looking for.
~ You may need to go to dozens of planets to find one specific thing you are looking for - either materials or objects that you must scan as part of the main quest line.
~ Certain mechanics are extremely limited in what you can do with them, while others provide the player with incredible depth and potential.
~ Mod mismatch is possible, and when you and your friends have different mods the game can sometimes crash or behave unexpectedly. There is a setting to prevent playing with others who do not have the same mods, but other mod systems (such as tModLoader for Terraria) allow the player to download the missing mods when they are trying to join and that feature is sorely missed here.
~ Toxic community members - They exist in every community, but it warrants a mention here regardless. If you spend a bit of time in the community you'll easily be able to spot these jerks. You know who you are, so there's no need for me to point fingers or say names.

That's about all I have to say in my completely overhauled Starbound review. Comments are enabled, so give me a piece of your mind, and I'll answer any questions I feel I can.

This game came in hard with it's mellow, calming trailers, right when Terraria was at its most popular. Right when this kind of game was trending.

The trailers offered players a glimpse into a fully explorable galaxy, with procedural generation, limitless exploration, plenty of hand crafted stuff thrown in there too.

But after a lengthy development, the focus shifted into giving the game a strong central storyline, that forced players into performing deeds on specific planets. Searching for ages for a certain thing because the game's told you to do so. Which was... not the charm of these kinds of games. The decision sent a lot of players packing. There were also many changes to how the armour works, and after what appeared to be a lot of work, the game still felt oddly balanced. Like a lot of items just didn't mean or do anything unique. Some weapons were just blatantly overpowered. Monsters in general felt dumb and weak.

To me, the shift in focus definitely killed the enjoyment of exploration. I really liked not being anyone in particular in this game, with a wide dangerous universe out there to explore piece by piece. With all of this responsibility to save the universe, there isn't really a whole bunch of time for ME, so when I am buying pets (yes there are pets) and decorating my ship, I feel like a jerk for doing it, because I should be out being a hero.

It took me a lot of mods to restore that feeling of an open universe. And by the end of it, the A.I / depth of the game's systems just wasn't there to keep me around. Sure, you could make some massive Habbo Hotel style thinger, on a deserted island on a Paradise planet, make yourself a lightsaber, and spend all day raking in the cash from punters and doing Luke Skywalker front flips off a diamond diving board into the sea.

But if you stop using your imagination and look at what's going on, the npcs are not using anything, or interacting, or doing anything in particular. Some of them are glitching out into walls, or can't figure out how to navigate the terrain. None of them have any depth beyond a simple repeating, random quest system, so after the first 5 minutes of engaging with these npcs you've seen it all.

Starbound, graphically, tonally, feels like it should be deeper, but it just isn't, so it feels weird playing it after a while. The success of it was partly because of the timing of the game's release, but there is still a lot of fun to be had here, I mean look how long I've played it before getting soulcrushingly bored.

Imagine watching the same movie, or going on the same ride in a theme park for 563 hours. You'd lose your mind right? It's a testament to how much stuff you can add to this experience yourself, in the sandbox itself if you have a great imagination, and also to how much you can add using mods. There is a specific mod, a huge one, that you can grab on the workshop, that dramatically changes the game, adding a new path you can take instead of the main story that is more open.

After having gotten almost a thousand hours of enjoyment from this game I wish I could say I recommend it but I can't. 

On the surface, this is a very pretty looking game with at times rough gameplay that can easily be fixed with the dozens of community made mods. I start having problems though, when you begin to peel back that first layer to reveal all the shady shit that's been going on underneath. 

I'd thoroughly encourage anyone reading this review to look into this themselves but I will provide a summary of many of the things I've read.

When it comes to the main game, the development is troubled to say the least. The spriters were forced to learn to code in order to implement their sprites because the coders didn't have enough time to do it themselves. Much of the game's art was taken from impressionable young artists who believed they were getting their foot in the door to be able to work at chucklefish when in reality they were just being used for unpaid labor. As well as the lead developer's alleged tendency to get sexual when he shouldn't. Hell, Toby Fox made music for this game that was rejected and he went unpaid for, that was until undertale blew up at which point it was added without his permission. 

As for the modding community, it's not much better there either. There are plenty of passionate modders here that really improve my view of the scene as a whole, but my main issue comes from the most popular mod, Frackin Universe. The gist here is that the developer of this mod has a tendency to steal content from other mods with no permission and then threaten the developers of the original mod should they not comply. There was also an instance where he made an empty public apology that many people chimed in to debunk. 

It honestly sickens me how much i've spent, and continued to influence my friends into spending on this company. If you're on the fence as to whether you should buy this game or not, don't.

Once upon a time, I said that this game was like No Man's Sky if they did more than just the tech demos. In 2022, this statement would still be true if it weren't for the fact that No Man's Sky is, at least in its content and community since its initial launch, up to now, and in the future, FAR AND REMOVED from its initial launch. 

That's a story that many have talked about, but not many have talked about Starbound. Put simply, from the last time I played this game unmodded, this game was like Terraria but in space. A lot more "adventure-like," since the game has a lot more in dedicated quests and storylines, but the similarities are apparent. By 2022, Terraria had been supported all the way to it's supposedly final update, to much fanfare, and the game is still going strong. By 2022, Starbound has only had one major update since its 1.0 launch. By all means this game is at best on life support.

Would I still recommend this game? Maybe. It's as "complete" as it gets, and it's a solid experience, but outside of a bounty hunter update, all you can get in the future are workshop mods. tl;dr Just play Terraria.

An enjoyable if admittedly somewhat shallow space exploration sandbox made all the better by an extensive modding scene that adds much-needed depth. Starbound all by itself is worth the price of purchase - modded Starbound is a true delight.

Edit: In the years since I originally posted this review other games have come and gone and I can no longer refer to Starbound, even modded, as "perhaps the best sandbox game on the market". But it is still a very good game worthy of your money, even if it failed to meet its full potential. If not for Chucklefish screwing its devs over Starbound could have been a Terraria or a Rimworld, great games that became legendary thanks to devoted developers given the freedom to do their best work, but right now it's more of a Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines - an excellent game that could have been even greater if not for production shenanigans - or a Skyrim, which was a good game for its era and has been sustained well past such a game's normal lifespan on the strength of its modding community.

But if you play without mods, the story is bad, EVERYITHING -all the weapons/worlds/missions/procedurally structures/races/enemies/ships/loot/armor- is all the exact same, few bosses are any good, many half-baked things like combat and NPCs and tech upgrades, the UI is horrible and the game lags a crap ton (when terraria doesn't while having more enemies and general stuff on-screen), and there are SO many pointless mechanics all fixed by mods, like slow crafting, loosing all loot, food expiring, many items not being on-handed, garbage damage scaling...

Only reason i'd play this over terraria is for the awesome exploration, for the mods (they completely carry the game), the beautiful spritework, the containers, those cool underwater cities, and because having a base in the galaxy is really cool.

Outside of that the game missed it's potential, which is really, really sad. I like it, and i like chucklefish, but It wants to be terraria so bad when it just doesn't have to be.

This game is great, one of my favorites even, but it really needs some improvements. It has a lot of lag and time wasting glitches that crash your game and set you back to your last save, losing all of your progress. And at a point, when you replay the game time and time again, the cut scenes get extremely repetitive. And with no way to skip you have to wait for a few minutes. And the ship, space stations, and barren planets are just silent. Its good, but really needs some updates.

On the plus side, the game has a based mod community and more things to do in vanilla than vanilla Minecraft or, to an extent, No Man's Sky. You can even make a fish tank, with actual fish.

So in conclusion, this game really do be bussin'.

Starbound is more than "space terraria" or "2D No Man's Sky". Starbound is an experience not like many others. The gameplay is rewarding, exploring planets is fun, and doing quests makes you feel good. Every race adds more layers to the game, and every mod helps the game feel more alive. There are a few cons, though. Some planets feel repetitive, and the start of the game is VERY slow. Overall, it's worth the price, but it gets very cheap at times so you could always just wait for that.

Based on information I've found online, it looks like this game was made by unpaid contributors, most of whom were children, who were laid off when they asked if they would be paid for their work. They were just banned from the development channels outright. All the art assets in this game have been made by unpaid, uncredited child labor. Modders have had their mods mainlined without credit or compensation. There's lots of information about this online.

Review at Patch: (Edit In Later)
Hours Clocked: 583 (At time of Updated Review)

I'll say this from the start, I loved, well still love Terraria. That said, I also love Starbound but for different reasons. This isn't Terraria in space and there's places Terraria is better but like Starbound I'm left wanting more.

I have played Starbound from the beginning, so I've seen all the changes for the better and for the worse. Old Bosses, old survival mechanics and just a different path of progression. It was in a manner of speaking trying to *be* Terraria in Space and, it wasn't everything I'd hoped it would be.

I liked it then too mind you, it just seemed like it was having trouble being its own game. Many updates later, here we are a game that stands on its own, and even brings things I wish Terraria could have.

If you've played neither, you will find yourself with little more than a mining tool a broken sword and a ship that could use a little bit of a tune up. Over the course of the game, you'll make your ship bigger, get a crew (or not), make a colony or many colonies (or none at all) all while exploring planets for loot, ore and decorations.

The story was enjoyable, and will push you along the progression path. You can progress without the story, picking up story "missions" with an instance of a dungeon with a boss at the end. These are optional if you just want to progress to explore tougher planets if you'd prefer.

Each planet contains biomes and mini biomes that have their own perils, flora and fauna. Some will have villages of different races in the game, some will have hostile dungeons, and others just have little unique quirks. The downside is after a while you'll see some of the same things over again and depending on your RNG, it might be annoying to find yet another village of one race while wanting to find one of another.

Combat is simple, but fun. Lots of weapons to choose from ranging from a simple sword to magic staves. There's guns, rocket launchers, bows, pistols, shields and even whips. It should be simple enough to find a weapon to suit your style, though RNG again can be a pest when all you want is a new spear and you find a dagger for the 100th time.

Even with the RNG being a pest at times, the ability to change up what you're doing at any given time is nice. Maybe you find a planet you really like and decide to build a place for yourself, or maybe make your own colony. There's plenty of themes to build with, and colonists will match your decor for the most part. There's farming to go with lots of cooking recipes, livestock and even fishing. There's also creature collecting for use in combat if that's your thing.

If you're playing in survival, you'll need to eat and while you could just eat a simple crop like rice, you could make more complex dishes for various buffs as well. My only gripe is that you eat a bit more often than I think you should, but food is easy enough to come by so you'll rarely find yourself in a place without any means to feed your seemingly insatiable hunger.

I've put a lot of hours into co-op, and being able to travel quickly to friends across vast distances is simple. You can share coordinates with one another, but also make teleportation networks in addition to if you're in a party having the ability to direct teleport to them. This allows you to help them out on story missions, or they can drop in, join your group, and teleport over to join the activity right away. You've got direct connect as well as server options, and if you're so inclined, PvP can be a thing.

Overall my recommendation of Starbound is Recommended.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Variety of weapons and gadgets leaves plenty of room to fit any style of play.
    [*]Sandbox gives lots of options.
    [*]Tired of the planet or solar system your on? Jump in your ship and find somewhere new!
[/list]

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Combat while simple, can be frustratingly so. The AI isn't going to challenge you and is exploited easily.
    [*]RNG can be a pest because finding something specific can be an ordeal if it doesn't go your way.
[/list]

[h1]The Ugly[/h1]
[list]
    [*]I want more, but the game just doesn't always scratch that itch of exploring how I'd like.
[/list]

    [*]GPU: NVIDIA 8GB GeForce RTX 3060 Ti

    [*]OS: MS Windows 11 Home
[/list]

for a game that's largely built around combat the combat is absolutely miserable... like it's either tedious and boring or just absolutely unfair.... like i beat one boss (mini-boss?) by just standing out of reach and shooting it... while another boss flies around out of reach and then rams me and kills me... and like it takes up most of the screen when it's on screen so it's not like it's all that dodge-able...

so yeah... the combat is basically i'm cheesing the enemies... or they're cheesing me.... i'm really glad i got this game on sale for 75% off.... the game isn't worth more than $5.... it is more fun when i'm playing with my family... but i wouldn't say the multiplayer is really all that accessible of a feature.... most of the online guides we found were about setting up a dedicated server which if you're not technically inclined is going to be out of reach for most people.... and the invite friends to play option we found has a lot of extra steps... and then requires you to invite your friends to your party via their typing their character name into a search field.. none of the other multiplayer games we've played are this tedious to just play together...

the building mechanic is nice once you get over the initial learning curve.... but so far the missions being purely combat focused have been basically unplayable. at least i'm playing on casual now so the broken combat (like the game lags really bad at times and like enemies will be attacking me and i'll be taking damage... but i have no control over my character... and i'm either still walking or like my attacks are lagging and will maybe happen in a few seconds)

like i'm finding all sorts of fancy weapons... but so far they're not enough to make the missions even remotely doable... i'm playing on casual and don't know that i'll ever buy anything with my pixels... so death is mostly meaningless.... but i'm still not sure if i'll ever be able to get through the missions... which means most of the game might be completely inaccessible... though if all that exists beyond the opening planet is just more boss fights and i've already found all the resources i need to build a neat looking house..... maybe the rest of the game just doesn't matter. this could still be a game to play when i'm just not feeling the much better survival crafting games i have actually completed.

the game really could use some basic key/button notifications. like i've had to look up "how do i use x" and it's "right click" but there's never any indication of what will happen when you right click on anything... so it's like right click to fly to a planet and you're on your way... but nothing in game tells you this... and in other places it actually does tell you which keys open different things. the shortcuts to select the mm tool functions are on the description of those tools...

10/10. Although similar to Terraria in many respects, Starbound has it's own unique feel with a near infinite procedurally generated world. The story is very in depth with paragraphs of information to read should you desire to. The planets, races, and items are very well thought out and balanced, and the ambiance each different planet displays is nothing short of incredible. Starbound supports multiplayer as well, which makes the game that much more fun when playing with friends. I really have nothing bad to say, other than my desire for every modern game to include voice acting.

Easily worth the price, especially if you enjoyed Terraria and are looking for similar, yet unique, experience. I don't say this much, but I wouldn't bother waiting for a sale.

I am rewriting my review now with 3630 hours of play time for a full blown and honest review.

Starbound is probably and will almost certainly remain my favourite game of all time and it truly isnt even close. Saying the game is a masterpiece is simply wrong because it definitely isn't, but what makes it so good is its modding. I am going to be talking a lot about modding.

To start off with a completely vanilla copy of Starbound, if you bash only the main quest you can probably be done in 3-5 hours. If you take your time however, exploring all the different types of planets, making farms, doing all quests, making pets, building, making outposts (etc, etc) you will be looking at the same level of replayability as Terraria, complimented by the enormous universe. It is definitely worth playing for, and i highly recommend it.

But then you open the steam workshop for the first time..

I can say without a shadow of a doubt, there is not a single game that even comes close to how perfect the starbound modding ability. They provide you with tools to create anything using real programming languages with user-friendly syntax to let new people with enough patience still create something they love. It is the greatest feature in any game I have ever played. With around 2000 hours of being an active Modder, I would say I am probably one of the better modders in the whole Starbound modding community, and the creativity I can express to make things of all different visuals extents and uses is what has brought me back every single time i have a break. Not only this, but the modding in starbound introduced me to REAL programming, and my fluency in the chosen modding language "Lua" has helped me with Computer Science in school as well as other passion projects at home.
But becoming a modder is not the only good thing about the modding community, it is also the things available  to the public to experiment and have fun with. The extents that people go to add so much content it essentially creates a whole new starbound is insane, and with the megapacks of mods you find on the workshop, you will NEVER run out of things to do in this game. 

To briefly touch on music, the orchestral perfomances are beyond masterclass and capture perfectly the tone of the game that the Devs try to create. My current two favourite songs are "On the beach at night" and "Planetarium".

Extra info:

The multiplayer implementation is pretty good too. I recommend for anyone looking for a good server to start on, "iLoveBacons" is the most popular one. with a port of `7777` and an id of `sb.ilovebacons.com` ( no username and passwords required )


TL;DR = The modding community will stop you from ever getting bored of this game, and I recommend pick it up and give it a try.

Its fun and it has a really relaxing atmosphere that Terraria just doesnt have. If you just take the game as its own thing without comparing it to Terraria all the time it is IMO a fun game. 
Comparing the two games i think is like comparing Factorio and Satisfactory. They are similar in some aspects but are overall very different games with Terraria being more fast paced and difficult while Starbound is more relaxed.

I do agree however that the game is generally vastly inferior to Terraria, and i blame the lack of Updates. The Devs seem to have completely abandoned the game before it was fully realized and you can tell. It just feels really unfinished in certain areas like planet generation for example. Honestly, if this game would still get active updates it could possibly compete with Terraria.

Despite this however, i still think it can be quite fun, especially if you get some mods and invite some friends (unless you dont have any in which case tough luck), so i definetely recommend that you at least try it.

Oh yeah and it has a beautiful Soundtrack

So here's the deal ... I love this game, so here's why i don't recommend it:

There is a negative for almost every positive aspect of the game:
The game is huge, immense you will not see every planet every star... But why would u? They are all the same, auto-generated you seen one of each kind you saw all of that kind.
And you can stick with red stars cause they have all the resources you need. And the threat is (with a good armor ) the same as on small planets so why bother with the low threat planets?

You have loads to do: You can upgrade your ship, create colonies, space stations ... but in the end it feels a all the same and has very little purpose.

Well maybe you can farm create goods sell them for pixels. That you can than use to ... well except for some pets there is really nothing that much useful you can buy ... usually have to grind stuff yourself.

Quests: Kill, create, fetch... repeat. I guess that is usually the case but no decision making, no smart way of completing them no nothing.

Now let me tell you about the multiplayer - LAN, or run your own server. No simple client to client join online game etc. ... which for 21 century and such a simple game, is really bad.

Your saves are not backed up to cloud. You loose your local disk you start again unless you back them up yourself. And your saves can get corrupted. So you then have to google the internet and figure out how to retrieve your character from backup files on your disk. Why is there no feature in the game menu?

Its a great idea, but the execution really feels unfinished, which is sad.

Starbound answers the question "What if you took Terraria, but removed all the aspects of it that make it a fun game?"

Pros:
+ Amazing premise, exploring strange new worlds and finding exotic life and civilization.
+ Huge array of blocks to build amazing bases with.
+ Awesome array of unique species with their own cultures and aesthetics.
+ Robust modding community, making the first 3 points even MORE amazing.
+ FISHING MINIGAME.

Cons:
- Fundamentally non-optimized. The game will always run on 2 cores and will not use your GPU, so the game WILL get laggy, no matter how beefy your computer is.
- A lot of incomplete ideas, mostly due to the unethical rotating-door of poorly paid interns that fueled the development of Starbound.
- Planets can be somewhat dull after your 5th or 6th one.
- Underground mining stinks.


Despite all the amazing content, the cons outweigh the pros, ESPECIALLY the first con. Modding can't fix bad optimization.

Most things about this game are middle of the road to downright bad;

...but the music? The game's saving grace. Curtis Schweitzer went above the call of duty for this game, the music of which I enjoy even today, nearly 10 years later.

I would like to say this game is great, but honestly it gets really damn monotonous if you're not prioritizing the story, and even then its boring as hell. 

"But what about the random generating planets and other randomized features in the game?", I hear you say. And to be honest it still feels very samey. About each type of planet feels like it was taken from a blueprint, and just had some things changed around to make it "a new planet." The enemy variety is also slightly boring. Some enemies are too easy, while some are just too hard. Hell, the game even holds your hand and tells you what planets are the easy difficulty and which are the hard difficulty.

The only reason I like to come back to this game is because of the workshop content, the customization, and the building. The mods for this game can help spice up the game play a little bit, but in my opinion its just not enough. The customization and building part though is awesome. Being able to customize furniture in my ship, and being able to build what I want on the different planets is really neat. You can even have your own space station. 

Sadly its just not enough to keep me from tearing my eyes out from boredom while playing. If you're still interested, then go ahead and buy it. It's not that bad of a game. It's just that it gets really boring after a while.

Edit(2022):
So Starbound, fantastic ost, very decent gameplay, overall progressions is good.

Stellaris is both an amazing sandbox and a hollow experiance. The game has issues, progression from beta to what it is now has changed so much that its honestly a different game at this point. The game controls really well, the bosses are decent at best, and there is a lot to do. 

Story: The game used to be that you were just some random person out in space with a damaged ship, now you are given a backstory as a someone who comes from earth to find away to protect the universe from some evil. Which honestly isn't to bad but I kinda wish they had kept the "you are nobody" angle, being trapped in space allows the player to have more control over who their character was and it kinda makes the game railroady as you are now hampered by the backstory.

To add on the more you play the story the more you encounter cultists and Lovecraftian horrors but the game never tries to explain who they are outside of a "they are some ancient evil", its just kinda ridiculous.

Gameplay: The gameplay is actually some of the better parts of this game, the loop is pretty much, dig into the ground and get as much ore as you can, make workbenches, do quest to progress the story so you can go to newer planets. Mining is fun, combat is pretty decent compared to other games like starbound. The bigger issues i have with starbounds gameplay as it stands is that i removed everything that made it unique. the game used to have a dynamic hot and cold system that was pretty much determined by your armor, the time of day, how high you were, and how much heat is being outputted next to you. Now its if you have this heat pack on your back the cold planets are completely transverable. Survival mechanics in general kinda got taken out of the game outside of farming and eating (although i would argue you get hungry way to fast). To even be able to experience hunger you have to play on survival difficulty or higher as apparently those who play casually and don't want to have item drop on death are just not allowed to be able to have the survival mechanics. I could go on about a lot of things but mods exist and players have already fixed most of my issues. Still salty about dynamic heat.

Modding: As stated before this game is a sandbox and oh boi does it show. By far the best portion of the game is modding it. This game has a steam workshop, a website modlist, and several other places where you can browse, download, and install a bunch of content to the game. Don't like the story of the game? BAM you just removed it, want more content in general? Frakin Universe adds so much to the game (although a lot of it kinda just baggage and extends to the point where i need a legit storage room.) You can change any aspect of the game and more than likly you will find people who have added more to the game than the devs will.

Overall: So do i like this game? Yes i very much do. Do i Recommend it? Yes, it is still one of the better sandbox survivals out there and even when you get bored you can find content to add your game to make it better.

Want to fly a castle in space? want too be a genocidal plant? or perhaps be a gas cowboy with a magic space train? well depending on what you decide this absolute 10/10 game from one of my favourite dev teams is absolutely for you. go on an adventure to stop the horror that is the ruin and make friends along the way, or bring you're own friends with co-op! if you so please give into you're inner capitalist! make a colony and build an empire! do whatever you want! build! genocide! recruit penguins! kick dreadwings ass time and time again! have fun with it and get out there!

Most underrated game of all time

The game is overall fun, probably one of the best open world space exploration sandbox in the 2D pixel format. The community adds mods to add more fun into the game, Galaxy in Conflict, Frackin' Universe, a Subnautica mod, Project Knightfall essentially fun mods just to play around with.

The only issue is that the game is very difficult to mod if you're not experienced in Starbound modding as I am, as these mods sometimes don't have compatibility with other mods so if you want to go into that league, I recommend that you read the descriptions of most mod pages if they are compatible with other mods from other creators.

But overall if you don't want to see those issues, try out Vanilla first. Or you could subscribe to "An Overly Complex Assortment of Mods" which has a grand total of 10GB, but I'm not expecting for it to work for some people buttery smooth as it did for me.

The Vanilla game has more room for improvement, would be better if CF decided to work around the hardware issues that plague Starbound.

In all honestly, this game is quite fun and enjoyable. It's a combination of: terreria, old version of no man's sky, as well as plenty of new and unique elements in the game. Combat is a bit simple, and although some things as added to combat to make it less simple such as dash, more weapons, and a mech that you get later in game, still... Don't get me wrong you do need some level of skill to truly play well, that limit is not as high as other games. Monsters and enemies have relatively simple mechanics for games (excluding bosses). However, I found that combat and mobs were not the main point of this game. Completing the story is fun, but base-building/ship-building, playing on servers, and, most importantly, mods really add much more to the game while making it fun and enjoyable.

Overall, 8/10.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Starbound, the game with sex mods because why not

Overall fun most people will call it a Terrarria clone, when you start you will starve a lot until you figure out how farming works, it has quite a weird progression locking you to 1 planet until you can repair your ship essentially having to "complete" your starting planet before being able to reach the ark where from there you're able to do much more

Wall jump, spin dash and air dash tech cards allow you the maximum amount of movement possible being able to climb vertical walls and go extremely fast when exploring planets and the wall jump giving you the ability to double jump and jump off of walls/cling

The Hylotls structures are Japanese style which for me being a massive weeb enjoys a lot and I spent around 12 hrs of my total playtime building a massive fucking temple where my starting house used to be although I wasn't able to think of ways to decorate it cause the amount of items i was dumping into chests without a dedicated storage area

Never really messed with the "Redstone" mechanics of the game which could've been interesting nor have I tried making colonies

The progression system actually makes sense if you want to explore other planets requiring you to mine in hostile territory for ores to survive more dangerous planets

The mods for this game is whack [strike] especially the sex mods [/strike] fracking universe being literally a overall of the entire games progression system that feels entirely different from the base game and the kawaii stuff mod allowing your character to look more appealing with more cosmetics as well

I didn't play the game for the story

Hostile enemies literally cant hit you with projectiles if you crouch

Fall damage is the literal worst thing in this game, you accelerate so fast its hard to react to anything and you have no air control with the added feature that your character can slip because you accidentally moved a tiny bit too much its like the floor is made of ice

The weapons and armor are very mmo like having a dedicated armor set for the specific weapon choice you want (ranger being the best because of the energy bar being the most used thing you'll be using)

No dedicated sorting system so everything is as whack as Minecraft chests, not to mention the storage units are way too small for even the bigger ones which take way too much space, its like you're forced to make a planet dedicated to just storage even if you can make your own space station

Worth noting this game runs like dog shit on integrated graphics but there is a button to shift the camera so you can actually see in front of you without having to sacrifice visibility for frames. There is mods to reduce lag but that should not be a thing in general for a fucking 2D game

Overall fun even by yourself, don't need to mention the cliche "fun with friends"

Starbound is incredible and I'm pretty amazed at the attention to detail that went into seemingly every aspect of this game. I was looking for something to sort of scratch that Stardew Valley itch but with a little more on the action side of things, and this game absolutely delivers on that front. The loot is procedural so you never really know what you're gonna find in that next container, and the weapons are incredibly varied from assault rifles and shotguns, to swords and magic wands, some coming with secondary firing modes that do some awesome stuff. I've also found "unique" weapons that are always something totally different and, well, unique, like an eyeball that shoots out worm-like tentacles. The combat in this game feels really good, though slightly clunky due to having to use keyboard and mouse. I tried using a bluetooth controller and someone's recommended controller layout, but it still didn't feel right, but as I've used the M&K more and more, I actually prefer it, even if it's still not the most intuitive control scheme.

Beyond the combat, the game has a very nice progression and reward loop. You craft better gear to allow you to explore more hostile planets, so you can mine better ore and build better equipment. The nice thing is you can also find civilizations on planets that will already have really strong gear, but you have to decide if it's worth the risk trying to find them while you're relatively weak to the local wildlife (or bounty hunters). A lot of the game is centered around mining, crafting, and farming. Farming gets easier with time as you upgrade your ship and have more space to put crops and you'll get things like sprinklers to help automate the watering process. It's satisfying in the same way that Stardew Valley felt, but I think I like it even more because there's soooo many items to collect and craft, so crops aren't simply for making money and serve an actual purpose in crafting.

The story is okay. It's very repetitive with you essentially being told to collect 6 artifacts from each major race which means a rather tedious mission of finding that specific race for the mission and "scanning" nearly everything in their villages or dungeons (sometimes you don't find enough stuff in a single village or dungeon, so you have to keep searching for more) then you are tasked with completing a unique instanced dungeon that ends with a boss battle. They're pretty easy though a nice change of pace from the normal loop of planet exploration and mining. 

The game has some nice progression and RPG mechanics, like being able to get Metroid-like upgrades for your gear that give you permanent passive bonuses, like being able to mine faster, turn yourself into a morph ball, and even give yourself a double or triple jump. These upgrades feel really good when you unlock them and make exploration that much more rewarding.

There's still so much I didn't touch on, like the Mech gameplay (also with it's own upgrades to earn and unlock), pets/minions, base-building, tenants that can offer protection or be merchants... there's just a surprising amount of depth here, but the real star of the show is the procedural generation, which will constantly surprise you with epic loot, cool biomes, and things like underground lost civilizations that you stumble upon while just digging straight down for awhile... pretty amazing what they did here. 

I did start using some mods around level 20 as there's certain things that I really wanted, like a mode that had hunger but didn't have you drop all your items when you die. You keep your equipment (something I think they didn't do in beta, which sounds awful), but if you were mining for 30 minutes and got a ton of ore, and died, you have to hope you can find your way back to your body because all of your items got dropped where you died, and after a few hours of having this happen over and over again, and not being able to retrieve my body, I just decided to add a mod to turn off the lost items penalty. I wish they would have added this option when starting a game because you either go easy mode, which turns off hunger and death penalty altogether, or you do normal mode, which has the item loss, which was just a little too much for me to bear. Perhaps on my next playthrough I'll try normal without the mod, but given that the keyboard controls are kind of clunky, I think this is a happy medium of being challenging without being frustrating.

The soundtrack for this game is PHENOMENAL! Probably one of the best I've ever heard, mostly because it fits absolutely perfectly with the vibe of the game... the music is super deep and ambient when you're traversing most organic planets, then gets a little darker when in the deeper biomes and is upbeat and tense when you're doing dungeons or high-action missions. A lot of devs (and gamers) seem to overlook music or put the least amount of effort into it, but Chris Schweitzer is a talented composer and I'm super glad Chucklefish brought him on to make this soundtracks because it is just sublime and brings this already amazing game to another level.


Anyways, give the game a shot, and once you feel like you've started burning out, consider trying the Frackin Universe (FU) mod. I haven't tried it yet, but it's all I ever see people talking about on Starbound forums, so I'm excited to try it out once the game starts to bore me, but it's still going strong for now. Sad to hear Chucklefish dropped support. The game has a lot of potential and wish they kept with it but I still think it's a stellar game.

This is literally Starbound. The Chucklefish anti-masterpiece. Like there is no joke it is actually Starbound. Please, I beg of you, go play Terraria instead of this, and if you have already played Terraria, go play Calamity. Just do not play Starbound.

As the Magnum Opus of anti-masterpieces, this game has:
- Extremely parasitic devs. If you want more info on this look it up, I'm not mentioning it much because my review may be marked as off-topic for just mentioning this, but this should 100% be taken into account before buying.
- Horrendous story that gets in the way of sandboxing in a sandbox game.
- The fact that it is LITERALLY Starbound.
- It is literally just not good.
- Has all the same issues as No Man's Sky at launch, but amplified due to lackluster base-building and the atmosphere is worse, you don't feel "Starbound" in this like you do in NMS (again, at launch) basically NMS but in 2D form. For some reason unlike NMS at launch, this has "Very Positive" and not "Mostly Negative".
- All mechanics are either watered down versions of Terraria's or just different to try and make you not think this is a Terraria copy, but it ends up being more tedious to use.
- Extremely uninteresting enemies and bosses after you fight 1 or 2.
- Everything which is not blatantly hand-crafted has mediocre at best repetitive generation.
- There's hundreds of other issues I have not mentioned states in other reviews of this game.
- Go play Terraria.
A beautiful game ruined by greed

Starbound is a GREAT game! Despite what some might say about it being old, the developers not working on it, or other negative ideas, it still has a very active modding community! The base (vanilla) game is great, with a pretty fun story, and the entire universe (stars, planets, monsters, quests) is procedurally generated, giving near infinite playability! Play as a multitude of space-faring races/civilizations and explore the universe! Not to mention the extensive modding community. Once you've played through the game in vanilla, adding mods from the steam workshop, which is super easy to do, adds many quality of life features, and anything you can imagine! Super fun with friends, and definitely worth your time and money!
fun game. especially with friends
yes.

I've been playing since early access (on another account, so I have about 100 hours less time on this one) and Starbound is my favorite game on pc (simply bc it checks all the boxes for me) but even then I can't recommend it as is. Devs got their kickstarter money, made a minimum viable product and left it as is. There's plenty of unfinished stuff in the gamefiles. 
The modding community is literally doing Chucklefuk's work for them and making the game actually fun to play.
At most I could see some kid having fun playing it vanilla but even then I think they'd get bored fast and just simply forget the game's existence.
I want to make this a neg review but only give a positive due to the efforts of the modding community and their hard work (Fracking and Arcana are amazing). I could write a whole blogpost about the goods and bads of the game as a whole but eh.

Tldr: You need to spend some time finding good mods or don't bother. It's bad. 
With the mods you like: a stupid amount of fun.

aight
I have played this game from early access and watched it grow and it it truly a wonderful game. Not Terraria but still really good!!

I love this game. There's many neat things it does that make it really cool to me.

- Because your ship is basically your home, you really just need one world to grow food on and can explore the rest of 'em with no cares

- Though a lot of the food growing process still needs to be done manually, you can somewhat automate the watering of plants early game by exclusively using tall plants, and having a thin layer of water at the base.

- You basically always have your trusty matter manipulator, so the standard tools you see in this game (aside from weapons) just give you a boost

- Speaking of the weapons, fancy ones look to be auto-generated, giving nice rewards. They also work nice for the point in the game you would find them at.

- The bosses are really fun

- Plenty of character mods to add funky races to the game, to the point that a major made up species (Avali) looks to have gotten popular by this.

It is a great game.

Really great game with lots of content. You could spent hundreds of hours playing it. Absolutly worth trying.

Whereas Terraria is a hectic boss-rush game, this is a chill planet exploration and landlording simulator.
The playable races are very unique and distinct, with some charming Florans even cosplaying as mushroom people that sell quiche. The story holds some cool rewards and it introduces you to the various cultures, with dungeons and boss fights to boot..

Honestly where the game shines is getting lost in a random hole in the ground, or while building your dream mansions, because the tile and clothing variety is just that good.

The random quests you get from villagers (pre-existing or your own) range from charming (growing plants, exchanging gifts) to dangerous with long walking distances (bandit hunts, rescuing villagers).. They do get repetetive. Same thing with the last expansion, the bounty hunting DLC. It was fun for 2 loops in one playthrough, then it got rather stale. The same goes for the previous mech combat addon. It was a very cool idea. But the inclusion into the main game is just.. not quite there.

For repeat playthroughs a lot of mods exist, ranging from custom furniture, races and quality of life patches.
I like to start Starbound back up again sometimes with a mod that makes the story optional just to build a little shanty town or two.

Cute artstyle, amazing soundtrack, and fun exploration. There are tons of planets to explore and tons of awesome weapons and items right off the bat. You can get awesome guns and other magical items on the first planet. Blends fantasy and sci fi into the game with things like staves and wands.

Also lots of weird wacky items like a ball of gnomes you can throw at enemies to kill them.

So, this game is a good sci-fi sandbox. Exploring, discovering, crafting, and exploring more is a fun gameplay cycle. (I would tentatively recommend playing with the Frackin' Universe mod, as it greatly expands this cycle.) However, combat is by far this game's weakest point; you are vastly too fragile to consistently survive battles with stronger foes, especially if they outnumber you. And, unfortunately, to progress in the main questline, the game sends you on a series of increasingly-difficult combat-missions. It's frustrating.
Sci-fi terraria the perfect mix.
it has squares
I have played this game for twelve hours today.

Y'know, I have a lot of complaints about the game. I, personally, find it intensely boring to actually play. How just.. un-fun the combat is? The fairly easy bosses, the layers of RNG to actually get a weapon that's weird and behaves weirdly and is fun, the boredom I've experienced spending hours searching for a *gold* duck or looking for specific temples so I could progress the main quest, the fact that the ending partly feels weird to me "oh no ur dead but you're brought back to life by the sacrifice of some cosmetic entity" because we can get evaporated in lava and be cloned at our ship (unless you play on no respawn), how any difficulty lower than easy requires you to eat every 5 minutes..

The fact that settlers will attack you if you pick up blocks that belong to them, and the fact they live on a volcano planet that burned their entire goddamn settlement to the floor is never a factor that's registered in that. Or that "Oh boy, cool mechs!" just ends up being boring with how slow and clunky they are?

I COULD go into detail about that or just.. mention that chucklefish was accused of exploiting and abusing dozens of people (or more) who contributed to this game. 
Given that, I'm not surprised that thi sgame turned out the way it did. Power to the people who still want to make it a decent thing, but I ain't playing it again with that knowledge (nor do I intend to buy further chucklefish products.)

That's all.

It's a sidescrolling sandbox game where you fly across the universe in a conveniently pilfered/acquired spaceship, and fight monsters made of what I assume to be giant wads of bubblegum. The movement feels fluent and it's really fun to jump around on low gravity planets, and while simplistic, constantly being worked on, and a little broken when it comes to shields, the combat is really nice.
The fact that it has an amazing and dedicated modding community makes it ten times better. For an early access game, I'd say it's worth every cent I spent on it.

Edit: Well, hindsight is 20/20; that phrase being *another* thing ruined by the passage of time.

I wouldn't buy this game because it's giving the "devs" money for basically forcing their community members to do unpaid labour in the form of programming and artwork & throwing it all together in a hopefully coherent mess that is vanilla starbound, then not even crediting them after making them work like slaves. Even Toby Fox himself got caught up in this mess, as one of very few people who actually got credited, probably just trying to leech off his fame. 

As for what reason other creators weren't credited is beyond me. You're not even giving them an opportunity to use their work on the game as a reference for employers, just pure malice.

If you buy it anyways, vanilla starbound is complete trash. It's a bunch of unrelated mechanics that don't work together resulting from everyone working on this game having a different vision for what starbound should be.

On the other hand, since vanilla starbound is basically just a game engine with a bunch of unrelated mods slapped on top of it, this game has really good mod support. This lets you tailor your experience to make it into an actually good game.

It's up to you whether you deem getting access to this game's workshop is worth supporting this kind of malpractice from the "devs". I bought this game years ago before knowing what was happening behind the scenes and if I did I would not have purchased this game.

This game had a lot of potential. Its idea was new and interesting, but sadly I can't really recommend this game to anyone. The best parts of planet exploration and building your own ship and crew are brought down by an uninspired story that the game forces you into. While some of the missions are fun, they get boring really fast on repeats of the game. In fact, this game has virtually no replay-ability besides bland structures and planets that barely reward the player for exploring. Even when you do find interesting structures or planets, it's still a nightmare to navigate and fight through due to horrible physics slowing progression to a crawl and tasteless, boring combat.

With mods this game is actually playable, Frackin' Universe is glorious.

TLDR: the truly good and innovative parts of this game are blocked behind bad controls, an meaningless story and boring combat.

This review is more for future me when I think hmmm why did I uninstall and hide this game rather than you, the reader, as I suspect most people who were going to buy this game have already bought it.

This game is garbage.

The combat - garbage: monsters damage you if they touch you, and on top of that they'll have random attacks. Nothing is balanced, when you first start day one blobs will kill you in two hits, and you lose 10% of your money when you die.

The itemisation - garbage: The whole time I've played chests always contain the same 3 or 4 items. Sometimes you'll get an upgrade chip, but mostly you'll just get some plant fibres, a salve or two, and some hunting spears.

Equipment - garbage: You've only got a handful of equipment slots and none of the equipment you get seems to actually increase your offensive/defensive capabilities.

Character progression - garbage: You can improve your ability to dig soil faster, but that's about it.

Graphics - garbage: Seems redundant to say, but lordy. It reminds me of Commander Keen.

Sound - garbage: At one point I had to actually pause the game and turn off my speakers and I could swear I could hear a car alarm going off, but no it was the game. Plus there are no audible notifications for anything useful, like for instance a low health warning.

I tried mods to improve the experience, but all it did was slightly polish a turd.
It's actually quite fun. I was skeptical but the game is totally worth full price.

starbound

BEFORE ACTUAL REVIEW: There had been accusations of young developers not being paid for their work, and chucklefish responding with the usual corporate: "sorry (nor sorry)" spiel. So if outside factors like that affect your decision then this if a FYI. Second, my game is [b] HEAVILY MODDED [/b] so my review might misremember or misattribute features as from a mod when its actual from the base game. 

Starting with the main/side quests and story:

The main quest is incredibly short with a handful of handmade quests with their own. SPOILERS for a short summary of the quest line/ story, though it's not much [spoiler] After the intro mission, its another 7 missions with one being handmade and the other six being a collection/ search mission where you find (actually random) artifacts, then go do a hand made level. After the six, you then go to a somewhat randomly generated final level dig deep and kill the two bosses: The end. That is the whole game. [/spoiler] Despite the main quest, the lore (If you care for it) is fairly expansive for what it should be, each species having their own lore from the Aztec warrior Avians to the Oppressive Apex government fighting against rebels. All of it is told via letters, books, NPCs, and buildings/ levels that you find throughout the game. I do wish however you could influence these events. Maybe seeing Avians praying to their god in a circle or Apex rebels fighting government agents on a random world. At most you'll find a rebel camp or avian tomb that you could visit but that's it.

Characters have... character. I honestly felt more attached to the NPCs in Terraria then I did with any in this game. Other than the side protagonists it's all randomly generated Tenants and crew members, which without mods were mostly annoying with crew members standing in front of crafting stations. Ironically the tenant system is a bit more in-depth in comparison with the Crews, as tenants come in different unique clothing and quests (though its still all randomly generated) and guards with their own variation coming in different looks. Admittedly i didn't delve too much into it as with BYOS I had those tenants on my own ship rather than on a planet and I didn't see any quests offered by them (again this was on my own ship using Frackin Universe's BYOS feature). 

Soundtrack was pretty decent, I enjoyed the orchestral parts music that fits your environment, though maybe it's because I'm a sucker for that type of music. Another thing to mention is that the game has six hours of the OST... which is... very impressive, as most indie games I've seen have around an hour or maybe two of music, this game's six hours is on another level.

A good 80% of the game is randomly generated, planets, enemies, structures, biomes, characters, weapons, etc. Which to me is awful. I would have preferred 15 or 20 handmade planets with 30 or so Randomly generated planets. The handmade being homeworlds like Earth or places where resources are guaranteed to spawn. Not the 12 Quadrillion planets that I've heard, which is strange because you really need around 9 planets to finish the game .The universe is apparently persistent among characters, with a simple need of the coordinates to see where your other character is located.  I've tried to reach a planet with a pre-made base I made with my first character with a newer character, only for the map to move so far away that it would have taken 999999 fuel to actually reach. And the camera moved to quickly that I wouldn't have been able to even chart a course over to my old base. 

A major gripe I have is how the game NEEDS mods to be good. I've seen a lot of people in different games attribute mods to being part of the original game and so because they tailored their game to their own likes, the game itself is good. Which I disagree, if a game needs mods to be good then it isn't a good game. But mods like Frackin Universe add features that I feel like should have been part of the original game such as... BEING ABLE TO BUILD YOUR OWN SHIP. Which is a massive oversight on Chuklefish which should have been in the game already. FU brings in the research tree, different weapons, abilites, etc. which makes the game so much better than what it was. Although I do think the people do really enjoy the game without mods, I just didn't really think the game could hold without mods and needs them to even be playable for any amount of time. 

Overall, I'll say what I saw a few other reviewers said: it's a Space Furry Terraria, and just go play Terraria. Starbound improves/ adds a lot more stuff that Terraria didn't have like vehicles (not mentioning the railcart) or body tech that allows you to double jump, turn into a samus morph sphere, and dash/ sprint without using enhanced boots or other armor. Even then, Terraria can be modded with its recent updates. And I think that kinda says for itself: Terraria, after nine years is still getting updates with a few years ago getting its last big update, and Chucklefish seemingly abandoned this game. This game was more of a cash grab riding on the back of the Terraria train, using unpaid young developers, random generated content, and advertising mods as being part of the game to make as much cash as possible. When the river dried up, they dropped the game and moved on to other games. Though I realize thats a bit harsh, I'm certain some of the devs or the composers and musicians for the OST really did put their heart into this game. Which makes me feel a bit guilty for giving this game a negative review and wish that there was a mixed recommendation option available.

If you don't mind heavily modding the game (It's been very stable for me, with only two or so crashes in the past 560 hours of me playing) or the heavy randomization that the game relies on then It could be a game for you. But the only fun I found through those 560 hours was with the FU mod and building my own ship while mining the new worlds added by mods and going through the FU research tree. So basically I found the FU mod fun, not the game itself.

My favourite sandbox game ever. It's kind of like Minecraft where I puts hundreds of hours in and never beat the game, lolz. Though it most definitely has its flaws, of which I am most definitely biased as I do love the game dearly. The story is bland an uninteresting, at least to me, and the procedurally generated planets look mostly just the same in vanilla. Though for me I don't find the value of the game in those aspects, I find them in the limitless potential for building, and finally, THE MODS.

WHERE DO I START. Think of the mods as like the mods for Bethesda games. There are endless mods to check out, which gives you endless things to do. Mods that make the story more interesting, mods that flat out remove the story, race mods (hundreds no joke), vehicle mods, planet mods, star mods, ship mods, and so SO much more. That's how I get all my playtime out of the game. Though, and I am not kidding, I know of someone who has over 42,000 hours in the game, as they mod it a lot. Not sure how I can prove it but you'll just have to take my word. And that goes to show, if you're creative and want to mod Starbound (which is very easy by design), you can get literally endless value out of the game.

[h1]Starbound: Space House Gacha Simulator[/h1][hr][/hr]
I did not play Starbound the way it was meant to be played. I used console commands and all sorts of mods, and I've not bothered with most of the fights. Mostly because that's not what I play this game for. Sure, there are cool abilities, especially modded ones, challenging bosses, but that's more the Terraria experience. Not my thing.

Graphics wise, though, Starbound probably satisfies a different niche from Terraria. More colorful, more pastel, which brings me to what I play this game for.

This game is great if you want to simply build a cozy pixel base with all sorts of contraptions and wiring justified by the scifi setting, ranging from pastel backgrounds, meadows, post-apocalyptic worlds, and much more. Even more if you factor in the Workshop.

This game is great to play with a friend, building things together in creative mode. 

Much and more time though, is taken finding a planet you actually like. There are options to manually bruteforce things, but they are limited.

All in all, great space house gacha. Will play at 2am after nightshift with friend again.

Starbound one of the sandbox games ever. And to be honest, while it can be fun, it does have a fair bit it could work on to keep the main story fresh and interesting at all, without encouraging modding the heck outta this game.

To begin, the positives are that its a game in which two playthroughs will never be the exact same, given that the universe you spawn into is procedurally generated, as well as every planet. This occasionally made loading times a little long, but it wasn't much of a problem. The universe is also superficially well fleshed out: collectable books add lore, NPCs of different races talk about their race (not in much depth, however) and other races. There's a fossil for most vanilla playable races (not novakid) and NPC races like the agaran, a moth collection, fish collection, etc. The characters you are introduced to are varied, [spoiler] Some, like Nuru and Koichi, are interesting and make sense as to why they join you at the ruins, while Lana doesn't seem to have a good reason to stay at the ruins with you, not while she's a rebel leader, and Esther...Isn't compelling, and has the personality of a boiled chicken leg mixed with your standard 'nice grandma' figure. [/spoiler]

However, despite having all of that in this game, very little of it is actually used in the main storyline. The story consists of talk to Esther, find a dungeon, scan some furniture, go to a larger, premade dungeon, fight a boss, get a thing, repeat. Also, to have even the slightest chance in the dungeons, you need to go underground and get metals to make armour and weapons. And while the underground layers of a planet are interesting in the sense that they also have mini dungeons and biomes, considering the amount of time the player will spend in them, they're pretty lacklustre. And none of the collection elements, like the codexes, fossils, or pets, are used to progress the main story. Which feels like a missed opportunity. If the game didn't hold your hand up until you find Esther, and continue to hold your hand once you decide to go on with the main story (which is optional, but will constantly have a quest marker telling you where to go), there are so many different ways you could have ended up finding out about the main bad guy, and the artifacts which lead you to them. The bosses are pretty good for their difficulty, and have varied attacks, even if the missions to get to them are the same.

After the first playthrough, go to the workshop and download some mods. They improve the gameplay by so much after one playthrough.

This game seems fun. But it's just not executed well enough for it to be worth it for me. It's missing several features common to survival/crafting games. Like a map, the ability to stack  food items in your toolbar, and controller support. Just a bunch of little annoyances that build irritation while playing. I kept Googling whether the game had x and y, but the answer always came back as a no. 

Overall this was such an annoying experience I don't think I'll go back to it. 

Also, I'm not sure if I just had bad luck or if it's a game issue, but I feel like there's not enough underground loot. Ores were sparse and there were no other pickups to break the monotony.

The game is clunky and unintuitive. Having played a few similar games before, I expected some controls to work the same way but they decided to fix what wasn't broken.
The main quest actually takes away from the fun of the game, in my opinion. It wasn't fun, and was pretty much all about visiting random planets, walking all around them until you maybe find what you need, then move on. There was no reason for base building which I spent a while doing at the start.
I also had a major stuttering issue that caused my death a few times. My PC is definitely capable yet was really struggling with this game. It's a known issue since the game's launch that was never addressed.

It literally is Terraria in space, but with an actual story and purpose besides "diggy diggy hole" + "finds loots" + "fight bosses".  If you love Terraria, then this is the game for you!

Like Terraria, it can be a little difficult to figure out the different game mechanics, so I'd recommend reading a few beginners guides first.  That helped me get past the first boss and start happily building my colony. Also, I recommend not installing mods until you've played the vanilla game for a while and get a good feel for it. 

Overall, great game play, good music, the grenade launcher delights me to no end (* pomf! BOOM! *) and the building options are fantastic. Every bit of world material can be used as a background/foreground texture for building houses, so deconstruct everything that's not in an NPC town (guards will eventually attack and kill you if you start ripping and tearing apart villages). You can even remodel your ship if you so desire! 

Also, NPCs will not move into your house unless you invite them to! Plus, what you place in the room determines what race and type of NPC moves in. BTW,  Florans and Avians are the best races to play because they are so. darn. cute!!! And stabby.  I loves the stabby. :P

10/10 and almost 80 hours in within a few weeks!  I highly recommend this one!

I really wanted to like this game.  If you're looking for Terrara 2, this isn't it.  Even on the lowest difficulty setting, it lacks the relaxing feel of Terraria.  And it seems that you can generate a new map that doesn't have the resources to keep your character alive on survival mode. Just started another new game, and can't seem to find any ore.  Without ore, I cant' craft a hoe, so I can't plant crops, and thus my character will probably starve to death (again.)  
Combat is also very dependent on player skill and learning the behavior of enemies. (If you like this type of game, then you may enjoy Starbound.) Terraria combat is more focused on DPS and armor, although the boss battles do require skill.
In conclusion, I'm not saying that this is a bad game or don't buy it.  Just giving my opinion so folks can judge for themselves.

greatly addictive

Let me get one thing across. If you're looking for Terraria in space, then you'll probably be disappointed by this game. Combat in my opinion is the weakest aspect of this game since it usually devolves into repeatedly clicking over and over until the thing you're fighting against ends up dead. The final boss especially suffered from this problem in my playthrough. I managed to slay the thing by duel-wielding axes and hitting it over and over until the ending cutscene played through.

That said, I would still highly recommend this title if you're more concerned with exploration and building. The game possesses a very beautiful pixel art style which really works to create unique environments and biomes that add a lot of flavor and personality into each world you explore. The building system certainly compliments the art style since the game hands you hundreds of different block types of different themes that you can mix and match to build whatever you want. 

To me, the gameplay loop here mostly consisted of going from planet to planet to find building blocks, followed by finding resources to go onto other planets to then take their blocks. If this sounds like something fun to you, then by all means I would encourage you to try it out. I personally found it to be fun for what it was worth. 

Just let me reiterate one more time, do NOT go into this game thinking it will be space Terraria, because that's not what this game is nor is it what it was trying to be.

One more thing that is important to mention. This game has garnered quite an infamous reputation for all of the exploitation and harassment that happened during its development period. I seriously cannot recommend supporting Chucklefish in any way and I only recommend this game out of its own merit and not from its developers. If you really want to play this, I would recommend finding some way to try it out without directly supporting the company and their asinine practices.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

=======================================================================

English Review:

Starbound is a phenomenal game, unique in its kind, it is a space exploration game, which has many great things, it has item collecting, bestiary, being able to travel to other planets with your ship, expand your spaceship, bosses, monsters generated from procedural way and some others that are fixed, you can even live in it, create space colonies, history, it really has everything, it is a very addictive game and its soundtrack is beautiful, although yes, it does not have a translation into Spanish in a way official, but it is not an inconvenience since there is a mod that allows you to translate it almost in its entirety, you can find this mod in the workshop.

In the same way, the game has a great infinity of mods that make the game expand even more in terms of content, one of them is the Frackin Universe that is practically Starbound 2, it would be the equivalent of the Calamity Mod if we talk about Terraria.

Starbound resembles Terraria in several of its mechanics and sprites, but it has a lot of content focused on space and totally new mechanics, so don't be fooled, both are great games, the bad thing about Starbound is that over the years it has been abandoned by it's devs, and in fact i tried to tweet to chucklefish to make the game open source but i got banned from their twitter so the game doesn't get any updates anymore but still the community keeps supporting it via the mods, although it is a pity, since the game has a lot of potential to exploit, and who knows what the future holds, maybe one day the developers will realize this gem and update it again, this game is totally worth it although its development company does not support it, it is worth every dollar, you will always have things to do, from playing with your friends to playing in singleplayer, in the same way it has support from both steam and external servers.

And well, sorry for this testament, but I wanted to review one of my favorite Steam games <3

(This review was meant to be written a long time ago but my opinion still stands) 

As a long time player of starbound I gotta say Iâ€™m very disappointed with the official release of this game. As it stands it isnâ€™t a terrible product but itâ€™s a very sloppy one that basically requires mods in order to both work properly, feel unique, and smooth out this games very rough edges. Starbound has a great idea but it squanders it due to trying to be too many things at once, it suffers from floaty controls, a clunky UI, a half baked shoehorned story, and misses a lot of wonderful opportunities. (For instance there are a multitude of races, but they are 90% cosmetic, wouldâ€™ve been pretty cool if they had some bonuses to make them a bit more unique.) this game wouldâ€™ve been wonderful if they removed the primary story and instead focused on building up their infinite galaxy with some unique factions to join, maybe even add in some RPG elements as well, but instead we get what feels like a half ***ed terraria that completely misses the point. Because of this I sadly cannot recommend starbound simply because there are better 100% finished products out there that donâ€™t require mods in order to have a good time.

A waste of time and money, the game is really tedious and lacks content, and it doesn't receive support from the developers anymore, the only things that keeps the game kind of alive are the workshop stuff that most of the time doesn't work properly with eachother, you gotta add around 40 mods to fix up the game and make it somewhat enjoyable, and that speaks badly of the game's quality when you have to add so much mods just to make it fun, you know, the thing games are supposed to be by themselves.
The story is simple and kinda skippable, which is what I recommend since the scan quests are tedious and there's not much pay off from the story, there's not much pay off from doing quests period, the content that is there is lacking and boring and lacks a ton of quality of life stuff by itself.

It's a good game, for sure. It can be described as "Terraria but in space" but this is a bit overreaching. By default the game is a liiiitle bit shallow. You'll get some good hours of it, but once you do everything there is to do, it can become stale.
