Prefacing this with something about the stereotypes around this game. No, this is not space Terraria. Go play Terraria if you haven't, it's a REALLY good game (If you can only buy this or Terraria, buy Terraria).  No, this is not 2D space Minecraft, although it's more similar to that than it is to Terraria. During this review, I will compare this game to both Minecraft and Terraria, but that doesn't mean this game is just a clone of those.

This game has a slow pace similar to Minecraft, in which you gradually work your way across the surface of a planet, and gradually travel deeper through caves. In this game's gameplay loop, you must:
-Mine the planet's new tier of ore to upgrade your armor
-Scan for clues from structures on the surface
And optionally, you may:
-Do space missions to upgrade your mech
-Progress several varieties of side quests
-Upgrade your mining abilities, movement, and spaceship
This repeats about 6 times during the game. With so many things to do each cycle, if you get bored with one aspect, you can always just switch to progressing something else, so the game stays interesting

This game does have a class based combat, with melee, ranger, and mage classes. However, class based armor only appears around the latter portion of the game, giving you ample time to get a feel for things first. Weapons are randomly generated from a somewhat limited but still decent variety of types, elements, and abilities. Additionally, there are unique weapons with strange or interesting mechanics.

Now for one of my favorite parts of the game, the atmosphere. With earth destroyed and humanity scattered to space, you spend a lot of time slowly drifting from planet to planet, taking things slowly. There's no rush, and you'll never encounter a challenge when you're just trying to chill. The soundtrack is AMAZING and really complements the slow, laid back feel of the game.

Overall, this game is great. I'm on my second playthrough right now, with a few light mods. If it's your first time, I recommend either playing vanilla, or playing with a few quality of life mods, or the Avali race mod. (Avalis were intended to be in vanilla but were cut due to copyright issues) td;lr don't play frackin universe your first time through.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

The Developer exploited and didn't pay the workers who created a lot of this game. I wish I hadn't gave them my money. If you really want to play it, there are ways to play games without giving the developers money.

I would have never played this if I had known how it was made, with unpaid labor, children working expectantly for no financial return other than "experience", even after all the money the game was able to make. This is a product of manipulation of youngsters who couldn't tell they were being exploited all the time they were giving their time and effort to help its development. That is completely against anything I believe in, and I would never support a company that takes on such disgusting acts with their contributors.

All that said, I used to enjoy this game when I first played it many years ago, despite the storyline being quite superficial and lacking depth and the game's performance being much lower than expected in any machine I ever played it, regardless of hardware capabilities. The best part of the game in my opinion is the progression and the music.

Personally I love the way Starbound has evolved. When I first played it, there wasn't much backstory and you really struggled to find your way in the game.
Since they added much more content it has been an amazing game, where I can lose hours just exploring the planets of one system and collect amazing stuff. I usually play on casual, mostly because I just prefer exploring without the fear of losing everything and worrying about hunger.

Pros:
- Great unique biomes/Amazing visuals.
- Good mechanics that work fluently with me.
- Great backstory with unique races to choose from.
- Fun ways to build yourself a nice base/ship
- Charming 2D Grafics
- Great multiplayer which can make the game more fun to play. (Except when you have a maniac like me.)
Cons:
- Can be hard at times to figure out
- Some of the main missions are quite unforgiving and you will die alot unprepared.
- Figuring out how to get your ship running so you can leave the system. (This is a personal opinion...I'm quite the moron in figuring those things out,
- Having Q set as the default Throw button had me panic several times over throwing away my weapon during a difficult fight.

Note that I made the game potentially harder for myself as I installed two Mods called Fracking Universe and Arcana Worlds, that added even more to the game. Overall...this game had me lose several times of my life due to its grafics and sheer vast choice in terms of planets and races. If you like sandbox games that contain visiting other planets, a bunch of mobs that may whoop your butt and you have a thing for 2D grafics, this is definitely something for you.

Starbound gives me a similiar feel to Aground, which is an awesome game. I enjoy this game quite a bit. I think some of the stars on the galactic map are far too close together causing issues sometimes when traveling with your ship to other locations. I enjoy the progression though and the risk of losing all of your loot when your traveling below. If you die make sure you remember how you got there or your body will be lost. You can also use torches to show the way you traveled as you go down to make this easier. But my only real issue something that I think really needs to get implemented immediately is a map with shadow of war that gets revealed as you travel through. Not having any idea where you have been is a little troublesome and seems illogical in a game where you dig massive tunnels places for a large portion of the gameplay. At least make a device in late game that shows you paths you've taken. Other than that issue the game is pretty incredible I enjoy everything about it.

I've played this game for close to 800 hours. Please don't play it, and buy Terraria instead.

Most of those hours were in the pre-release version of the game, which while buggy and unpolished, had an incredibly more satisfying gameplay loop, focused on mining and equipment upgrades. The current version of the game replies almost exclusively on long, boring, excruciatingly unskippable quests that are designed to stretch your patience and attention span to their absolute limits. There's also the issue of the devs *removing vast amounts of content from the game* in the transition from beta to release.

The story of the released game, much hyped by Chucklefish, turns out to be incredibly drawn-out and simplistic. Earth has been destroyed! An interesting prospect, right? Wouldn't any responsible storyteller do anything to explore this unusual setting? No, all we're asked to do is to stop some nefarious individual from using that same force of destruction on aliens because... uh, well, the person in question does not like aliens, I guess. And then you stop them. The end.

Please support Re-Logic instead and buy Terraria, which is still releasing free content updates a full decade after its launch.

Starbound, a space sandbox that you explore and shape. Hereâ€™s a quick review:

Pros: 
-Infintite universe sandbox (If your pc can handle it)
-Great mod support and mods
-Not complicated (I caught on fairly quick so I donâ€™t speak for everyone)
-Endless replayability (mods take it to next level)

Cons:
-Crashes sometimes (Probably just me since I have a really old pc)
-Although the universe is infinite some star-systems/planets tend to become repetitive (Solely based if going for unmodded expierence, mods expand the variety of planets and stuff so I recommend you check some out)


Verdict: Overall good game, I bought it when the infamous exploit was found, but didnâ€™t abuse it since Iâ€™m not thirsty for steam levels. This has probably been said a lot but itâ€™s similarity to Terraria drove me to it and I liked it more than Terraria. The whole exploring space thing really caught my eye and I just had to buy it. So if you enjoyed Terraria and want something even more fun then this game is for you. Looking forward for the next big update!

Not enough QoL features, which makes it frustrating to play

-Can't quick-stack to and from chests
-Can't name chests
-Are you just supposed to backtrack your whole path after digging deep down into the planet? There's no teleport possibilities from underground (at least not one that I could find early game; Terraria for example has potions and then an item that does this)
-The quick select system for items is cool, utilising both left- and right-click, but there are two many regular-use items for just six slots

The graphics are fun and great. I love the pre-generated areas too, and that there's a story and quests rather than just full sandbox. I love that you have to find crafting recipes rather than just knowing everything from the start. But too many shortcomings with the base game to make this enjoyable for me
